Title: Presentation of a Typical Patient with Atrial Fibrillation  Slide 1: Introduction The patient  whom I will refer to as Mr. Thomas  is a 72-year-old Caucasian male presenting with symptoms suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Atrial fibrillation is the most common form of arrhythmia and is often observed in the age demographic of 65 and above.   Slide 2: Demographics According to literature  atrial fibrillation is more common in males than females  and in Caucasians than African-Americans. A 2016 study in the Journal of the American College of Cardiology shows that the Caucasian population has around a 24% lifetime risk of developing atrial fibrillation  as compared to a 23% risk for African-Americans.   Slide 3: Past Medical History  Mr. Thomas has a history of controlled hypertension for 15 years. He was a moderate smoker (15 cigarettes/day) until he quit ten years ago. He has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago which is under control through oral medication. Mr. Thomas's father died from a heart attack at the age of 80  but upon evaluation it was noted that he was also suffering from a long history of atrial fibrillation.   Slide 4: Symptoms  When presenting to our office  Mr. Thomas complained about intermittent bouts of palpitation  unexplained fatigue  shortness of breath  and dizziness for about 6 months. These symptoms were predominantly occurring during minor physical exertion.  Slide 5: Conclusion Mr. Thomas's age  gender  race  past medical history  and presenting symptoms are consistent with the majority of patients diagnosed with atrial fibrillation according to various literature sources. Further diagnosis  including EKG and echo-cardiograms  and appropriate treatment modalities will be pursued to ensure the best possible patient outcomes.   Slide 6: References  (Insert suitable references consulted for the case presentation)

Title: Case Presentation of Atrial Fibrillation  Patient Background: Our patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  living with his wife in a suburban community. He is a former smoker and has a history of moderate alcohol consumption. He leads a sedentary lifestyle but is independent in activities of daily living.  Past Medical History: Significant past medical history includes systemic hypertension  treated for 10 years. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both well-managed with oral medications. There is no past history of stroke  heart failure or other cardiovascular diseases. He had a cholecystectomy 15 years ago and no significant surgical history thereafter.  Presenting Complaint: He presented to the outpatient clinic complaining of intermittent episodes of rapid heartbeat  palpitations  and occasionally shortness of breath over a period of two months. Recently  he experienced lightheadedness and fatigue impacting his daily activities. His family also reports occasional confusion.  Physical Examination: On examination  he appears mildly distressed. His heart rate was irregularly irregular at about 110 bpm  blood pressure was slightly elevated at 150/90 mmHg. Cardiovascular examination revealed absent heart sounds suggestive of ‘silent’ or 'irregularly irregular' intervals. Other systems were within normal limits.  Investigation: A 12-lead ECG subsequently confirmed atrial fibrillation.  Discussion: Atrial fibrillation is common among older adults  particularly males. Risk factors that the patient presents with include advanced age  hypertension  diabetes  and a sedentary lifestyle. These could potentially have contributed to the development of atrial fibrillation.   The next steps encompass the initiation of anticoagulant therapy to reduce stroke risk  rate control  evaluation for rhythm control strategy  and addressing and modifying lifestyle and risk factors such as sedentary habits. He may also require additional diagnostic testing including a full blood workup to quantify cardiovascular risk factors and an echocardiogram to evaluate for possible structural heart disease.     This case illustrates the importance of timely recognition and management of atrial fibrillation to minimize the risk of complications such as stroke and heart failure. A comprehensive approach to management including lifestyle modification  risk factor management  stroke prevention  and symptom control is necessary for optimal patient outcomes.

Title: Case Presentation of Atrial Fibrillation   Patient Identification Mr. John Smith is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who presents with episodes of palpitations  breathlessness  and fatigue.  Reason for Consultation Complaints of shortness of breath  irregular heartbeat and tiredness  worsening over the last two weeks.  Past Medical History Significant for hypertension for which he currently takes Lisinopril  diagnosed 7 years ago. He was a heavy smoker but quit smoking ten years ago and has been diagnosed with COPD 5 years back. John also has a history of coronary artery disease and underwent an angioplasty 3 years ago. John is also on aspirin and atorvastatin for his coronary artery disease. He denies any major surgeries or allergic reactions. Familial medical history is significant for cardiovascular diseases.   Lifestyle He is married with two children and four grandchildren. He consumes alcohol moderately and has been abstaining from tobacco since quitting a decade ago. He is now retired but has been experiencing increasing difficulty in keeping up with his daily gym routine due to these symptoms.  Recent Examination On examination  his heart rate was irregularly irregular  and blood pressure was slightly elevated. Cardiovascular examination revealed an irregularly irregular pulse with a rate of around 108 beats per minute. There were no murmurs or added sounds. Chest was clear on auscultation.  Primary Diagnosis Based on these symptomatic presentations  the clinical examination  and his past medical history  the primary diagnosis is Atrial Fibrillation.  Plan Initial management would include rate control medication  following which he will undergo further diagnostic testing including EKG and blood tests. After confirmation  further decisions regarding anticoagulation therapy and rhythm management will be made to prevent stroke and other complications. The patient will also be counseled on the importance of medication adherence and lifestyle changes suitable for healthy heart function.  Summary In conclusion  the 68-year-old male patient presents with classical symptoms of atrial fibrillation  possibly complicated by his history of hypertension  COPD  and coronary artery disease. His lifestyle and genetic factors likely has contributed to his current condition. Evaluation and management will focus on controlling the atrial fibrillation  managing symptoms and averting potential adverse events  particularly stroke.

Title: A Case Presentation of a Patient with Atrial Fibrillation  Background   Mr. John Smith  a 73-year-old African American male  presented with the primary complaint of palpitations and episodic shortness of breath. He is a retired truck driver  a widower  and lives with his adult daughter. His symptoms have been present for the last few weeks and are progressively getting worse.  Demographics   Considering demographic representation  atrial fibrillation is more common in individuals over 65 years of age  and in African Americans. According to the American Heart Association  close to 9% of Americans over 65 suffer from atrial fibrillation.  Medical History  Mr. Smith has a past medical history significant for hypertension  controlled with Hydrochlorothiazide  and type 2 diabetes  managed with Metformin and a diet plan. He is a former smoker  quitting about ten years ago  and reports moderate alcohol consumption. There is a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died of a heart attack at the age of 65. He is mildly obese with a body mass index of 31.  Present Illness  His condition started with occasional fluttering sensations in the chest accompanied by a feeling of tiredness. However  over the last few days  these episodes have become more frequent  with shortness of breath also presenting during moderate exercise  such as when walking up stairs.  Examination   On physical examination  his pulse rate was irregular  with a rate of 110 beats per minute. His blood pressure measured 140/90 mmHg. The cardiovascular exam revealed an irregular rhythm without any murmurs. Lungs were clear to auscultation.  Laboratory Findings  Basic blood tests were performed  which indicated slightly raised fasting glucose levels. An electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrated an irregularly irregular rhythm  absent P waves  and a variable ventricular response  confirming the diagnosis of atrial fibrillation.  Plan  After detailed discussion with Mr. Smith regarding his diagnosis and potential treatment options  a decision was made to start him on an oral anticoagulant for stroke prophylaxis  control rate with a beta-blocker  and for rhythm control strategy  he was referred to a cardiologist for further evaluation regarding catheter ablation due to his young age and relatively few comorbidities.   References   American Heart Association. (2021). Atrial Fibrillation.   [End of Presentation]

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Brown  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic today with complaints of recurring palpitations and occasional fatigue over the last two weeks. He denies any chest pain  lightheadedness  or syncope. His past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia managed with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  respectively. He is a non-smoker and consume alcohol only socially. Family history revealed his father had a stroke at age 78.  As for social history  he is a retired engineer  lives with his wife and they have regular assistance from a home caregiver. He reports good adherence to his medical regimen  and his regular exercise is walking with moderate pace for about 30 minutes per day.  Physical exam showed irregularly irregular rhythm and a rate of about 100 beats per minute. Blood Pressure was recorded at 145/90 mm Hg  pulse was irregular at a rate of 96 bpm  and other vital signs were within normal limits.  Initial ECG confirmed atrial fibrillation. Ongoing management of the patient will require further workup  including lab investigations  echocardiogram  potential adjustment in hypertensive treatment  consideration for anticoagulation based on the CHA2DS2-VASc score  and discussion about rhythm vs rate control strategy.  Mr. Brown's demographic information and past medical history are consistent with the literature’s identification of key risk factors for atrial fibrillation such as age  hypertension  and family history. Other risk factors not present in Mr. Brown but that could increase susceptibility include diabetes  heart failure  and coronary artery disease.   For individuals aged 40 and above  the lifetime risk of developing atrial fibrillation is estimated at 1 in 4  indicating the importance of a comprehensive and timely management plan for older patients with atrial fibrillation  like Mr. Brown. As such  emphasis should be placed on risk stratification  individualized  patient-focused decision-making  and multidisciplinary care.

Title: Case Presentation: Atrial Fibrillation  Patient Profile  Name: Mrs. Irene Johnson Gender: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian Age: 71 Occupation: Retired Location: Urban dwelling  Chicago  IL  Medical History:  Mrs. Johnson has a past medical history significant for hypertension and Type II diabetes  with both conditions managed with medication for the last 15 years. She is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol moderately. She has no known drug allergies.  Current Presentation:  Mrs. Johnson presents to the clinic today with complaints of fatigue  palpitations  and shortness of breath  especially when climbing stairs or walking short distances. These symptoms have been progressively occurring over the past three weeks  prompting her appointment today.  Upon clinical examination  an irregular rhythm was noted. An electrocardiogram (ECG) confirmed atrial fibrillation with a ventricular rate of approximately 120 beats per minute (bpm). Her blood pressure was 139/85 mm Hg. Her current medications include metformin for diabetes and lisinopril for hypertension.  Family History:  Both sides of Mrs. Johnson's family have a history of cardiovascular disease. Her mother died at the age of 78 due to a stroke and her father passed away at 72 from a heart attack. Her older brother has also been diagnosed with congestive heart failure at the age of 67.  Conclusion:  Considering Mrs. Johnson’s age  gender  and ethnicity  her presentation is typical of an atrial fibrillation patient. As per the literature  atrial fibrillation is common among the elderly  especially those with underlying health conditions  such as hypertension and diabetes. Early intervention to control heart rate and identify potential therapeutic anticoagulation is critical in order to reduce the risk of stroke  as atrial fibrillation patients have a 5 times higher risk compared to the general population. This case represents an opportunity to explore optimal treatment approaches for a high-risk patient with atrial fibrillation.

Title: A Case Presentation of Atrial Fibrillation  Patient Profile:  Demographics:  Mr. James Johnson is a 67-year-old Caucasian male retired high school English teacher. He comes from an upper-middle-class background and lives in a suburban neighborhood with his wife in Raleigh  North Carolina. Both his children are married with their own families  living out of state.  Chief Complaint:  Mr. Johnson presents with complaints of palpitations  unusual shortness of breath especially on exertion  and mild chest discomfort. Symptoms have been present intermittently for the past two months.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has been diagnosed and managed for hypertension for the past five years  was diagnosed with Type II diabetes mellitus three years ago  and was found to have mildly elevated cholesterol levels one year ago. His father died of coronary artery disease at the age of 69  and his mother had a stroke at the age of 75  from which she passed away.  Lifestyle:  Mr. Johnson has a 30-pack-year history of smoking tobacco but he quit ten years ago when he retired. He consumes moderate amounts of alcohol  averaging 6-8 drinks weekly. He isn't heavily engaged in physical activity besides occasional gardening and daily walking of his dog.  Clinical Assessment:  Given his symptomatology and risk factors including age  hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and previous smoking habits  the possibility of atrial fibrillation is being considered for Mr. Johnson. The exact pathophysiology and understanding of the disease process will guide further diagnosis and treatment processes.   Next Steps: An electrocardiogram (ECG) is scheduled to confirm atrial fibrillation. Based on the results  he will be referred to a cardiologist for further management including possible anticoagulation therapy  rate or rhythm control medications  and either medical or surgical (i.e.  cardioversion or ablation procedures) intervention.  Conclusion: Effective management of Mr. Johnson's condition will require an integrated approach  incorporating both medical management of his arrhythmia and lifestyle modifications  including dietary habits and physical activity  to address his diabetes and cardiovascular risk factors.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Atrial Fibrillation  Patient Introduction: Mr. Jones is a 75-year-old Caucasian male presenting with symptoms consistent with atrial fibrillation.  Demographic Information: Mr. Jones resides in a suburban setting in the Midwest of the United States. He is a retired engineer and is married with three adult children. He states his ethnicity as non-Hispanic white  which aligns with demographic literature as atrial fibrillation (AF) is more common in whites than any other race. His age also correlates with epidemiological data showing the incidence and prevalence of AF considerably increase with age  with a steep rise after 65 years old.  Past Medical History: Mr. Jones has a long-standing history of hypertension and was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 15 years ago. He successfully quit smoking 10 years ago but continues to consume alcohol in moderate amounts. Over the years  he has also undergone treatment for high cholesterol. His father had a stroke at the age of 82  and his mother suffered from heart failure in her late seventies. Both of Mr. Jones's parents had AF  suggesting a potential genetic predisposition.  Current Symptoms: Recently  Mr. Jones has been suffering from episodes of rapid and irregular heartbeats  often accompanied by fatigue  lightheadedness  and shortness of breath. He has noticed an unexplained decline in his exercise tolerance and transient spells of feeling his heart fluttering—symptoms indicative of AF.  Taken together  Mr. Jones's age  familial history  hypertension  diabetes  and former smoking habit all place him in a higher risk bracket for developing AF. His self-reported symptoms suggest the necessity for further diagnostic evaluations to confirm AF and to initiate appropriate treatment strategies to manage the condition and avoid potential complications such as stroke and heart failure.

Title: Atrial Fibrillation Case Presentation  I. Introduction The purpose of this presentation is to highlight a case of a patient diagnosed with atrial fibrillation. As we know  atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common arrhythmia in clinical practice  and it is a leading cause of stroke  especially in the elderly population.  II. Patient Demographics Our patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Thompson  who is retired and lives alone. He is a former smoker  quit 15 years ago  and has a history of moderate alcohol consumption. His BMI categorizes him as overweight. These demographics are representative of typical AF population as AF incidence increases with age and is most common in Caucasian males.  III. Past Medical History Mr. Thompson has a significant medical history:  1. Hypertension: Mr. Thompson was diagnosed with hypertension 20 years ago. Hypertension is a major risk factor for AF.  2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 15 years ago. Diabetes also significantly contributes to the pathogenesis of AF.  3. Prior Stroke: Mr. Thompson suffered a minor ischemic stroke 10 years ago  fortunately with no permanent neurological deficits.   IV. Current Symptoms Mr. Thompson has been experiencing episodes of palpitations  shortness of breath  and occasional lightheadedness  particularly during physical activity.  V. Summary In summation  Mr. Thompson's age  gender  and medical history  including hypertension  diabetes  previous stroke  and his symptoms  make him a typical representational case of atrial fibrillation. His management would likely include heart rate control  rhythm control strategies  anticoagulation therapy  lifestyle adjustments  and regular outpatient follow-ups.

Patient Presentation  Demographics: Mr. James Carter  a 72-year-old African American male  presents with a recently diagnosed atrial fibrillation.  Past Medical History: Mr. Carter's past medical history is significant for hypertension  managed with Lisinopril  and type 2 diabetes managed with Metformin. He has a history of myocardial infarction three years ago. The patient has been a smoker for the past 20 years  although he has significantly reduced smoking during the last year. His family history reveals his father died at age 67 from myocardial infarction and his mother is alive with a history of stroke at age 75.  Present Complaint: Mr. Carter reports experiencing ""fluttering"" sensations in his chest accompanied by a slight feeling of lightheadedness over the past two weeks. He didn’t report any chest pain  shortness of breath  or loss of consciousness.  This presentation of Mr. Carter operates under the knowledge that African American men are at higher risk for cardiac issues  with atrial fibrillation being more common in older adults. Hypertension  smoking  and a family history of heart disease contribute to this risk. Concurrent conditions such as diabetes and past heart attacks also increase the likelihood of developing atrial fibrillation.   In conclusion  Mr. Carter’s lifestyle and past medical history have put him at risk for several diseases and conditions  notably atrial fibrillation. His care team will need to provide education on the potential complications of this condition while strategizing an appropriate and effective treatment plan.

Title: Case Presentation of a Patient Presenting with Atrial Fibrillation  Introduction:  Our patient  Mr. Martinez  is a 66-years-old Hispanic male presenting with symptoms consistent with atrial fibrillation  which include heart palpitations and shortness of breath. He resides in El Paso  Texas  where substantial populations of older Hispanics are found.   Demographics:  Atrial fibrillation is the most common heart rhythm disorder in the world  and its incidence increases with age. On average  its onset occurs at 66 years for men and 74 for women. In the US  whites have the highest risk for atrial fibrillation  followed by Latinos. In terms of other demographics  it's also important to note that moderate to high alcohol use significantly increases the risk.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Martinez has a history of Hypertension since he was 50  Diabetes Mellitus (DM) type 2 diagnosed at age 62  and a known smoking habit of 10 years  which he quit 5 years ago. Studies suggest that hypertension and obesity significantly increase the incidence of atrial fibrillation  while DM type 2 and smoking are also known risk factors.   Current Status:  Upon arrival  Mr. Martinez reported experiencing irregular heartbeats  fatigue  and dizziness  which began approximately 2 days ago. He denies chest pain  nausea  or fainting spells. On physical exam  he appears anxious. His blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg  heart rate is irregularly irregular at 120 bpm  respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air.  Objective Findings and Conclusion:  Electrocardiography (ECG) showed irregular R-R intervals and absence of identifiable P waves – findings consistent with atrial fibrillation. It is worth mentioning that 40% of individuals with atrial fibrillation do not experience any symptoms  the so-called 'silent' atrial fibrillation  which might potentially lead to stroke or heart failure. Early recognition of symptoms and proper management is of utmost importance.  Mr. Martinez proposed management plan includes lenient rate control  using a beta blocker to keep his heart rate under 110 beats per minute at rest  starting him on an anticoagulant to reduce his risk of stroke  and lifestyle modification instructions.  The patient should be reminded of the importance of medication adherence  as both hypertension and atrial fibrillation require chronic management. He'll need close clinical follow-up for monitoring of his cardiac status and blood pressure control  and counseling for maintaining a healthy lifestyle.

Title: Case Presentation on Atrial Fibrillation  Introduction: Today I am presenting the case of Mr. John  a 67-year-old African-American retired factory worker who lives with his wife in the suburbs of Washington DC. He is a non-smoker  doesn't consume alcohol  and maintains an active lifestyle.  Demographic Details: Mr. John represents one of the most at-risk demographics for atrial fibrillation. Atrial fibrillation seems to increase with age  affecting about 9% of people aged 65 or older. Additionally  it tends to be higher in males than females  and higher in whites than in African-Americans  but the condition still affects substantial numbers in all demographics.   Presenting Issue: Mr. John recently presented at the clinic with intermittent chest discomfort and palpitations for the last two months which has started to affect his quality of life. He reports feeling breathless and tired after mild activity  such as walking to the nearby grocery store.   Past Medical History: His past medical history includes hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which are well controlled with prescribed medications - Ramipril for hypertension and Metformin for diabetes. He also has a familial history of cardiovascular disease - his father had a myocardial infarction in his late 70s. This places Mr. John at a higher risk for cardiovascular conditions  including atrial fibrillation. To add  he has no known allergies.  Physical Examination Findings: On examination  Mr. John's blood pressure was 130/85 mmHg  and his heart rate was irregularly irregular  around 115 beats per minute.  Conclusion: Given his complaints of palpitations and dyspnea on exertion  along with the irregularly irregular pulse  the picture is strongly suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Management and treatment will aim to control his heart rate and prevent possible complications such as stroke. Further diagnostic examination  including Electrocardiography (ECG) is necessary to confirm the diagnosis. Regular follow-ups will also be necessary to evaluate the course of the treatment.

Patient Presentation:  I’d like to present Mr. Michael Thompson  a 70-year-old African-American male retired military officer who was brought to the emergency department by his wife due to increasing shortness of breath and light-headedness experienced over the past couple of days.   Medical History:  Of note  Mr. Thompson has an established past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  controlled with metformin and a calcium channel blocker. He does not have a history of stroke  heart failure  or vascular disease. Although he smoked in his early twenties  he has been smoke-free for the past forty years. There is no known familial history of cardiovascular diseases.   Current Status:  Upon physical examination  the patient presented with an irregular pulse and an overall fatigued look. Blood pressure was somewhat elevated at 145/96 mmHg. An electrocardiogram was performed  demonstrating fibrillation waves consistent with atrial fibrillation. Subsequent echocardiogram revealed no evidence of structural heart disease and a normal ejection fraction.  Clinical Importance:  In terms of demographics  Mr. Thompson fits within the typical cohort for atrial fibrillation (AF). AF is more common in older individuals  with a prevalence that steeply increases with age. It is estimated to affect approximately 9% of individuals aged 65 or more and it has a predilection for males. Additionally  African Americans and Caucasians have comparable rates of AF occurrence  although some studies suggest a slightly lower incidence among African Americans. In terms of comorbidities  hypertension  diabetes  and prior smoking  as in Mr. Thompson's case  are all established risk factors for the development of AF.  Plan:  Given his symptoms and EKG findings  Mr. Thompson was diagnosed with new-onset atrial fibrillation. A workup was initiated to rule out underlying precipitating causes  and given his elevated stroke risk due to age  hypertension  and diabetes  anticoagulation therapy was started with a target INR of 2-3. In the absence of structural heart disease  rate control is the chosen strategy for this patient  and thus his calcium channel blocker will be continued. He will also be referred for outpatient follow-up in the cardiology clinic.

Title: Atrial Fibrillation: A Case Presentation  Patient Information:   Mr. Johnson  a 69-year-old Caucasian male  presents the symptoms consistent with atrial fibrillation. He is a retired engineer who now lives with his wife. On the social front  he is a former smoker and drinks socially. He is moderately overweight with a BMI of 29  indicative of potential sedentary lifestyle or unhealthy eating habits.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Johnson has a past medical history significant for hypertension  diagnosed about 7 years ago. He has been on a regimen of antihypertensive medications since the diagnosis. Additionally  he also has type 2 diabetes mellitus  for which he takes oral hypoglycemic agents. He has been managing his diabetes for the past 5 years. Apart from these  he has a history of occasional gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)  and has been on proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) intermittently for symptomatic relief. He had also undergone an appendectomy in his 30s  with no notable post-surgical complications. His father passed away due to a myocardial infarction in his early 70s and his eldest brother has been diagnosed with chronic kidney disease.   Current Presentation:  Mr. Johnson has been noticing some unusual symptoms for the last month. He reports experiencing recurring episodes of palpitations and occasional breathlessness without exertion. He describes his heartbeat as ""fast and irregular"". Moreover  he has also been experiencing feelings of fatigue and weakness more frequently. He denies having any chest pain  dizziness  or loss of consciousness. He comes to medical attention in the hope to discuss these symptoms.  In line with literature  the case of Mr. Johnson supports the established demographic trend that atrial fibrillation is common in older  Caucasian individuals. In this particular case  history of chronic conditions such as hypertension and diabetes also aligns with the known risk factors associated with the onset of atrial fibrillation.

Title: Case Presentation: Atrial Fibrillation  Participant: Mr. John Harris  Demographics: Mr. Harris is a 76-year-old Caucasian male  retired military officer and a lifetime nonsmoker. He is a divorcee with three grown children. His BMI classification is within normal range (24kg/m2)  and he lives in an urban residential setting in the Midwest.  Past Medical History: Mr. Harris has had a myriad of chronic medical conditions. These include systemic hypertension  which was diagnosed 10 years ago and is managed with Lisinopril daily. His hypertension is generally well controlled  with a regular BP around 135/85. He was diagnosed with Type II diabetes 8 years ago and maintains his diabetic condition under control through his diet  Metformin  and regular physical activity.  In his early 70s  he was diagnosed with ischemic heart disease  followed by percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with drug-eluting stent placement. Currently  his ischemic heart disease is well managed with daily statin (Atorvastatin) and low-dose Aspirin.  Presenting Issues: Mr. Harris has been encountering intermittent heart palpitations and shortness of breath of mild-moderate severity over the past few weeks  mainly during physical activities. He also reported one episode of dizziness  adding to the concern.  On examination  irregular pulse rhythm was detected  leading to suspicion of atrial fibrillation. To confirm the diagnosis  an EKG was done  which illustrated an irregular  rapid heart rate with absence of distinct P waves  supporting the diagnosis.  Studies suggest that atrial fibrillation is highly prevalent among elderly white males  particularly those with a history of hypertension  diabetes  and ischemic heart disease. This aligns with Mr. Harris's profile  making him a typical case for atrial fibrillation. His treatment and management plan will be personalized per his individual profile and will focus on controlling his heart rate  minimizing risk of stroke  and management of his symptoms.

Title: Clinical Presentation of a Patient with Atrial Fibrillation  I. Introduction of the Patient   The patient  Mr. White  is a 67-year-old Caucasian male  who presents with the main complaint of intermittent palpitations and fatigue for over two weeks. He is retired  living with his wife in the suburbs of Ohio. His weight is 88kg  standing at 5'10""  and demonstrates a BMI of 27.9  indicating that he is overweight. He happens to be a smoker with a 30 pack-year smoking history but quit smoking ten years ago. He drinks alcohol moderately.   II. Past Medical History  According to the patient's medical records  he had myocardial infarction five years ago  which was treated with percutaneous coronary intervention  and he's been on aspirin and statins since then. He was diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus ten years ago. His other significant past medical history includes hypothyroidism. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  including his father who had an atrial fibrillation diagnosis.  III. Current Symptoms  Mr. White describes his symptoms as feeling a fluttering in his chest intermittently for the last two weeks. He has also been feeling fatigued easily with shortness of breath after doing modest physical activity  which he wasn’t experiencing before. He also complains of occasional dizziness.  IV. Physical Examination  Upon examination  the patient presents with irregular heart rhythm  evidenced by irregular pulse found on physical examination. Blood pressure is slightly elevated at 150/85 mmHg. No other significant physical findings are present at this time.  V. Conclusion  The patient's age  history of hypertension  diabetes  and past myocardial infarction  together with his symptoms and physical examination findings  make atrial fibrillation a strong consideration for his current presentation. Further tests including ECG  echocardiogram and blood work are planned to confirm the diagnosis and assess the patient's overall cardiovascular status.

Title: A Case Presentation of Atrial Fibrillation   I. Introduction: Patient’s demography The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male named Martin Johnson. Mr. Johnson is a retired civil engineer from Portland  Oregon. He lives alone  has been a widower for two years  and has two grown-up children. He has a BMI of 28.5 and a history of consuming moderate to heavy alcohol  specifically whiskey  over the years. He doesn't use any tobacco products and is not engaged in any regular physical activity.  II. Past Medical History Mr. Johnson has a long history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He's also been dealing with a moderate case of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) since his early 60s  which is managed with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP). In addition  he has a noted 15-year history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus that is currently managed with Metformin 500mg two times daily and Diet control. Unfortunately  he has difficulty following dietary restrictions and tends to have poor glycemic control.  III. Presenting Complaints Mr. Johnson presented with persistent general weakness  palpitations  occasional lightheadedness  and increased shortness of breath  especially during minor physical exertion. These symptoms have been on-going for the past week or two  and he reports that they are becoming progressively worse.  IV. Potential Diagnosis Given his symptoms and past medical history  he is likely presenting with atrial fibrillation (AF). However  we will need to conduct necessary investigations such as an electrocardiogram  echocardiogram  and blood work including a complete blood count  thyroid function test  and a coagulation panel to confirm this. If our suspicions are correct  his condition would be classified as non-valvular atrial fibrillation due to lack of any heart valve diseases. This classification is important as it influences the choice of anticoagulation to prevent stroke  which is a common complication of AF.   V. Risk Factors Various risk factors make Mr. Johnson more susceptible to atrial fibrillation  including his age  male gender  long-standing uncontrolled hypertension  history of diabetes mellitus  obesity  sleep apnea  and heavy alcohol drinking.  VI. Health Disparities AF is prevalent among older  Caucasian males. Management and screening can be challenging due to socio-economic factors  lifestyle choices  and comorbidities  which might have influenced the delivery of health services to those patients.   In the following steps  it would be of critical importance to thoroughly conduct the required examinations  discuss the available treatment options with Mr. Johnson  and work closely on lifestyle modification to manage this condition.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Atrial Fibrillation   Patient Overview:   The patient is a 71-year-old Caucasian male from an urban setting and belongs to the middle socio-economic class. The average age of AF onset ranges within the seventh decade of life  and the prevalence of AF is higher in men than in women. The racial burden is predominantly on whites compared to other races according to numerous studies.  Past Medical History:  The patient's past history includes hypertension  diabetes  and a history of smoking. He is a former smoker  with a 40-pack year history  but quit smoking about ten years ago.  He was diagnosed with hypertension about 15 years ago and has been on medication – ACE inhibitors (Lisinopril) with fairly good blood pressure control. His blood pressure at last reading was 130/80 mm Hg. He was also diagnosed with Type II Diabetes mellitus about 10 years ago which has been relatively controlled by oral hypoglycemic agents (Metformin) with a last recorded HbA1c level of 6.5%.   These comorbid conditions are relevant as experience and studies show that patients suffering from heart diseases often have a history of hypertension  Type II Diabetes mellitus  and smoking.   The patient has also been hospitalized before for a myocardial infarction (heart attack)  about 5 years ago  contributing to a higher risk for AF. He received percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and since then has been on standard post-MI medications: Beta-blockers  Aspirin  Statins  and ACE inhibitors. No past history of any surgeries or known drug allergies.   Family History:   The patient's father had a history of coronary artery disease and died of a heart attack in his seventies. His mother had hypertension and passed away due to stroke in her late seventies.   These multiple risk factors with a strong family history coupled with his own past medical history  including diabetes  hypertension  and myocardial infarction  significantly raise the patient's chance of getting atrial fibrillation. Being a septuagenarian male himself  places him in the highest demographic risk group for this condition.   The objective now would be to identify any signs and symptoms of Atrial Fibrillation and proceed accordingly.   Sources:  1. Chugh  S. S.  Havmoeller  R.  Narayanan  K.  Singh  D.  Rienstra  M.  Benjamin  E. J.  & Murray  C. J. (2014). Worldwide epidemiology of atrial fibrillation: a Global Burden of Disease 2010 Study. Circulation  129(8)  837-847.  2. Staerk  L.  Sherer  J. A.  Ko  D.  Benjamin  E.J.  Helm  R. H. (2017). Atrial Fibrillation: Epidemiology  Pathophysiology  and Clinical Outcomes. Circulation Research  120(9)  1501-1517.

Title: A Case Presentation of Atrial Fibrillation  Patient Profile: Mr. John Anderson  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  has come in for a scheduled clinic appointment. He lives in an urban environment with his wife. He is retired and was previously working as an engineer. He is a non-smoker but has a history of moderate alcohol consumption.  Past Medical History: Mr. Anderson has a known medical history of Hypertension (HTN) and Hyperlipidemia  both of which have been managed with medication for the past 15 years. He also has a history of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) due to his past as a heavy smoker for over 30 years  which he quit 10 years ago. He has no known history of surgeries or allergies.  Presenting Complaint: For the last three weeks  he has experienced intermittent episodes of palpitations  lethargy  and shortness of breath which initially occurred during exertion but now occur at rest. He has also noticed that he is easily fatigued.  Physical Examination: Mr. Anderson appears mildly dyspneic with irregular pulse rate (96bpm)  blood pressure at 148/90mmHg  and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. Cardiac auscultation reveals an irregular rhythm. The chest is clear to auscultation and there is no lower limb edema. Neurological examination  chest and abdominal examinations were unremarkable.  Based on his symptoms  past medical history  and physical examination  atrial fibrillation (AF) is suspected.   This presentation for Mr. Anderson is representative of studies that show a higher incidence of atrial fibrillation in older  Caucasian men  with underlying cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and those with chronic conditions like COPD. Confirmatory tests  including an EKG and echocardiogram  will be needed and should be supplemented with relevant management strategies after the diagnosis is established.

Patient Presentation:  I'd like to present a 67-year-old African American male patient who is currently experiencing signs and symptoms consistent with atrial fibrillation (AF). The patient lives in an urban area of Georgia and is retired. He has a history of smoking for about 30 years but has quit for the past five years.  Previous medical history indicates hypertension which has been managed for the past 10 years with medication (Lisinopril). He also has a high cholesterol level (hyperlipidemia) and is currently prescribed statins. Additionally  he has been treated for heart failure and had an acute myocardial infarction seven years ago.   Upon reviewing his medical records  it was revealed that his father had AF and suffered from a stroke in his late sixties. The patient implies his compliancy to doctor visits which he sustains every six months. However  he confesses that his diet leans heavy towards the southern cuisine  which may have contributed to his current health issues.  Through physical examination  the patient presented with irregular heart rhythm and a slightly increased heart rate. Further  non-invasive diagnostic tests showed irregularities in heart rhythm. As a result of these symptoms and findings  the patient was therefore diagnosed with Atrial fibrillation.  Considering the patient's demographic and clinical history  a comprehensive treatment planning including arrhythmia management  stroke prevention  and symptom control will be initiated to improve the patient's prognosis and quality of life. Regular monitoring of the patient's condition will also be instructed along with diet and lifestyle changes.  Given the patient’s age  ethnicity  and history of heart disease  he accurately represents the typical AF patient as shown in literature. A study found that the prevalence of AF increases with age  being most common in individuals aged 65 and above. It further states that AF also occurs more frequently in men  and in black individuals compared to other racial or ethnic groups (Munger et al.  2014). Other risk factors include hypertension  heart failure  and heart attack as seen in the case of our patient. Therefore  this case presentation accurately represents the demographic and clinical profile of a typical AF patient as shown in medical literature.  Reference:  Munger  T. M.  Dong  Y. X.  Masaki  M.  Oh  J. K.  Mankad  S. V.  Borlaug  B. A.  Asirvatham  S. J.  Shen  W. K.  Lee  H. C.  Bielinski  S. J.  & Hodge  D. O. (2014). Epidemiology of atrial fibrillation in African–Americans: a population-based study. American Heart Journal  168(2)  239-246.

Patient Presentation:   We present a 68-year-old Caucasian male  named John Smith  who has come to the outpatient department today presenting with palpitations and occasional fatigue. Smith is a retired high school teacher  who currently lives in rural Michigan with his wife. They have two grown-up children residing in different cities. His BMI is 29 suggesting he is overweight. He is a former smoker having quit 15 years back  but continues to indulge in social drinking.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Smith has been diagnosed with hypertension for over 10 years which had been well-controlled with lifestyle management and medication. He also has hyperlipidemia for which he takes statins. His father had a history of a stroke at the age of 72 and consequently  Smith has always been diligent about his annual health checks. About three years ago  he had been diagnosed with diabetes mellitus Type II  which is being managed with diet control and metformin. He experiences mild knee osteoarthritis  managed with regular physiotherapy sessions and occasional use of over-the-counter pain medication. He is known to be allergic to sulfa drugs.  This demographic presentation is representative of the literature  which shows that atrial fibrillation (AF) is often seen in older patients  predominantly in men and Caucasian population. AF is often associated with comorbidities such as hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes mellitus. The patient’s lifestyle habits  such as previous smoking and current alcohol intake  are additional common risk factors for atrial fibrillation. His BMI in the overweight range further increases his risk for AF due to the associated atrial pressure and volume overload resulting from the increased body mass. His family history of stroke is another significant risk factor  given the well-known association between atrial fibrillation and increased stroke risk. Therefore  the patient’s overall demographic information  habits  comorbidities and family history align with typical characteristics of patients diagnosed with atrial fibrillation.

Title: A Case Presentation on Atrial Fibrillation  Patient Profile: We are presenting a case of a 68-year-old Caucasian male with atrial fibrillation (Afib). Patient is a retired military officer  living with his wife in their suburban home in Michigan.  Present Health Status: The patient reports increasing fatigue  dizziness  and palpitations  which he has been experiencing intermittently for the past 60 days but have been rising in intensity the past week. His resting heart rate is currently irregular  with pulse rate ranging from 87 beats per minute (bpm) to 154 bpm. Blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg.  Past Medical History: The patient has a 10-year history of hypertension  which is controlled by taking a daily dose of 5mg Amlodipine and 50mg Losartan. He also has a long-standing history of smoking and alcohol consumption  but he quit smoking five years ago. He is still having difficulty curbing his alcohol intake.  Over the past year  he has been diagnosed with hyperlipidaemia and has been managing it with moderate-intensity statin therapy. He has high cholesterol levels  but not diabetic. He suffers from obesity (body mass index is 30kg/m2) and he has a sedentary lifestyle  mostly due to his age and tendency to feel tired easily. As part of this patient's family history  his father had angina and his mother was hypertensive.  Conclusion: Considering the demographic information together with the medical history  there is an increased risk for atrial fibrillation in this patient. His uncontrolled hypertension  age  and history of tobacco exposure collectively increase the risk of developing atrial fibrillation. Early detection  management  and control of this irregular heart rate can significantly diminish the threat of stroke  heart failure  and other heart-related complications.  The medical team is recommended to create a comprehensive treatment plan that includes rate control  rhythm control  stroke prevention  and lifestyle changes to manage his atrial fibrillation effectively  reduce his symptoms and enhance his quality of life. Regular follow-ups are also recommended to monitor his progress.  Reference: Andrade J  Khairy P  Dobrev D  Nattel S. The Clinical Profile and Pathophysiology of Atrial Fibrillation: Relationships Among Clinical Features  Epidemiology  and Mechanisms. Circ Res. 2014 Apr 25; 114(9): 1453–1468. doi: 10.1161/CIRCRESAHA.114.303211

Patient Presentation:  Demographics: The patient is a 71-year-old Caucasian female  living in an urban area of the United States. She is retired  married  and has two adult children. She has a postgraduate level of education and worked as a teacher before retirement. Prior to presenting  she has been living independently with her husband without any requirement for in-home assistance.  Medical History: She has a known medical history of Hypertension for the last ten years  which is being controlled by first-line antihypertensive drugs  specifically Lisinopril. She also has been diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the past eight years and is currently on oral hypoglycemic agents with fairly well glycemic control.   Other notable conditions include hyperlipidemia managed by a statin medication  Atorvastatin. She has also been maintaining a healthy diet and moderately active lifestyle to better manage her multiple chronic conditions.  No history of prior surgeries. She quit smoking 20 years ago  consumes alcohol socially  and has no known drug allergies. There is a family history of cardiovascular disease  with her father succumbing to myocardial infarction in his late 60s.  Current presentation: The patient is presenting with relatively recent onset of symptoms - palpitations  occasional bouts of breathlessness  and fatigue which she initially attributed to her advancing age. An initial ECG done showed irregular rhythm  leading to a suspicion of atrial fibrillation.   These common risk factors  age  hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and her symptoms align with the literature indicating that atrial fibrillation is often found in older adults with other cardiovascular risk factors. Further investigations and management are planned to confirm the diagnosis and manage atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation:  A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents in the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and dyspnea on exertion for the past 2 days. He also reports mild chest discomfort  occasional dizziness  and fatigue during the same timeframe. He denies any past similar episodes. He has no documented history of syncope  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or edema.   Past Medical History:  His past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus which are controlled on metoprolol and metformin respectively. He was diagnosed with these conditions 7 years ago but has been non-compliant with lifestyle changes. He is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago but with a 20 pack-year history prior to quitting. He denies any personal or family history of cardiovascular disease. He has no known drug or food allergies. He remains sedentary with poor dietary habits.   Socio-Demographic Details:  The patient is retired and lives with his wife. He used to work as a high-school teacher. He does not consume alcohol. He has two adult children  both in good health. The patient has Medicare insurance coverage. The patient and his family lack a comprehensive understanding of diabetes and hypertension and the related lifestyle modifications. He has inadequate follow-up with primary care due to transportation issues. There is no history of illicit drug use or any psychiatric illness.   His vitals on arrival are BP – 150/90mmHg  Pulse – irregular at 110/min  RR- 16/min  Temp – 98.6 F  SpO2- 96% on room air. ECG shows irregular rhythm with no P waves suggestive of atrial fibrillation. He is alert and oriented  and his physical examination is unremarkable except for an irregularly irregular heart rhythm on auscultation.

Patient Information: A 75-year-old African-American Male.  Presenting Complaint: Patient reports persistent palpitations and fatigue for the past couple of weeks.  Medical History: Patient has a documented history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. He is a former smoker but quit 10 years ago. His medication regimen includes Ramipril  Atenolol  and Metformin. There is no known family history of cardiac diseases but his father had a stroke at age 80.  Physical Examination: Patient is conscious and alert but appears fatigued. His pulse is irregular and rapid  blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg. There are no signs of peripheral oedema or cyanosis.  Investigations: An ECG confirms atrial fibrillation with a ventricular rate of 120 beats per minute. Blood tests show slight elevation in HbA1c and cholesterol levels.  Working Diagnosis: New onset atrial fibrillation  possibly secondary to underlying hypertensive and diabetic heart disease.  Plan: The patient is planned to undergo further diagnostic tests including echocardiogram and thyroid function tests. Anticoagulation therapy should be considered due to the patient's age and co-morbid conditions. The patients diabetic and hypertensive treatment will be re-evaluated. The management strategy will be in line with the current atrial fibrillation guidelines. Increased periodic follow-ups are scheduled for monitoring. The patient is educated about lifestyle modifications which include maintaining a healthy diet  regular exercise  and keeping track of his blood pressure and glucose levels at home.

Patient Presentation:  A 75-year-old black man presents to the emergency room with complaints of episodic rapid  irregular  pounding heartbeat and recurrent fatigue for the past two weeks. He also reveals that he has experienced bouts of dizziness  chest discomfort  and shortness of breath. He does not experience any radiating chest pain  nausea  or sweating suggestive of an acute coronary syndrome. Any attempt at physical activity leads to him feeling weak and out of breath.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension which is treated with a thiazide diuretic  and diabetes type 2  for which he takes oral hypoglycemic medications. He does not smoke or consume alcohol but has a sedentary lifestyle. The patient lives at home alone and reports good medication compliance. Patient's father had a history of cardiovascular disease. The patient was hospitalized one year ago for pneumonia and was found to be in normal sinus rhythm at that time.  His blood pressure is slightly elevated at 145/90 mmHg and his heart rate is irregular and fast  ranging from 90 to 135 bpm. He appears slightly uncomfortable but not in acute distress. Physical exam reveals an irregularly irregular pulse. His lungs are clear to auscultation  and lower extremity exam does not show signs of peripheral edema or visible signs of deep vein thrombosis.  Based on his age  presenting symptoms  physical exam combined with his history of hypertension and diabetes  atrial fibrillation is suspected in this patient. Further diagnostic workup is needed to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Albert Johnson  a 71-year-old African American male  presents to the office today with complaints of palpitations and mild shortness of breath that have been progressive over the last 2 weeks. He also mentions that he occasionally feels fatigued and light-headed. He denies chest pain  syncope  or lower extremity swelling.  Mr. Johnson has a medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His hypertension has been reasonably well-controlled with losartan 50 mg daily  and his diabetes is managed with oral metformin. Mr. Johnson has no known cardiac history. He is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago  and occasionally consumes alcohol socially  having approximately one drink per week.  His father reportedly had chronic heart problems and passed away from a heart attack in his mid-seventies. His mother lived into her eighties but had a stroke towards the end of her life. Mr. Johnson is widowed and lives alone. He is retired and enjoys gardening.  He does not have a history of any surgical procedures and has not traveled recently. He denies any recent dietary changes or significant weight loss or gain.  Upon physical examination  his blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg  pulse rate is irregular at 110 bpm  respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation on room air is 96%. The cardiovascular examination reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm. There are no murmurs or additional heart sounds. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable.  An electrocardiogram (ECG) confirms atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Lewis is a 72-year-old African American male presenting with complaints of new onset palpitations and mild shortness of breath on exertion. These symptoms started approximately two weeks ago and have been persistent. He denies chest pain  dizziness  or syncope. His breathing is normally comfortable at rest but becomes more difficult with activities such as climbing stairs or walking for more than 10 minutes. He has noted intermittent rapid heat beat which he describes as ""fluttering"" in his chest.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which are largely controlled with medications. He also has a history of high cholesterol and a 15-year history of tobacco use  which he quit five years ago. He consumed alcohol socially in past but quit six months ago. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father passing away from a heart attack at 77 and his older brother having a stroke at the age of 70.  Mr. Lewis's current medications include metformin for his diabetes  lisinopril for his hypertension  and a statin for his cholesterol. He is allergic to penicillin  which causes a skin rash.  On physical examination  his heart rate was irregularly irregular  and his blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg. BMI is 28 kg/m2  indicating he is overweight. Cardiovascular examination reveals no murmurs  rubs  or gallops  and his lungs are clear to auscultation. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.  An ECG confirms atrial fibrillation with a rate of about 115. Blood tests reveal slightly elevated glucose levels and normal electrolytes  kidney and liver function. LDL cholesterol is slightly above the target. HbA1c is 7.6%.  He was formerly a construction manager and is currently retired. He is widowed and lives alone  but his daughter checks on him regularly. He is independent with his activities of daily living.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jones is a 68-year-old African American male who presented to the Emergency Room complaining of intermittent palpitations and occasional shortness of breath for the past few weeks. The palpitations seem to occur mostly at rest and are associated with bouts of lightheadedness. He denies any chest pain or syncope.  He has a history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus which he controls with Lisinopril and Metformin respectively. He also has a 20 pack year history of smoking but quit about 10 years ago. He occasionally consumes alcohol but denies recreational drug use. He is retired and lives with his wife.  Family history is significant for stroke in his father at an age of 75. His mother has diabetes and hypertension  and a younger brother had a myocardial infarction in his early 60s. There is no known family history of any genetic or congenital diseases.  On examination he is alert and oriented. Vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 135/85 mmHg  pulse of 108 beats/min  irregular  respirations at 16 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation at 97% on room air  and he is afebrile. Cardiovascular exam is notable for irregular rhythm without murmurs. The remainder of his examination is essentially normal.  This high risk presentation composed of palpitations with a history of hypertension and diabetes has given strong clinical suspicion of possible atrial fibrillation. ECG  blood work and additional diagnostic studies have been ordered for further evaluation.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is Mr. John Smith  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  who presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue  palpitations  and mild shortness of breath. He reports these symptoms started a week ago and has been persistent since. Mr. Smith is a retired engineer and has been living with his wife in a suburban community. He is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago but admits to a history of moderate to heavy alcohol use  which he reduced significantly over the past year. Mr. Smith reports a family history of heart disease  with his father passing away from a heart attack at the age of 65.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Smith has a past medical history significant for hypertension  which was diagnosed about 10 years ago  and hyperlipidemia  on record since he was 60. Both conditions are under control with medication. He has no history of diabetes  stroke  or kidney disease. He had a brief episode of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (AF) three years ago  which was successfully cardioverted and managed with medication. Mr. Smith's other significant medical history includes an appendectomy at age 45  and treatment for a basal cell carcinoma on his forehead about two years ago.  Current Medications:   Mr. Smith is currently on Lisinopril for his hypertension  Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia  and Aspirin for prophylaxis of cardiovascular disease.  Upon physical examination  irregular rapid heartbeat is noted. An EKG is performed displaying signs consistent with atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson  a 72-year-old African-American male with a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease  presents to the clinic complaining of intermittent episodes of palpitations and mild shortness of breath which he has been experiencing for the past two weeks. He also describes a feeling of ""tiredness"" on mild exertion  which he previously did not have. He denies any chest pain  orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He does not have diabetes or any known thyroid disease. He has been compliant with his medications including a beta-blocker and a statin. He is a non-smoker and denies alcohol intake. He has lived alone since the death of his wife 10 years ago and has been mostly independent. However  he shares he has been having some occasional difficulty remembering dates and appointments recently. His ECG reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm consistent with atrial fibrillation. Further  his anticoagulation needs were evaluated using a CHA2DS2-VASc score which indicated a moderate risk of ischemic stroke. Blood tests including full blood count  electrolytes  and thyroid function tests were ordered for further evaluation.

Patient Presentation:  A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents in the emergency department with complaints of increased fatigue  occasional lightheadedness and rapid  irregular heartbeat for the past two weeks. He states that these symptoms have been making it increasingly difficult for him to engage in his favorite hobby  golfing. The patient reports that on two occasions within the past week  he has nearly fainted.  His medical history includes hypertension  for which he takes amlodipine  and type 2 diabetes  reasonably controlled with metformin. He used to smoke a pack of cigarettes daily but quit fifteen years ago and reports moderate alcohol use. His paternal grandfather had a 'heart condition ' but he is not aware of specifics. The patient is retired; he worked as a civil engineer.  Upon examination  an irregular rhythm is noted on cardiac auscultation. Blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg  and the pulse is irregularly irregular at a rate of 120 beats per minute. His body mass index (BMI) is 29 kg/m2.   This presentation suggests that the patient could potentially be suffering from atrial fibrillation. Considering the patient's age  sex  racial background  history of hypertension  diabetes  and lifestyle  he fits in the most commonly affected demographic. His symptoms including irregular heart rate  fatigue  and near fainting experiences are indicative of atrial fibrillation. The detection of an irregular rhythm on examination further lends weight to this potential diagnosis. His elevated blood pressure also indicates poorly controlled hypertension  which can cause atrial fibrillation.

Mr. Chen is a 68-year-old Chinese male coming into the clinic with complaints of heart palpitations  fatigue  and shortness of breath which has been getting progressively worse over the past week. He has noted a decreased exercise tolerance  as he becomes winded after walking a short distance  something that hadn't been happening until recently. He denies any syncope  chest pain or pressure  or swelling of extremities.   Mr. Chen's history is significant for well-controlled hypertension (on Lisinopril 10mg daily) and type 2 diabetes controlled with diet and Metformin 500mg twice a day. Mr. Chen’s father suffered a stroke at age 75. The patient does not smoke  rarely consumes alcohol  and generally has a balanced diet and low-sodium intake due to his hypertension.   Physical examination reveals an irregularly irregular pulse rate of 98 beats per minute. His blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. His lung and abdominal examination are unremarkable  with no signs of heart failure. His lower extremities are free of any noticeable signs of deep venous thrombosis.   Preliminary EKG suggests atrial fibrillation  so labs have been sent including TSH  electrolytes  CBC  and an INR given his high risk for stroke based on his age  hypertension  and diabetes. He is being considered for anticoagulation therapy.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Wilson is a 68-year-old Caucasian man who presents to the clinic complaining of persistent palpitations and occasional shortness of breath especially during physical activity  over the past two months. He reports episodes of feeling lightheaded but denies any incidents of syncope. His appetite and sleep patterns are unremarkable.  The patient has a past medical history significant for controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His medication profile includes Metformin  Lisinopril  and Simvastatin. He has no known drug allergies. Mr. Wilson is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago  and reports social alcohol use.   On physical examination  his pulse is irregularly irregular  and a heart rate of 98 beats per minute is noted. His blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg and his BMI is 29. Routine blood tests indicate stable control of his diabetes with a HbA1c of 6.9%.   Mr. Wilson’s family history is significant with a history of heart disease in his father  who had a heart attack at the age of 65.  Considering the patient's age  clinical history  symptoms and irregular pulse  a provisional diagnosis of atrial fibrillation is suspected. Additional diagnostic workup  like an ECG and echocardiogram  is ordered to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate the cardiac structure and function.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Alvarez is a 67-year-old Hispanic male who presents to the clinic with complaints of palpitations  shortness of breath  and fatigue for several weeks. He states that these symptoms are new and seem to worsen with activity. He denies chest pain  orthopnea  or leg swelling.  His past medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has been treated with lisinopril and metformin for the past 5 years. Despite having these significant medical conditions  he admits he has not been adherent to his medications or diet due to financial constraints. He has a 10 pack-year smoking history but quit 20 years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally and has no known drug allergies.  On examination  his blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg and heart rate is irregularly irregular at 110 beats per minute. Cardiovascular examination reveals an irregularly irregular pulse.  An EKG is obtained and shows atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Lab results including a complete blood count  basic metabolic panel  lipid panel  and HbA1C are ordered. The patient is counseled about the importance of medication adherence and is given resources to assist with medication cost. Further management will be based on the results of the lab tests.

Patient Presentation:  Names  genders  and conditions are randomly assigned and do not refer to any actual individual.  Mr. Roy Johnson  a 71-year-old African American male  presents to the clinic complaining of intermittent episodes of rapid heart beating and shortness of breath that have progressively worsened over the past 6 weeks. These episodes occur at rest and during physical activity  lasting from a few minutes to several hours. The most recent episode occurred yesterday lasting approximately 3 hours. He also reports fatigue and light-headedness during these episodes but denies chest pain  palpitations  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or lower extremity edemas.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  conditions for which he has been on treatment (Metformin and Lisinopril) for the past 10 years. He has no known history of heart disease  stroke  or kidney disease. He has a 45-year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. He consumes alcohol moderately and doesn't use any illicit drugs. His family history is significant for hypertension (both parents) and atrial fibrillation (mother).  Physical examination findings reveal an irregularly irregular pulse and an apical pulse that doesn't match the peripheral pulse. The rest of his physical examination is unremarkable. Considering these findings and clinical manifestations  a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation is suspected  pending confirmation by electrocardiography and echocardiography.

Patient Presentation:  Name: Thomas Hill Age: 68 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired police officer  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Hill presents with complaints of intermittent palpitations  tiredness  and shortness of breath that started a week ago.   Past Medical History: On inquiring about his past medical history  he reports being diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago. He had been fairly regular with his medications (Lisinopril 20 mg once daily). However  he also admits that he has been less compliant with his medication regimen over the past two months due to financial constraints. He also has a history of diabetes which he reports is well-controlled with Metformin.   There is no history of any major surgery. He quit smoking over a decade ago and consumes alcohol occasionally.   Family History: Mr. Hill's father passed away due to a myocardial infarction at the age of 72. His mother is alive and well at the age of 92. He has one elder brother who was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation (AFib) at the age of 70.   Review of Systems: Cardiovascular: Positive for palpitations  fatigue  and shortness of breath  Respiratory: Negative for cough  chest pain. Gastrointestinal: Negative for nausea  vomiting  or changes in bowel habits.   This history  combined with his age  family history  and ongoing hypertension places him at risk for atrial fibrillation. The patient was advised to undergo some investigations including an Electrocardiogram (ECG) which showed atrial fibrillation  confirming the diagnosis. The patient is counseled about the condition  medications  and the need for long-term adherence to the treatment plan.   (An example patient presentation will vary according to the exact demographic representation  but this offers a typically encountered detailed scenario.)

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Milton is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic  complaining of palpitations and unusual fatigue for the past couple of weeks. He has been feeling increasingly short of breath during his daily walks. He has also noticed intermittent palpitations  described as a rapid  irregular heartbeat. There has been no associated chest pain or discomfort.  His past medical history includes hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia; all are well-controlled with medication. He has a 30-pack/year smoking history but quit 15 years ago. His mother had a stroke at age 82 and his father died of a heart attack at age 74.   He currently takes Metformin 500MG twice daily  Lisinopril 10MG daily and Atorvastatin 20MG at bedtime. He has no known drug allergies.  On review of systems  there are no symptoms of fever  weight changes  changes in appetite or recent illnesses. His vital signs are as follows: BP 142/90 mmHg  HR 88 bpm and irregular  Temp 98.6 F  RR 16 per minute.  On examination  his jugular venous pressure is mildly elevated  heart sounds are irregularly irregular  but no murmurs or abnormal lung sounds are noted. His pulses are irregularly irregular as well.   This presentation  in conjunction with the patient's advanced age  history of hypertension  and diabetes mellitus  puts Mr. Milton at higher risk of developing atrial fibrillation. His symptoms of palpitations  unusual fatigue  and shortness of breath also support this potential diagnosis. An EKG and additional diagnostic tests are recommended to confirm this diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  A 72-year-old African-American male patient presented to the clinic with complaints of a persistently ""racing"" heart and increasing shortness of breath over the last two weeks. The patient also reports occasional light-headedness  fatigue  and reduced ability to exercise. He denies any chest pain  palpitations  syncope  or edema.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which have been well controlled with medication. He has a 45 pack-year smoking history but quit 10 years ago. He does not have a history of heart diseases but his younger brother underwent a heart bypass surgery at 70. His daily medications include Metformin 1g twice daily  Enalapril 10mg daily  and Aspirin 81mg daily for cardiovascular disease prevention.  He is retired  living with his wife  and reports an active lifestyle with regular moderate exercise and a balanced diet. He admits to consuming alcohol occasionally but denies illicit drug use. His vital signs are within normal limits  but an irregular heart rate was noticed on examination. His BMI is 27.8 kg/m2  and blood pressure is well controlled at 130/84 mmHg. An Electrocardiogram (ECG) conducted subsequently confirmed a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation  A 73-year-old African American man  Mr. James Carter  presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and shortness of breath  which started 4 hours ago. He states that the palpitations are associated with a feeling of 'an irregularly beating heart.' He has been experiencing increased fatigue and mild dizziness for the last couple of weeks but did not seek medical advice thinking it to be an age-related issue. He denies chest pain  syncope  or undue sweating.   Mr. Carter is a retired bus driver living with his wife and has a medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is currently on Metformin 500mg twice daily and Amlodipine 5 mg daily. He has a history of smoking 1 pack/day for the last 50 years but quit about 10 years ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally and denies any illicit drug use.   His family history is notable for cardiovascular diseases  with his father having had a myocardial infarction at the age of 68 and his elder sister living with chronic heart failure. There is no history of stroke  blood clotting disorders  or thyroid diseases in the family.   On physical examination  you notice his pulse is irregularly irregular  which further raises your suspicion for atrial fibrillation. His blood pressure is slightly elevated at 145/92 mmHg. He appears mildly distressed due to palpitations but is oriented and in no apparent pain.    His ECG needs to be taken promptly to confirm your suspicion and initiate appropriate management. He also needs relevant laboratory studies and cardiac imaging to assess cardiac structure  function  and to rule out any underlying reversible cause of his palpitations.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Sarah Adams is a 72-year-old Caucasian female presenting to the clinic with complaints of heart palpitations and mild shortness of breath which she has been noticing intermittently for the last few weeks. The patient reports a feeling of her heart ""racing"" and ""skipping beats"". Each episode lasts a few minutes and spontaneously resolves. These episodes are often accompanied by lightheadedness. She denies any associated chest pain or discomfort.  She has a significant past medical history of hypertension which is generally well-controlled with amlodipine. She is a former smoker and quit 10 years ago. She infrequently drinks alcohol with a range of 1-2 drinks per month. No known drug allergies.   Her maternal grandfather had a history of stroke around her current age and an aunt on her mother's side with a history of heart disease.   She lives alone  does her own shopping and cooking  and has two adult children who visit regularly. She remains physically active with a regular walking regimen.   Ms. Adams reports good medication and appointment adherence  with a last documented normal sinus rhythm on EKG done and stable blood pressure at her regular check-up 6 months ago. Her last check-up revealed a normal BMI  normal lipid profile  controlled blood pressure levels.   The patient expresses worry about her symptoms  mentioning how she leads an active lifestyle and is apprehensive towards it being hampered by her current symptoms.   Given her age  symptoms  and familial history of cardiovascular illness  a thorough cardiovascular examination and an EKG would be immediate steps in her evaluation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Sanchez is a 69-year-old Hispanic male who presents to the clinic today complaining of intermittent palpitations and mild shortness of breath for the past 4 months. He describes his palpitations as his heart “racing” and “skipping beats” which lasts for several minutes and then spontaneously resolves. These episodes occur approximately 3-4 times per week. His shortness of breath is noticeable when he is climbing stairs or walking uphill. He also notices that he gets tired more easily nowadays.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Sanchez has a known history of hypertension for the past 10 years and type 2 diabetes for the past 6 years. He has had a past medical history of hyperlipidemia for 15 years. He quit smoking 10 years ago  and he has not consumed alcohol in the past 5 years. There is no known family history of heart disease.  Current Medications:  He is currently taking Metformin 1000 mg twice per day for diabetes  Lisinopril 20 mg once per day for hypertension  and Atorvastatin 40 mg once at bedtime for his high cholesterol.   Review of Systems:  He denies chest pain  dizziness  syncope  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or edema. He denies having a fever  cough  or weight loss.  Social History:  He is retired and lives with his wife. He has 2 adult children. He used to smoke 1 pack of cigarettes per day for over 30 years but quit 10 years ago. He has no history of illicit drug use.  Assessment & Plan:  He is planned for an EKG  echocardiogram  and Holter monitor to evaluate for possible atrial fibrillation considering his symptoms of palpitations and the risk factor of hypertension. His antihypertensive therapy may need adjustment depending on the results. Patient education will be given about lifestyle modifications and the importance of adherence to medication.

Patient Profile: Mr. Jose Garcia  a 68-year-old Hispanic man from San Antonio  Texas presents to the clinic today complaining of heart palpitations  feeling of fatigue and occasional light-headedness for the past couple of weeks.
