Presenting Complaint: He described his heart's rhythm as ""out of beat"" and ""jumping around."" The palpitations appear more frequently during the evening  lasting for several minutes each time. His symptoms have persisted despite the cessation of caffeine and alcohol intake.   Past Medical History: Mr. Garcia was diagnosed with type II diabetes 10 years ago  for which he takes metformin. He also has a history of hypertension  which is managed with losartan. He was a smoker for 30 years and quit about three years ago. His father suffered a stroke in his late 60s.  Social History: He is a retired mechanic  lives with his wife  and is still an active member of his local community. He quit smoking 3 years ago but admits to having a glass of wine with dinner several times a week.  Observations: On examination  Mr. Garcia appeared slightly anxious. He had an irregular pulse rate of 98 beats per minute  blood pressure 138/85 mmHg  respirations were 16 per minute  and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air.   This presentation and past medical history highlight the increased risk for developing atrial fibrillation  considering the patient's age  hypertension  type II diabetes  and history of smoking.

Patient Profile: Name: Mr. John Smith Age: 78 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer Living condition: Lives with wife Location: Urban setting  Arizona  USA  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Smith comes into the clinic complaining of increased heart palpitations over the past few days. He also notes occasional bouts of lightheadedness but no chest pain  shortness of breath  or loss of consciousness.   Past Medical and Social History: Mr. Smith has a history of stage 2 hypertension for which he takes Lisinopril. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia managed with atorvastatin. He is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago after a 30-year pack history. He drinks socially and reports no illicit drug use. He has no known drug allergies.  Family History: There is a family history of cardiac diseases  with his father having passed away from myocardial infarction and his mother having suffered from congestive heart failure. His two siblings are both alive and well.  This presentation is representative of the common demographic characteristics of patients with atrial fibrillation  namely advanced age  male gender  history of hypertension  and Caucasian race.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 72-year-old African-American male who presents to the Cardiology department with complaints of palpitations and occasional breathlessness for the last three weeks.   He describes his symptoms as a fluttering feeling in his chest  with occasional bouts of breathlessness especially when trying to climb the stairs or walk a long distance. He denies  however  any chest pain  dizziness  or fainting episodes.  His medical history is significant for hypertension and Type II diabetes mellitus  both managed with medications for the last 10 years. He also has a history of smoking for over 30 years but decided to quit 5 years ago. He mentions that he consumes alcohol socially but has not had any in the last month.  He has been adherent to his antihypertensive and anti-diabetic medications. His family history is significant for his mother who had a stroke at 79 years old and his father who died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 70.   On physical examination  his heart rate is irregular and fast  currently clocking at 120/min. His blood pressure is 155/90 mmHg and blood glucose levels at 180 mg/dL. On auscultation  you notice an irregular heart rhythm.  Given his age  gender  race  medical history  symptoms  and physical exam findings  you suspect he has atrial fibrillation and decide to conduct more tests to confirm the same.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Williams  a 72-year-old African American retired school teacher  presented to the emergency department (ED) with persistent palpitations  shortness of breath  and a sense of fatigue since the past two days. He described his heart rate as “faster than usual and irregular”. His symptoms were more pronounced with physical exertion.  Mr. Williams is a resident of New York. He lives with his wife and has a history of controlled hypertension for which he has been on Lisinopril for several years. He also recently underwent a total knee replacement surgery for osteoarthritis 6 months ago. His father underwent a cardiac bypass surgery at 75 years age  indicating a family history of cardiac disease.  In his social history  he is an ex-smoker (quit 10 years ago after smoking a packet a day for 30 years)  consumes alcohol socially  and has no known drug history. His BMI is recorded as 28  suggesting overweight but no severe obesity.  He has been otherwise generally fit and active up until these symptoms appeared. He does not report any chest pain  dizziness  syncope  or symptoms of stroke.  On examination  his heart rate was found to be irregular at approximately 100-120 beats per minute  blood pressure was 140/90 mmHg  while physical examination revealed no evident signs of heart failure. He was alert and oriented. EKG confirms suspicion of atrial fibrillation.  Based on the initial presentation  it appears Mr. Williams is presenting with new-onset  non-valvular atrial fibrillation. More data from blood tests and possibly echocardiogram are awaited to examine possible underlying causes and plan management.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. A is a 73-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  and previous cerebrovascular accident. He presents in outpatient clinic today with complaints of intermittent palpitations  feelings of fatigue  and shortness of breath over the past month. These symptoms seem to be increasing in frequency and intensity. He denies chest pain  dizziness  or fainting.  Social History: Mr. A is a former 30 pack-year smoker; quit 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally and denies any illicit drug use. He is retired and lives with his wife. His diet is mainly plant-based as part of his diabetes management. He maintains a sedentary lifestyle due to arthritis.  Family History: His father died of a heart attack at age 75. His mother lived till 90  with a history of type 2 diabetes and osteoporosis.  On clinical examination  his heart rate was irregular and fast. EKG showed atrial fibrillation. Blood pressure was 155/85 mmHg and the rest of the physical examination was normal. His routine blood test results  including thyroid function tests  are pending.   The patient is planned for further evaluation and management of his newly diagnosed atrial fibrillation. A discussion was initiated about initiating anticoagulation therapy to reduce stroke risk  considering his age  history of previous stroke  hypertension  and diabetes.

Patient Presentation:  A 70-year-old African American male presents to the clinic with complaints of heart palpitations and fatigue for the past 2 weeks. He mentions that these symptoms are often accompanied by lightheadedness  shortness of breath  particularly on exertion and occasional chest discomfort. He denies any history of fainting or lower extremity edema.   Past Medical History: The patient has a known medical history of hypertension for which he has been on Amlodipine 5mg daily for the past 8 years. He was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus 5 years ago  currently controlled with Metformin 1000mg twice daily. He also has a history of ischemic stroke 2 years ago  from which he made a full recovery with nil long term neurological deficits.  His other past medical history includes hyperlipidemia for which he is on Atorvastatin 20mg nocte  and he has a 30 pack-year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally and denies any drug abuse.  His only surgical history was a right total knee replacement 4 years ago for severe osteoarthritis. His family history reveals that his father had suffered from atrial fibrillation and his mother was diabetic and hypertensive.   On physical examination  his heart rate was irregularly irregular  blood pressure was 150/90 mmHg and respiratory rate was 18 breaths per minute. Oxygen saturation was 96% on room air. Findings from chest  abdominal and neurological examinations were unremarkable. His weight was 210 lbs and height was 5'10''  making his BMI 30.1 kg/m2.   Lab results revealed a HemoglobinA1C of 7.3% and a lipid panel with a LDL of 110 mg/dl. Baseline EKG was performed which showed atrial fibrillation with a ventricular rate of 110 bpm. The patient was admitted for rate control  anticoagulation initiation  and further management of atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. James Brown  a 73-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the cardiology clinic complaining of intermittent heart palpitations and general fatigue over the last two months. He rates his symptoms as mild to moderate  but expresses concern since these symptoms are a recent development. He denied any associated chest pain  shortness of breath  dizziness  or syncope. He states that these episodes last for few hours and usually resolve on their own.  Mr. Brown is a retired teacher  a non-smoker  and a social drinker who averages two to three glasses of red wine a week. He considers himself relatively active for his age  engaging in regular walking and gardening.   His past medical history includes hypertension  which was diagnosed at 60 years of age and currently managed with Lisinopril. He also has a history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus  controlled with Metformin for the past eight years. He has negative family history of heart diseases.  On physical examination  his vital signs showed a blood pressure of 145/85 mmHg  pulse rate of 98 bpm with irregular rhythm  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  body temperature of 98.6°F  and a oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. Cardiovascular examination revealed an irregularly irregular pulse and absence of murmurs. Rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.   Given his demographic profile  medical history  and clinical presentation  he seems suggestive of Atrial Fibrillation. However  additional cardiac diagnostic tests such as Electrocardiogram (ECG) will be necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 75-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the cardiology clinic with a complaint of recurrent palpitations since last month. He reports that these episodes of rapid  irregular heartbeats typically last from minutes to hours  and are occasionally associated with lightheadedness. He denies experiencing any chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncope. He has a history of hypertension controlled with Lisinopril for the past ten years. He also reports being a former habitual smoker  with cessation twenty years ago  and denies any illicit drug or alcohol abuse. Family history is significant; his father had atrial fibrillation and coronary artery disease.  His only additional health concern is osteoarthritis that is managed by occasional over-the-counter NSAIDs. His BP is 135/85 mm Hg  heart rate irregularly irregular at 85-120 bpm. Physical examination is remarkable for an irregularly irregular heart rate. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable  with good pulses in all extremities and no signs of heart failure.  The patient's electrocardiogram (ECG) confirms atrial fibrillation. Given his age  history  and physical examination findings  Mr. Smith is term risk for stroke and will most likely require rate control  possible rhythm control  and anticoagulation treatment after further evaluation for risks and benefits. His hypertension and age put him in an elevated risk category per the CHA2DS2-VASc Score. His healthcare team proposes further investigations like an echo-cardiogram  lab tests  and a discussion about initiating anticoagulation therapy.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Martinez  a 69-year-old Hispanic male  retired businessman  presents to the clinic with complaints of recurrent palpitations  fatigue  and occasional light-headedness on exertion  which has been ongoing for the past two months. He reports that he has episodes of rapid  irregular heartbeat that may last from a few minutes to a few hours  occurring randomly. There have been no episodes of syncope  chest pain or shortness of breath.   He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  which has been controlled well with medication (Lisinopril) for the last ten years. However  he admits to having been lax with his diet lately with increased intake of salt. There's no personal history of heart attacks  strokes  or valvular heart disease.  The patient is an ex-smoker who quit 15 years ago. He admits to occasional alcohol use  especially during social events. He denies recreational drug use. His father had a history of myocardial infarction in his 70s  his mother died in old age from non-cardiac causes  and one of his brothers has diabetes mellitus.  Mr. Martinez is currently living with his wife. He is a retired businessman who continues to stay active in his community. He mentions often feeling stressed over family matters.  Summary: A 69-year-old Hispanic male with a history of hypertension  presenting with palpitations  fatigue  and light-headedness  suggestive of atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the office with a chief complaint of intermittent palpitations and shortness of breath for the past three weeks. The episodes last for minutes to hours  are not triggered or relieved by anything specific  and are sometimes associated with lightheadedness. He denies chest pain  syncope  or pre-syncope.   He has a past medical history significant for hypertension which is managed with lisinopril  and benign prostatic hyperplasia for which he takes tamsulosin. He has been a non-smoker all his life  drinks alcohol socially  and has a BMI within normal limits. His past surgical history is unremarkable.  Upon examination  irregular pulse and rapid heart rate were noted. No signs of heart failure or valvular disease were observed on examination. An ECG was advised which showed irregular R-R intervals and the absence of distinct P waves  consistent with atrial fibrillation.  His mother had a history of stroke and his father had a history of ischemic heart disease. He is retired and lives with his wife  and their two adult children live nearby. He is independent in all his daily activities.  This case seems to be a presentation of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation given the patient’s history  physical examination  and ECG findings.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. J.  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic complaining of occasional palpitations  slight fatigue  and a ""fluttering"" feeling in his chest. These symptoms occurred intermittently for the past month but have been increasingly frequent during the past week. His past medical history details are as follows:   Medical History: 1. Hypertension: Diagnosed at age 50  treated with amlodipine and hydrochlorothiazide. 2. Type II Diabetes: Diagnosed at age 52  under control with metformin. 3. Dyslipidemia: Diagnosed at age 58  controlled with statin therapy. 4. Prior history of smoking: He quit smoking around age 60. 5. Moderate alcohol use  drinking 1-2 glasses of wine  4 times per week.  Mr. J. denies symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath  dizziness  or fainting episodes. He has had no previous cardiac-related symptoms and has had no interventions such as heart surgeries or procedures. He denies any family history of premature heart disease or sudden cardiac death.  The patient is a retired school teacher. He lives with his wife of 40 years and they have two adult children. His diet mainly consists of home-cooked meals  with occasional dining out. He occasionally goes for evening walks as part of his exercise regimen.  His vital signs upon presentation are blood pressure 140/90 mmHg  pulse rate irregular at 105 beats per minute  respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute  temperature of 37.2 degrees Celsius  and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. His BMI is 28 indicating overweight.   In the demographic literature  atrial fibrillation is commonly found among elderly populations  with a median age of 66.8 years. There is also an over-representation in Caucasian populations  and the condition is more common among males. Risk factors often include hypertension  diabetes  dyslipidemia  obesity  and a history of smoking.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith  a 72-year-old African-American male  reports to the clinic with a chief complaint of ongoing intermittent palpitations and fatigue over the past couple of weeks. He has no associated chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncope but has noted occasional light-headedness. Smith's past medical history includes hypertension (on Lisinopril and Amlodipine)  hyperlipidemia (on Atorvastatin)  and Type 2 diabetes mellitus (on Metformin). He has no known past history of heart disease  stroke  or blood clotting disorders.  He is an ex-smoker and quit 15 years ago after smoking a half pack a day for 35 years. He uses alcohol moderately  an average of 1-2 drinks per day. Mr. Smith is a retired public school teacher  and he lives with his wife. He has a family history of heart disease  with his father deceased from an acute myocardial infarction at age 85.  On physical examination  his pulse is irregular and fast-counted at around 105 beats per minute  and his blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg. The cardiovascular examination shows an irregular rhythm with no murmurs. Rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. An electrocardiogram (ECG) confirms atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response.   Based on his presentation  age  sex  and past medical history  it was decided to further investigate and manage Mr. Smith for his atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Wilson  a 78-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic today with complaints of palpitations and intermittent episodes of light-headedness over the past three weeks. He states that he has been feeling his ""heart race"" randomly in his chest  which lasts for about 1-2 minutes and then subsides on its own. These symptoms have increased in frequency over the past week. The patient denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  loss of consciousness  or lower extremity edema.   His past medical history is significant for Hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus  both of which have been well controlled with Metoprolol and Metformin respectively. He reports adherence to his medications. He quit smoking around 20 years ago and drinks alcohol socially. The patient's father had a history of atrial fibrillation.   Upon examination  an irregularly irregular heart rhythm is noted. Besides  the patient's blood pressure is controlled  and neurological examination does not show any deficit. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. The initial ECG reports atrial fibrillation with a variable ventricular response. Further diagnostic tests including lab works  echocardiogram and Holter monitoring are deemed necessary to establish the severity and underlying cause of his arrhythmia. His risk of stroke is assessed and for now  falls in medium risk category due to above 75 years of age.  He is advised to limit his alcohol intake and a change in his currently prescribed beta-blocker medication is discussed to manage his newly diagnosed atrial fibrillation. His case is also studied for the possible initiation of anticoagulation therapy to prevent stroke  incorporating risk factors and contraindications. He is referred to a cardiologist for further management and consultation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Rogers  a 75-year-old African American male with a prior medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes into the clinic complaining of occasional feelings of a ""rapid heart rate"" and ""fluttering"" in his chest that started a few weeks ago. He also reports intermittent episodes of light-headedness. He denies any chest pain  dyspnea on exertion  or syncopal events.  He had quit smoking 10 years ago after a 40-pack year history  and drinks alcohol socially with moderation. His mother had a history of atrial fibrillation and he has no allergy history. His regular medications include amlodipine 5mg and atorvastatin 20mg.  On examination  the pulse is irregularly irregular  ranging between 75-105 beats per minute with a blood pressure of 148/90 mmHg. An ECG is performed which shows absence of P waves with irregularly irregular QRS complexes consistent with atrial fibrillation. Arrangement for ECHO and cardiology consultation is made.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. James Wright is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations  occasional shortness of breath  and fatigue that has been ongoing for the past 2 days. Mr. Wright mentions that he has had intermittent episodes of these symptoms in the past  but none that have lasted this long. He denies any chest pain  dizziness  or syncope.   Demographics:  Mr. Wright lives in New York with his wife and is retired from his job as a set designer in Broadway Productions. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially  usually limited to 1-2 drinks during social events. His diet is well balanced  and he was previously very active and enjoyed jogging and hiking; however  he has curtailed these activities due to his recent symptoms.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Wright has a history of hypertension which is being managed by a calcium channel blocker. He also has a diagnosis of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which is controlled through metformin and lifestyle modifications. He does not have any known allergies to medications. His mother suffered from chronic heart disease and his father was hypertensive.  Current Medication:  1. Amlodipine 10 mg daily  2. Metformin 500 mg twice a day  Upon examination  the physician notes an irregular rhythm during the cardiac examination - irregularly irregular - raising suspicion for Atrial Fibrillation. Further workup  including an ECG  is planned to confirm the diagnosis and assess the patient's stroke risk. Based on the patient's age  hypertension  and diabetes  medical management is likely to consist of rate control  rhythm control  and anticoagulation pending further diagnostics and specialist consult.

Patient Presentation  Mr. James Smith is a 71-year-old African American male with a chief complaint of palpitations and shortness of breath that has been ongoing for the past three days. He also reports experiencing mild fatigue and intermittent chest discomfort.   Past medical history is significant for hypertension  managed with Lisinopril 20mg daily for the past five years. He has no known history of heart disease or stroke  and there's no family history of heart disease. His BMI is 29.8 and he admits to consuming alcohol on regular basis  although he quit smoking two decades ago.  On examination  his blood pressure is 138/82 mmHg  his pulse is irregular at 110 beats/min  respiration rate is at 16 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. An electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm without any P waves  suggestive of atrial fibrillation.   In summary  Mr. Smith is a 71-year-old hypertensive  African American man  presenting with signs and symptoms consistent with atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Dawson is a 67-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the cardiology clinic complaining of persistent heart palpitations and occasional breathlessness for the past few weeks. He says he hasn't been able to do his daily 2-mile walk due to feeling winded. He also reports episodes of light-headedness but denies any chest pain or syncope.  He has a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both controlled with medication. He was a 30-year  pack-a-day smoker but quit 10 years ago. Mr. Dawson admits he drinks about 2-3 glasses of wine every evening. His diabetes control has been difficult with HbA1c ranging from 7%- 8% over the last year.   Family history is significant for cardiovascular disease in both his father and mother. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 62 and his mother had a stroke at the age of 68. He has two siblings who are alive and well.   Other than his longstanding hypertension and diabetes  he has not been hospitalized for any other medical conditions. He is currently on metformin 500mg twice daily  lisinopril 10mg once daily  atorvastatin 20mg at bedtime  and low-dose aspirin. He denies any allergies or drug intolerance.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic complaining of an ""irregular and occasionally racing heartbeat"" for the past few weeks. He notes associated symptoms such as fatigue  lightheadedness  and occasional shortness of breath especially during his regular morning walks. He denies any chest pain or syncope.   Mr. Johnson has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medication (Lisinopril 20 mg daily and Atorvastatin 20 mg per night  respectively). He also mentions a history of ""heart trouble"" in his family; his father had suffered from a heart attack at the age of 72.   He quit smoking ten years ago but admits to drinking a glass of wine with dinner most nights. He is retired and lives with his wife; both of his children live within driving distance.  On examination  his pulse was irregularly irregular  blood pressure was 130/85 mmHg  and respiratory rate was 16 breaths per minute. Lungs were clear to auscultation  cardiac examination revealed irregular rhythm with no murmurs  and no peripheral edema was noted.  Lab results: N-terminal pro-B-type natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP): 1000 pg/mL (normal: less than 300 pg/mL)  A subsequent 12-lead ECG revealed evidence of atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old African American male presents to the clinic with complaints of intermittent palpitations  occasional shortness of breath and fatigue that has progressively worsened over the past four months. He rated the severity of palpitations on an arbitrary scale (1 to 10) as a 7 but denies experiencing any chest pain  dizziness  or syncope.   He has a known past medical history of hypertension  for which he takes Lisinopril  and Type 2 Diabetes managed with Metformin. He has a 10-pack year smoking history but quit 15 years ago. Only significant family history is his father who had a stroke at the age of 70. He maintains a mostly sedentary lifestyle and admits non-compliance to his prescribed diabetic diet.   On physical examination  an irregularly irregular heart rhythm is noted. The blood pressure reading is 155/88 mmHg  and his resting pulse rate is 105 bpm. Pulses are irregular  and no heart murmurs are identified on auscultation.   The presenting symptoms and physical examination findings raise suspicion for atrial fibrillation. Further diagnostic tests  including an ECG and potentially echocardiogram  should be performed to confirm this suspicion.

Patient Presentation: Ms. Patricia  a 73-year-old Caucasian woman  presents to the clinic with complaints of heart palpitations and shortness of breath.  History: She describes experiencing palpitations over the past few weeks  mainly noticeable at rest  causing her to feel anxious. In addition  over the past few days  she has encountered increasing breathlessness during her regular morning walks which she had not experienced before. She denies experiencing chest pain  fainting spells or blackouts.  Demographic and Lifestyle Details:  She is a retired school teacher  lives alone  and she has been a nonsmoker and teetotaller her entire life. She follows a balanced diet and has been relatively active until the commencement of these symptoms.  Past Medical and Surgical History:  Significant past medical history includes well-controlled hypertension for 15 years  and type 2 diabetes managed by diet and oral hypoglycaemic agents over the past 10 years. She has had no previous surgeries.  Family History: Her father passed away in his late 70s due to heart failure  and her mother succumbed to a stroke. She has 2 siblings  a brother diagnosed with coronary artery disease  and a sister who is healthy.  Medications:  She is compliant with her medications which include Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension  and Metformin 500mg twice daily for diabetes. She has no known drug allergies.  On examination  her blood pressure was 140/85 mmHg  pulse irregular at 110 beats per minute. An electrocardiogram indicated atrial fibrillation  and hence  she was scheduled for echocardiography and further evaluation.   Given her age  demographics  medical history and current symptoms  she represents a typical patient with new onset of atrial fibrillation.

Patient Information:   Mr. Fredrick Johnson  a 70-year-old African American man  solutions architect  married with three adult children.  Chief Complaint:   Mr. Johnson presents with a complaint of irregular heartbeats and shortness of breath for the last two weeks  particularly after physical activities.  History of Present Illness:  Patient reports that these symptoms began approximately 14 days ago. He has noted that his heart “flutters” throughout the day and occasionally feels short of breath  especially upon climbing stairs or doing any physical work. He denies any chest pain  dizziness  or syncope.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a past medical history significant for hypertension for the last 10 years  currently well controlled with Amlodipine  and early stage chronic kidney disease. He also had a transient ischemic attack five years ago with full recovery.  Family History:  There is a maternal history of heart disease with his mother passing away at 75 from a myocardial infarction. He has one sister who is currently living with diabetes at 65.  Social History:   He is a retired solutions architect and does not report any exposure to hazardous materials. He has a 20-pack year history of smoking but quit around 20 years ago; consumes alcohol socially  roughly two times a month. He is active and walks regularly for exercise and has a diet consisting of fruits  vegetables  and low sodium following his hypertension diagnosis.   Medications:  Daily medications include amlodipine 10mg/day for hypertension.  Review of Systems:  Mr. Johnson denies chest pain  orthopnea  swelling of legs  unexplained fatigue  and fainting or palpitations. He reports no issues in other systems.  Physical Examination:   On physical exam  Mr. Johnson appears in no acute distress. His blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg  pulse 96 beats per minute and irregular  respirations 16 per minute  and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Cardiac auscultation reveals an irregular rhythm. His lungs are clear to auscultation and there is no lower leg edema.  This patient presentation could suggest Atrial Fibrillation and further tests including an ECG would be ordered to confirm this.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. S  a 72-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the clinic with complaints of palpitations and occasional shortness of breath. The symptoms have been ongoing for about two weeks. He reports no chest pain  dizziness  or syncope. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  treated with Losartan  and diabetes mellitus type 2  controlled with Metformin. His BMI is 28  representing overweight. He has a 10-pack-year history of smoking but quit 15 years ago  and reports excessive alcohol consumption in the past  though has been abstinent for the last 5 years.  Family history reveals his father had a stroke around his current age. Review of systems is otherwise negative including no recent illnesses or fever. On examination  his pulse is irregularly irregular  and blood pressure is slightly elevated. The remainder of the physical exam  including a respiratory and neurological examination  is unremarkable. EKG shows atrial fibrillation with an average ventricular rate of 95 beats per minute. This is Mr. S's first presentation with symptoms suggestive of atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation:   Ms. Perkins is a 75-year-old African American female  retired school teacher  who presents in your clinic with complaints of persistent fatigue  intermittent rapid and irregular heartbeats  and occasional shortness of breath for the past three weeks. Despite a moderate  active lifestyle and balanced diet  she has been experiencing these symptoms which have disrupted her daily activities.   Past medical history reveals that she has hypertension and was diagnosed with type II diabetes five years ago. She has been managing her illness with dietary control  oral hypoglycemic agents  and antihypertensive medication. She also has a family history of cardiovascular diseases - her mother had a stroke at the age of 78  and her father died of myocardial infarction at age 84.   On physical examination  she has an irregularly irregular heartbeat. EKG results confirm atrial fibrillation. She denies any chest pain  nausea  vomiting  or presyncope. She does not smoke  consume alcohol  and has no known allergies. She lives with her husband and they have three adult children  none of whom have any significant health issues.  Upon query  Ms. Perkins reveals that she has been non-compliant with her medications due to financial constraints. She has a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg which is higher than her usual 130/85 mmHg.   Her increased age  history of hypertension and diabetes  and her recent non-compliance present an increased risk for atrial fibrillation. Patient education and adjusting her treatment plan to be more affordable are crucial next steps.

Patient Presentation:  A 67-year-old African American female presents to the emergency department with chief complaints of irregular heart palpitations and shortness of breath  which have intensified over the past two days. She has also experienced mild dizziness and fatigue which she attributes to poor sleep given her recent discomfort.  The patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension which was diagnosed 10 years ago and is well-controlled with Losartan 50mg daily. She was also diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus 5 years ago. She admits non-compliance towards her antidiabetic medication (metformin 500mg twice daily) due to gastrointestinal disturbances. She denies any history of cardiovascular disease  stroke  thyroid disease  or pulmonary disease. The patient does not smoke and only drinks alcohol socially.  On examination  her blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg  pulse 115 bpm with irregular rhythm  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 98% on room air  and temperature is normal. A cardiovascular examination reveals an irregularly irregular pulse and no murmur. She is alert  oriented  and denying any chest pain currently.  Considering her age  ethnicity  and history of hypertension and type II diabetes  she falls within the demographic more commonly affected by atrial fibrillation  particularly among those individuals with uncontrolled blood pressure and non-compliant with an anti-diabetic regimen. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is ordered to confirm the suspected diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of periodic chest discomfort and palpitations for the past couple of weeks. The patient describes the sensations as intermittent periods where his heart feels like it's ""fluttering"" in his chest. This is often preceded by a feeling of slight discomfort and tightness. He also reports increased fatigue and intermittent dizziness particularly upon exertion  but no history of syncope  breathlessness or pedal edema. The incidents last anywhere from 30 minutes to a few hours and self-resolve.  He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has been compliant with his medications which include atenolol  lisinopril  atorvastatin  and metformin. He denies smoking and illegal drug use  but admits to moderate alcohol intake. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease; both his father and older brother had myocardial infarctions in their early 70s. His routine yearly check-ups and blood work have been largely unremarkable. He claims that his weight has been stable and has had no recent decline in appetite. His exercise capacity has been gradually reducing over the past year.  This presentation  combined with his existing risk factors indicates a high clinical suspicion of atrial fibrillation. Further investigations including an EKG and perhaps an echocardiogram are necessary for diagnosis  and subsequent management and treatment can be decided based on the results of these investigations.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jose Gonzalez  a 70-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the clinic with complaints of feeling faint and having palpitations. He reports an onset of these symptoms for the past two weeks. He occasionally experiences shortness of breath and lightheadedness  especially after performing physical tasks or walking for extended periods.  He moved to the U.S. from Mexico in his early twenties and has been working for the last 50 years as a construction laborer. He has a history of smoking (1 pack of cigarettes daily) for 20 years but quit about 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally.   Past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus  being controlled with metformin  for which he complies with the prescribed medication. He also has a history of hypertension  which is managed with amlodipine. His family history reveals that his father had a myocardial infarction in his late fifties.  He prefers a low-salt diet. He's moderately active but admits that he could exercise more regularly. He reports his sleep is generally adequate  although lately disrupted by his symptoms.  On examination  irregularly irregular heart beats are noted. Vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  and pulse rate of 115 bpm. He is alert and oriented  the rest physical examination is unremarkable.  His recent blood investigations show HbA1c of 7.1%. However  the patient has not had any cardiac investigations recently. A regularly scheduled appointment is advised for further investigations including an electrocardiogram (ECG). With his age  ethnicity  history of hypertension  diabetes  and the presenting symptoms  the patient is potentially at risk for atrial fibrillation.

Patient Profile:   Name: Mr. John Allen Age: 65 years old  Gender: Male Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired engineer   Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Allen comes to the clinic with complaints of recurrent episodes of palpitations  rapid heartbeats  and shortness of breath for the past 3 months. He also occasionally experiences dizziness and fatigue.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Allen has a history of hypertension over the past 10 years and has been on anti-hypertensive medication. He was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 5 years ago.   Family History: His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60. His mother has hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus.  Social History: He is a former smoker  reporting smoking a pack a day for 30 years  but quit 4 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially. He lives with his wife in a suburban neighborhood. He is relatively sedentary  as he enjoys reading and woodworking as hobbies.  Physical Examination:  On examination  he has an irregular pulse rate of 100 beats per minute. Blood pressure recorded is 140/90 mmHg. Rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Based on the history and examination  a preliminary diagnosis of atrial fibrillation is considered  and further investigations are planned.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Smith  a 73-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic today with complaints of irregular and often rapid heart rate experienced for the past two days. He reports dyspnea and considerable fatigue  especially on exertion. Mr. Smith has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he takes lisinopril and atorvastatin respectively. He also reveals a family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father having passed away at the age of 78 from myocardial infarction. Mr. Smith is a retired teacher  non-smoker and occasionally drinks alcohol socially. His last annual check-up  6 months ago  did not indicate any significant abnormalities. Currently  he is afebrile and reports no chest pain  cough  or recent illnesses. Critical to note  Mr. Smith underwent a surgical procedure for a hernia repair 3 years ago but experienced post-operative atrial fibrillation which resolved in 48 hours with rate control and anticoagulation. However  he has not experienced or been treated for atrial fibrillation since that episode.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. David Johnson  a 67-year-old African American male  presents with complaints of palpitations  fatigue  shortness of breath  and occasional dizziness. He states these symptoms have been occurring intermittently over the past few weeks and have progressively worsened  leading him to seek medical attention.   Mr. Johnson has a past medical history significant for hypertension  which is poorly controlled despite antihypertensive medication compliance. He also has a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  managed with Metformin. His surgical history is unremarkable but he has a family history of heart disease - both parents had myocardial infarctions in their late 60s. He admits to a prior smoking habit of 2 packs per day for 20 years  but quit approximately 10 years ago. His alcohol consumption is moderate  reporting a few drinks per week. His diet could be better but he states  ""I've been trying to make healthier choices."" He does not exercise regularly but tries to stay active with his grandchildren. He is retired and lives with his wife.  Review of systems reveals no chest pain  cough  or lower extremity swelling. He denies any headaches or changes in vision. There are no neurological symptoms such as numbness  tingling  or weakness. No abdominal or genitourinary symptoms are reported. He has had no recent illnesses or fevers.   Examination reveals an irregularly irregular heartbeat on auscultation with otherwise clear lungs and normal exam findings. These findings have led to a further investigation suspecting atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. John  who works as a retired engineer. He came into the clinic with a primary complaint of intermittent palpitations for the last couple of days. These episodes are not associated with chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncope  but he has noticed an increasing frequency over the past few months.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension for which he has been taking Lisinopril for the past 10 years. His hypertension has been well-controlled with his medication regimen. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father passing away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 75. He quit smoking 15 years ago and only drinks alcohol occasionally.  His vital signs show a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg and a heart rate varying from 80-120 beats per minute  irregularly irregular. On physical examination  he appears alert and oriented. There are no signs of cyanosis or jaundice. Cardiovascular examination reveals irregularly irregular pulse and no murmurs.   The EKG performed in the clinic confirmed atrial fibrillation. His labs indicate his kidney and thyroid function are in normal ranges.  This correlates with demographic representation  with older age and Caucasian race being a common demographic in atrial fibrillation. Similarly  his history of hypertension and family history of cardiovascular disease also increases his risk of developing this condition.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. A.J.  is a 70-year-old African-American retired schoolteacher male  who presented to the clinic with complaints of intermittent palpitations  lightheadedness  and occasional shortness of breath  particularly after moderate exercise such as climbing stairs. These symptoms have been on and off for the past few weeks. He denies any chest pain  syncope  or loss of consciousness.   Mr. A.J. Professes to maintaining an active life post-retirement  often involving community service and minor athletic endeavors. He does not smoke or consume alcohol. His diet is mainly vegetarian with low-sodium. He reports no allergies.  As per his medical history  Mr. A.J. was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago  and manages it with a daily dose of amlodipine 5mg. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia controlled with atorvastatin. His father had a diagnosed case of atrial fibrillation in his old age  but the patient has never been diagnosed with any cardiac arrhythmias before. His last baseline ECG performed two years ago was normal.   Mr. A.J. has been adherent to his medication regimen and annual general check-ups  however  he reveals his blood pressure readings have been slightly elevated over the past couple of months. His BMI is within a normal range and there is no history of significant weight loss or gain in the recent past. He got vaccinated for influenza and pneumococcus earlier this season.   The rest of his family history is non-contributory  with no other notable heart diseases. His social history shows he lives with his wife and enjoys time with his grandchildren when they visit every weekend. The review of other systems  including the gastrointestinal  respiratory  and central nervous system  is non-contributory. His last colonoscopy and prostate screening were normal 1 year ago.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Williams is a 75-year-old African-American male  retired Army veteran  who presents to the office complaining of an occasional ""racing"" heartbeat and mild shortness of breath  especially during physical activities  for the past two weeks. His symptoms seem to come and go. He also reports generalized fatigue.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension  treated with lisinopril 10mg daily  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed with metformin 500mg BID. He also reports a prior heart murmur detected 20 years ago  but he was not given any treatment for it. He has not had any previous surgeries.  Mr. Williams is widowed and lives in a suburban neighborhood in California with his daughter. He has a history of smoking at least one pack a day for 40 years; he quit six years ago after being diagnosed with diabetes. He drinks alcohol occasionally and denies drug use. His father passed away due to a myocardial infarction at the age of 65  and his mother had a history of stroke.  On examination  his blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg  heart rate irregularly irregular at 110 beats/min  respiratory rate is 15 per min  and SpO2 is 96% on room air. On cardiovascular examination  an irregularly irregular rhythm is noted. Laboratory findings include a Hemoglobin A1C level of 8.0%.  The clinical features and examination findings of a fast  irregularly irregular rhythm suggest a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic with a persistent sense of irregular heartbeat over the past few weeks. He complains of associated mild shortness of breath on exertion  fatigue and intermittent light-headedness  particularly during episodes of fast heartbeat. He denies chest pain  syncopal episodes  or severe dyspnea.   Relevant past medical history reveals hypertension for 8 years  managed with Lisinopril  and type 2 diabetes mellitus for about 5 years  controlled with Metformin. He had a cholecystectomy 12 years ago  with no other surgical history.   His family history is significant for cardiomyopathy in his mother. Mr. Doe is a retired banker  lives with his wife and has no history of smoking or alcohol consumption. He walked his dog daily until these heart irregularities began. His diet is balanced with minimal intake of salt and sugar  as advised because of his medical conditions. On review of systems  no other issues are identified.   The picture  based on this initial evaluation  points towards symptomatic atrial fibrillation which requires further investigation and prompt management considering his age and co-existing cardiovascular risk factors.

Patient Presentation:  A 72-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. T  presents to the clinic with persistent palpitations. He describes these palpitations as irregular and admits to feeling light-headed at times. He has also reported episodes of shortness of breath on exertion. He denies chest pain  syncope  or any form of lower extremity swelling.  Mr. T has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia and his medications include hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. His family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases. He is a former smoker and has a moderate alcohol consumption of two drinks per week. His diet is generally balanced  but he admits he may consume high salt meals occasionally. He lives with his wife  retired  with a pet dog.  On physical examination  his vital signs are within normal limits  except for an irregular heart rhythm at a rate of 96 beats per minute. No murmurs were noted on auscultation and there were no signs of peripheral edema.   Given his age and non-specific but suggestive symptoms  along with his predisposing history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  there is a high suspicion of atrial fibrillation. A 12-lead ECG is recommended to confirm this preliminary diagnosis. Further long-term management of this condition may involve rate control  anticoagulation  or rhythm control strategies  depending primarily on Mr. T's symptoms  stroke risk  and quality of life.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Thomas is a 67-year-old African-American retired school teacher who presented to the outpatient cardiology department. He has been experiencing episodes of palpitations and shortness of breath for the last few months.  He is known to have hypertension for the past 10 years which is currently managed on Metoprolol and Losartan. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus three years ago  which is currently well-controlled on oral anti-diabetic agents. He also has a past medical history of heart failure diagnosed two years prior. He has never smoked and consumes moderate amounts of alcohol. His father passed away due to a stroke and his younger brother has coronary artery disease.  On examination  his pulse is irregularly irregular and there is mild pitting edema in his lower extremities. His recent bloodwork showed a near-normal HbA1c and a lipid profile within normal ranges.  The patient’s complaints of palpitations and irregularly irregular pulse  along with his past medical history of hypertension  diabetes  and heart failure  suggest he may be having episodes of atrial fibrillation. The patient is advised to undergo an ECG and echocardiogram for further evaluation.

Subjective:  Mr. David Stevens is a 71-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic complaining of persistent intermittent palpitations  fatigue  mild shortness of breath during routine activities  and occasional lightheadedness over the last two months. He denies chest pain  recent illness  or any associated lower extremity swelling. The patient reports that his symptoms have been progressively increasing in frequency and severity over the last two weeks.  Objective:  Upon examination  the patient appears in no visible distress  with unremarkable skin color  but with a slight irregularity observed in his pulse rate. Vital signs are within normal limits apart from an irregular heart rate fluctuating between 75 and 100 BPM. His BMI suggests he is overweight (BMI: 28).  Past Medical History:  Mr. Stevens has a history of hypertension for which he has been on Lisinopril for the last five years. He is also a former smoker who quit 10 years ago after a 30-year smoking history. There is no known heart disease or diabetes mellitus in his medical history.   Family History:  Father passed away due to complications related to heart failure at the age of 83  and mother has hypertension.  Lifestyle:  He is retired  lives with his wife  and holds a moderate activity level. He drinks alcohol socially but denies any illicit drug use.  Assessment:  Given the symptoms and medical history  there is suspicion for atrial fibrillation. He needs to undergo EKG and other appropriate lab workup for a proper diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. A is a 72-year-old African-American male presenting with a fast and irregular heartbeat that he describes as a ""fluttering"" sensation in his chest  accompanied by weakness and fatigue. These symptoms have been occurring intermittently over the past three days. He also reported occasional episodes of lightheadedness and shortness of breath  especially during physical activities.   Past Medical History:   Mr. A has a history of hypertension for which he takes Amlodipine 10mg daily. His blood pressure at today's visit is 150/90 mmHg. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 7 years ago and is on Metformin 1000mg twice daily. His HbA1c level at his last visit 3 months ago was 7.4%. Mr. A also has a history of hyperlipidemia and is currently on Atorvastatin 20mg daily.  He quit smoking 10 years ago but had smoked a pack a day for over 35 years. He continues to consume 2-3 glasses of wine per week.  Family History:   His father had a stroke at the age of 80 and his mother passed away at the age of 92 due to Alzheimer's disease. He has one brother who also has hypertension and diabetes  and one sister with no known health issues.  Review of Systems:   Negative for chest pain  palpitations  cough  or wheezing. He complains of no fever  weight fluctuations  or changes in appetite. He has not been experiencing any difficulty urinating  abnormal bowel movements  or edema of his legs.   Physical Exam:   On physical examination  his heart rate was irregular at 110 beats per minute. Auscultation revealed an irregular rhythm without any murmurs  rubs  or gallops. No jugular venous distension was observed. His lungs were clear on auscultation  and his extremity exam revealed no peripheral edema.   Based on his irregular pulse and the lack of any signs suggesting congestive heart failure  a 12-lead ECG was ordered which confirmed our suspicion of atrial fibrillation.  The patient was informed that based on his comorbidities and symptoms  he likely has atrial fibrillation. He was referred for further evaluation with Echocardiography to evaluate heart chambers  valves  and to confirm AF  initiate empiric anti-coagulation along with rate control therapy and cardiology consultation was done for further management.   This clinical scenario is representative given prior literature exhibiting a higher prevalence of atrial fibrillation with increasing age as well as its more common occurrence in those patients with histories of hypertension  diabetes  and prior smoking.

Patient Presentation:  A 70-year-old African American male presents to the clinic complaining of a four-week history of an irregular heartbeat  episodes of shortness of breath  and fatigue. He also describes occasional lightheadedness but denies experiencing chest pain or syncope. On examination  he is noted to have an irregularly irregular pulse. His blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg  pulse is 90 beats per minute  and he has a grade 2/6 systolic murmur in addition to his irregular heart rhythm.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension which has been well-controlled on lisinopril for the past decade. He has never smoked and has a moderate alcohol consumption of around five units per week. He has no known drug allergies. His father had a myocardial infarction in his early seventies and his mother suffers from rheumatoid arthritis.  The rest of his examination is within normal limits  including a clear chest on auscultation  no lower limb edema  and no signs suggestive of cerebrovascular or peripheral vascular disease.   Based on his age  AF-associated symptoms  and African American race  this patient’s presentation is consistent with atrial fibrillation. In society  atrial fibrillation is common in the elderly  hypertensive patients  and African Americans appear to be disproportionately affected.

Patient Presentation  Mr. John Doe  a 71-year-old African American male  presents to the cardiology clinic with a several week history of palpitations  dizziness and shortness of breath on exertion that has been progressively getting worse.   He has a past medical history significant for hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus which are well controlled with medications. He denies a history of heart disease but has a family history of myocardial infarction. He used to smoke a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years before quitting 10 years ago. There is no recent history of alcohol or illicit drug use. He has no known drug allergies.   Upon examination  irregularly irregular heart rhythm was noted and subsequent ECG confirmed atrial fibrillation. His current medications include metformin for diabetes and amlodipine for hypertension.   These symptoms are impacting his daily living as he is retired and enjoys playing golf. He lives with his wife and spends active time with grandchildren. He is a veteran and used to be in good physical condition. He admits difficulty managing these symptoms which are causing him anxiety. Current BMI is 28  indicating he is overweight.  Considering his age  race  existing conditions of hypertension  DM and lifestyle factors  he is on the high risk of having atrial fibrillation (AF). AF risk increases with age and is higher in men and people with diabetes or heart disease. African Americans are reported to have a lower prevalence of AF compared to white individuals but far worse AF-related health outcomes. AF has been independently associated with increased risk of all-cause mortality  myocardial infarction (MI)  heart failure and chronic kidney disease in African Americans. It is paramount we address his condition with appropriate management and treatment.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Peterson is a 67-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the clinic with complaints of palpitations  fatigue  and occasional dizziness for the past few weeks. His symptoms have progressively worsened  forcing him to seek medical attention. He reports discomfort in the chest area  but denies any chest pain or shortness of breath.  Mr. Peterson is a retired mechanical engineer who lives with his wife. He has a 25-pack-year smoking history and consumes alcohol socially. In regards to his dietary habits  he admits to a preference for fast food and a low-fruit and vegetable diet.   His past medical history reveals t that he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 12 years ago  and hypertension 7 years ago. He has been on Metformin 500mg twice daily for diabetes and Losartan 50mg daily for hypertension. Mr. Peterson is fairly compliant with his medications but admits that he has struggled with weight control and regular physical activity over the years.  His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 75  and his mother has a history of chronic atrial fibrillation. He has a brother and a sister  both living and with no significant health issues.  On examination  his blood pressure is 135/85mmHg  pulse is 110 beats/minute and irregular  respirations are 18 breaths/minute  and he is afebrile. Cardiovascular examination reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Given Mr. Peterson's symptomatology  past medical history  family history  and physical examination findings  there is a high suspicion for atrial fibrillation. Further diagnostic workup  including an EKG and possibly an echocardiogram will be carried out. Additionally  given his risk factors  full lipid profile and HbA1c level check will be done. The management plan will be based on these findings.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 72-year-old African-American male presenting to the clinic today with complaints of heart palpitations and recurrent episodes of fatigue and mild shortness of breath over the past few weeks. He articulates that his symptoms are not associated with exercise and mainly occur at rest. He denies any chest pain  radiating pain  or loss of consciousness. There is no history of recent travel  injury  or trauma.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a past medical history significant for well-controlled hypertension on Amlodipine 10mg daily and hyperlipidemia on Atorvastatin 20mg. He was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) 10 years back which is currently well controlled on Metformin 1000mg BID.   He has a 40 pack-year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago. He is a social drinker  limiting to one or two drinks per week and denies any drug use. He had undergone appendectomy 20 years back. There is a known family history of coronary artery disease  his father having an MI at the age of 68.  Medication Review:  On physical examination  irregular heart rhythms were noted on auscultation. Blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg  pulse 90bpm irregular  temperature 98.6 °F  respiratory rate is 18/min and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. He does not show any sign of heart failure such as swelling of ankles or abdominal distension. Lab reports revealed a Hemoglobin A1c of 6.8  Lipid profile within normal limits.  Based on the clinical history and physical examination findings  he is suspected of having atrial fibrillation and is scheduled for an EKG to confirm the diagnosis. His antihypertensive and antidiabetic treatment would be reviewed considering the new onset of atrial fibrillation symptoms. His lifestyle  including diet and physical activity  would also be reassessed to manage his current situation.   Socio-economic Background:  Mr. Smith is a retired engineer  living with his wife in a suburban neighborhood. He has two adult children who live in different states. His medical expenses are covered by his retirement health benefits and Medicare.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Alberto Ruiz  a 72-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the clinic with a complaint of intermittent rapid heartbeat and feeling light-headed over the past few weeks. He reports that these palpitations are sometimes associated with shortness of breath  weakness  and an overwhelming sense of fatigue. He explains these symptoms typically occur sporadically  but have seemed to increase in frequency and intensity recently.   Mr. Ruiz has a significant medical history that includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which  according to his report  he manages with medication  diet  and exercise. He also shares he is a former 20-year smoker but quit about 10 years ago. Mr. Ruiz also noted mild weight gain in recent months  with a change in exercise habits due to the ongoing pandemic situation. His mother had a stroke in her late 70s and his father had heart disease.  On examination  pulse is irregular and rapid  and blood pressure is slightly elevated (145/90 mm Hg). Electrocardiogram (ECG) confirms atrial fibrillation.   The patient denies any chest pain  fever  cough  or syncope. He lives with his wife  is retired  and admits to drinking socially  but only one or two drinks a week. The patient is urged to continue managing his diabetes and hypertension appropriately while a treatment plan for atrial fibrillation is developed.

Patient Presentation:  A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents with complaints of heart palpitations that started two days ago. He also complains of exertional dyspnea  fatigue  and occasional light-headedness. He denies any chest pain or discomfort  no syncope or near syncope. He denies recent illnesses  fevers  or other symptoms.   He has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia which are well-controlled with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin. He has no history of hospitalizations or surgeries. He also has a 40-pack year smoking history  but he quit 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally and denies any illicit drug use.  No family history of sudden cardiac death but his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 65. He is a retired engineer and lives with his wife.   On examination  his blood pressure is on the higher side (150/90 mmHg)  heart rate is irregular and fast  around 110 bpm. Auscultation reveals irregularly irregular heart rhythm.   Workup including an electrocardiogram confirms the suspicion of atrial fibrillation. Further management will be planned accordingly.   This presentation is consistent with literature which highlights that atrial fibrillation is common in the elderly population (>65 years)  often presents with palpitations and is associated with other cardiovascular diseases such as hypertension. Also  males and Caucasians are at a higher risk of developing atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation:  John Doe is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic with complaints of episodic palpitations  occasional shortness of breath  and mild fatigue for the past few weeks. He states the symptoms are intermittent and predominantly occur during physical exertion. He describes the palpitation as his heart 'racing' with no associated chest pain.   He has a past medical history significant for well-controlled hypertension for which he takes Lisinopril 20 mg daily. He also has high cholesterol  managed with Atorvastatin 40 mg nightly. He had been diagnosed with Type II diabetes mellitus 10 years ago  which is currently maintained with oral Metformin.   Mr. Doe is a non-smoker and quit drinking alcohol about 5 years ago. He retired from a bank job and has led a mainly sedentary lifestyle recently. His father died at 74 from a heart attack  and his mother had a history of ""irregular heart rhythm "" but he's unsure of the specifics.   Given his new symptoms  age  past medical history including hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes and family history of heart disease  atrial fibrillation is a potential differential diagnosis for his palpitations. Therefore  an EKG would be performed to confirm a potential diagnosis of atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Joseph Brown is a 68-year-old African American male who was referred to the cardiology clinic after his primary care physician noticed an irregular rhythm on his routine annual check-up. He reports intermittent episodes of palpitations  fatigue  and slight shortness of breath over the last couple of months. He says he also tends to feel a bit lightheaded lately  but he hasn't experienced any fainting spells  chest pain  or syncope.  Mr. Brown's past medical history is significant for managed hypertension  for which he has been on Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg once daily for the past 6 years. His cholesterol levels have also been well-controlled with Atorvastatin 10 mg once daily for the last three years. Mr. Brown had occasionally smoked tobacco for about 15 years but quit smoking 20 years ago.  Mr. Brown is a retired school principal who lives with his wife in the suburbs. He denies any recreational drug use  and he drinks alcohol socially but in moderation. His father had coronary artery disease and died due to a heart attack at the age of 75. His mother lived well into her 80s and had a history of hypertension.   Today  his vital signs show: blood pressure of 135/85 mmHg  heart rate varying between 75 and 105 bpm with an irregular rhythm  respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. Upon physical examination  there was no jugular venous distension observed  and his cardiovascular examination showed irregularly irregular pulse.  His ECG was consistent with atrial fibrillation (AF)  confirming the diagnosis. His moderate  controlled risk factors for stroke and heart failure make him a typical candidate for monitoring and possible anticoagulant therapy.  Given the patient's history  symptoms  and presentation  an explicit plan for the management of his newly diagnosed atrial fibrillation  including anticoagulation  rate control  and potential referral for rhythm control is needed.

Patient Information: Mr. John Thompson  72 years old  Caucasian male.  Chief Complaint: Heart palpitations and fatigue for the past few weeks.  History of Present Illness: Mr. Thompson reports that for the past few weeks he has been experiencing episodes of heart palpitations that last several minutes  accompanied by general fatigue and occasional lightheadedness. These symptoms have gradually become more frequent  worrying him enough to seek medical help. No reports of chest pain  breathlessness  edema  or syncope.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension  which is currently being managed with amlodipine. He was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 10 years ago and is currently managed with metformin. He is a former smoker  quit 15 years ago  and reports only social alcohol use.  Family History: His father had coronary artery disease and passed away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 68. His mother  aged 92  is in good health.  Review of Systems:  General: Reports of fatigue persist. Cardiovascular: No chest pain or edema  but palpitations persist. Pulmonary: No cough or shortness of breath. GI: Normal appetite  no nausea or vomiting. Regular bowel habits. Neurological: Had occasions of lightheadedness but no headache  seizures  or loss of consciousness.   Physical Examination:  General: Appears anxious but does not appear in distress. Cardiovascular: Irregularly irregular rhythm noted with tachycardia  no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Pulmonary: Clear to auscultation bilaterally  no wheezing  rales  or rhonchi.  GI: Abdomen soft  non-tender  with no organomegaly. Neurological: Alert  oriented x 3  cranial nerves II-XII grossly intact.  Impression: With the given history and physical examination findings  the leading diagnosis is atrial fibrillation. Will require further examination such as an EKG or echocardiogram to confirm. Considering his risk factors  there's also a concern for possible thromboembolic events like stroke. Anticoagulation therapy and rate or rhythm control will need to be discussed based on his overall risk profile  symptoms  and results of further investigation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 67-year-old African American male  currently retired. He previously worked as a construction worker. He presents today with complaints of recurrent palpitations  occasional light-headedness  and fatiguing easily over the past three weeks. He also reports a feeling of 'missing a heartbeat.' He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncope.   He has a past medical history of moderate hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has been on Losartan 50 mg daily and Metformin 500 mg twice daily for the past 10 years. He has no known drug allergies. He has been a smoker for the past 45 years with an estimated 30 pack-years but quit smoking 4 years ago. He denies any alcohol or illicit drug use.   On family history  his father had a stroke at the age of 70 and mother has a long-standing history of cardiac arrhythmias including atrial fibrillation. His only sibling  a brother  is healthy with no known heart diseases.   Upon physical examination  irregular heart rhythm was noted with a pulse rate fluctuating between 80 to 140 beats per minute. Other physical examination findings were within normal limits.   The patient's symptom of palpitation with an irregularly irregular pulse as felt on examination along with relevant family history leads to a provisional diagnosis of atrial fibrillation. Thorough diagnostic investigations including electrocardiogram and echocardiogram are ordered to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Robert Smith  a 67-year-old African American male  presents to the clinic complaining of palpitations  fatigue  and shortness of breath for the past week. Upon further questioning  he also admits to occasional light-headedness but denies any episodes of syncope.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension and diabetes mellitus type II  both managed with medications for the past 10 years. His medication list includes Metformin 500mg twice daily for diabetes and Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension.   He is a retired engineer  drinks alcohol socially  and has a 20 pack-year history of smoking  although he quit 15 years ago. There is a family history of heart disease; his father passed away following a myocardial infarction at the age of 72.  On examination  irregularly irregular pulse is noted. Blood pressure is 132/86 mmHg  pulse 88 and irregular  respirations 16  temperature 98.2 F. Cardiovascular exam reveals an irregular rhythm. No murmurs  rubs  or gallops are noted.   An EKG is performed in the office  which shows atrial fibrillation. No signs of ischemia were noted. The patient is informed and referred for further evaluation and treatment to a Cardiologist.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Davis is a 72-year-old African-American male  retired teacher who presents to the clinic with complaints of ongoing 'fluttering' sensation in his chest and increasing general fatigue over the past two weeks. Other symptoms include intermittent palpitations  shortness of breath and slight dizziness.  His past medical history is well documented and significant. He was diagnosed with hypertension 12 years ago and has been on medication (Lisinopril-Hydrochlorthiazide 20/12mg) since then. Additionally  he has a five-year history of diabetes mellitus type 2  which is being managed with Metformin (500mg BD). He has also been on a low-dose aspirin regimen for primary prevention of cardiovascular disease for the past 8 years.   Mr. Davis has a 30-year history of smoking one pack a day and admits to moderate alcohol intake. He denies recreational drugs. He maintains an active lifestyle  adheres to a Mediterranean diet  and goes out for 30-minute walks 5 days a week. Family history of cardiovascular disease is significant: his father died at the age of 69 due to a heart attack.  On examination  irregular pulse and rhythmic heart sounds were noted. Initial ECG is suggestive of atrial fibrillation.  Mr. Davis represents a fairly typical presentation for atrial fibrillation  with demographic information reflecting literature - being over the age of 65  having comorbidities such as hypertension and diabetes  and a history of long-term smoking. He could potentially benefit from treatment options like rhythm control strategies  anticoagulation  and modification of risk factors. His case underscores the importance of individualized approach in management of atrial fibrillation.

Patient Profile:  - Name: Mr. E - Age: 68 years old - Sex: Male - Race/ Ethnicity: Caucasian  - Occupation: Retired engineer  Presenting Complaint:   Patient presents with progressive palpitations for two weeks  a sensation of an irregular heartbeat  intermittent fatigue and light-headedness.   Medical History:  Mr. E was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago and has been managed with a regular dose of antihypertensive medications. He also has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus which has been controlled with Metformin for the past 10 years. He was previously a smoker but quit 15 years ago. The patient has a surgical history of appendectomy which took place 30 years ago. Family history reveals that his father had a stroke at 70 years old and his mother has coronary artery disease.   Lifestyle:  Patient admits being sedentary for the past 2 years  consuming a diet high in carbohydrates and fats  and indulging in daily moderate alcohol consumption.  Upon Examination:  Harvard Step Test revealed poor cardiovascular endurance. Irregular rhythms were noted in pulse palpation and auscultation  heart rate ranged from 85 to 115 beats per minute. Blood pressure was slightly elevated at 145/90 mmHg.   Investigations:  Consideration for ECG  echocardiogram  and blood tests including thyroid function test and complete blood count.   Given the patient's age  gender  ethnicity  and his past medical history of hypertension and diabetes  his presentation is consistent with a possible diagnosis of atrial fibrillation. An incidental finding of remaining sedentary and daily moderate alcohol consumption are contributing factors in his presentation.

Patient Presentation:  A 72-year-old African-American male presented to the cardiology outpatient clinic with a complaint of recurrent palpitations and intermittent episodes of breathlessness for the past 2 months. These symptoms are more pronounced when he is involved in physical activity. He also shared about occasional episodes of dizziness but denied any history of chest pain  syncope  or presyncope.  His past medical history revealed that he has been managing long term hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past 10 years and was prescribed Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  respectively. He has been non-compliant with his medication regimen  infrequently taking his prescribed medications. Family history indicated his father had a stroke at age 75.   He is a retired teacher  lives with his wife  a non-smoker but drinks alcohol socially. His Body Mass Index is 29  which is considered as ‘Overweight’  height is 5feet 10inches  and weight is 90 kg. He does not engage in regular physical activity due to his current symptoms and his diet is rich in sodium.  On examination  his heart rate was irregularly irregular with a rate of 110 beats per minute  blood pressure of 155/90 mmHg  respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 97% in room air. Chest auscultation revealed an irregular heart rhythm. The rest of the physical examination including the neurological examination was normal.  Given his age  symptomatology  and hypertension  atrial fibrillation is strongly suspected. Further evaluation and diagnostics will be planned to establish a diagnosis and initiate appropriate management accordingly.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Roy Jensen  a 75-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and intermittent lightheadedness over the past 4 days. He describes a sensation of rapidly erratic and 'pounding' heartbeats which are uncomfortable and sometimes associated with shortness of breath. There have been occasions where he has felt quite light-headed but has not fainted. No associated chest pain  nausea  or sweating reported.   Mr. Jensen has a past medical history significant for hypertension  for which he has been prescribed Lisinopril 10mg oral daily for the last 7 years. He has also been diagnosed with high cholesterol around the same time  and has been on Atorvastatin 20mg oral daily. He also has a history of type-2 diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years  managed with Metformin 850mg oral twice daily.   He quit smoking 20 years ago and consumes alcohol modestly. He has a family history of heart disease; his father had his first myocardial infarction at the age of 62.  On physical examination  his blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg  pulse irregularly irregular at 110 bpm  respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Precordial examination reveals irregularly irregular heart sounds with no murmurs.   The rest of the examination is unremarkable.
