There have been no recent changes or non-compliance to his medication regimen. He denies any tobacco  alcohol or illicit drug use. His father had a myocardial infarction at 68 and his brother has type II diabetes. His vitals on arrival are BP 160/100  pulse of 130bpm  respiratory rate of 20/min  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. On physical examination  his heart rate was irregularly irregular  without murmurs  rubs or gallops and his lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally without crackles or wheezes. He had no evidence of peripheral edema. He appeared uncomfortable and anxious.

A 68-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents to the clinic complaining of palpitations and occasional shortness of breath for the past week. On examination  his heart rate is irregularly irregular  and an EKG confirms a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation. The patient states that these symptoms have been interfering with his daily activities. He denies any chest pain  dizziness  or syncope. He has a family history of stroke and heart diseases. He is currently on Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension. The patient is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially. He is compliant with his medications and follows a balanced diet to control his diabetes. He is married  retired  and lives with his wife. They have a supportive community around them.

A 68-year-old African American male presents with palpitations and fatigue. He has a five-year history of hypertension  managed by lisinopril  and a one-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed by metformin. His father had a stroke at age 70 and his mother was also hypertensive. On examination  he has an irregularly irregular pulse of 112 bpm  a blood pressure of 149/85 mmHg  and other examinations are unremarkable. He denies chest pain  dyspnea  or syncope. EKG confirms atrial fibrillation. His blood glucose level is controlled well on his current regimen. He has no known drug allergies. He is a non-smoker  drinks alcohol socially  and is physically inactive with a sedentary lifestyle. His BMI is 28  indicating that he is overweight. The patient has never had a stroke or a transient ischemic attack  but has two risk factors for stroke: hypertension and diabetes.

A 68-year-old African American female patient with a previous history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with new-onset palpitations and shortness of breath for the past 3 days. She also reports experiencing light-headedness and mild fatigue. She denies any chest pain  syncope  or previous episodes of similar symptoms. She is adherent to her antihypertensive and diabetes medications. On exam  her blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg and pulse rate is irregular at 120 bpm. EKG confirms the diagnosis of atrial fibrillation. She has no known drug allergies or family history of cardiac diseases. She is a non-smoker and consumes moderate amount of alcohol. She is currently retired and lives with her husband.

A 72-year-old African American male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with shortness of breath  palpitations  and weakness. These symptoms have been progressively worsening over the last two weeks. He admits to occasional alcohol consumption and is currently on atorvastatin 20 mg daily and lisinopril 10 mg daily. He denies any chest pain  orthopnea  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  but does note a reduced tolerance to exercise lately. He has no prior history of cardiac arrhythmias or known structural heart disease. His father died of a stroke at an age of 75. On examination  his pulse is irregularly irregular  and he is slightly short of breath. Echocardiogram reveals left atrial enlargement and an ECG confirms atrial fibrillation.

A 67-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of chronic hypertension and diabetes presents with a newly detected irregular pulse during a routine physical examination. He reports a 4-week history of progressive fatigue  shortness of breath on exertion  and occasional palpitations. He denies chest pain  syncope  or presyncope. He mentions he has been struggling to manage his stress due to family issues. He is a non-smoker  drinks socially  and has no history of recreational drug use. His father has a history of stroke. His antihypertensive medications include hydrochlorothiazide and lisinopril. His blood pressure is marginally elevated today and he is noted to have an irregular heartbeat on auscultation. His body mass index (BMI) is 31 kg/m2  demonstrating obesity. Electrocardiogram (ECG) confirms the diagnosis of atrial fibrillation.

A 68-year-old African-American male with a significant medical history of Hypertension  Type 2 diabetes  and prior stroke presents to the emergency department with acute onset of palpitations  shortness of breath  and fatigue. Physical examination reveals irregularly rapid heartbeat. EKG confirms the diagnosis of atrial fibrillation. The patient denies any chest pain  dizziness  or fainting episodes. Blood glucose levels are slightly elevated and blood pressure readings are consistently high despite the currently prescribed anti-hypertensive regimen. He is currently on Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Aspirin for stroke prophylaxis. The patient is a retired teacher  lives with his wife  is a non-smoker  and drinks alcohol socially. There's a family history of heart disease with his father  who died at 70 due to heart failure.

A 75-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2 presents to the emergency department complaining of feeling irregular heartbeats or ""fluttering"" in his chest for the past 48 hours  accompanied by fatigue  dizziness  and shortness of breath. This is an acute exacerbation of his recurrent non-valvular atrial fibrillation. He has a known history of atrial fibrillation diagnosed 5 years ago and is on daily dose of aspirin and metoprolol. In the last 6 months  he has had two similar episodes which were managed with electrical cardioversion. There is no history of other cardiovascular disorders  thyroid disorders  or significant alcohol intake.

A 72-year-old African American female  retired English teacher  who has a medical history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2  presents to the clinic with a one-week history of palpitations  fatigue  and intermittent chest pain. She also reports occasional episodes of dizziness and shortness of breath occurring over the same duration. The patient's medications include metformin  lisinopril  and low dose aspirin. No known allergies. She quit smoking 10 years ago and denies any recent use of alcohol or recreational drugs. Her family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases with her father having passed away from myocardial infarction at the age of 67. On examination  her pulse is irregularly irregular and rapid  while other vital signs are normal. EKG reveals atrial fibrillation.

A 75-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents to the clinic complaining of irregular  rapid heartbeat episodes accompanied by a sensation of fluttering or ""thumping"" in his chest for the past few months. He also reports associated frequent fatigue and mild shortness of breath  particularly during physical activity. On some occasions  these symptoms were accompanied by mild dizziness and faintness but he denies any chest pain  severe breathlessness  sudden onset of paralysis  vision loss or slurred speech. He denies smoking  alcohol  or illicit drug use. Overall the patient's symptoms are suggestive of atrial fibrillation (AF)  a common heart rhythm disorder in the elderly population  particularly in those with a history of hypertension.

Patient Information: 71-year-old Caucasian male  Medical History: History of hypertension  heart disease with a myocardial infarction two years ago  and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus under metformin. Current smoker with a 20-pack-year history. No known allergies.   Presentation: Patient presents to the emergency department with an episode of palpitations that began about 6 hours ago. Associated symptoms include mild shortness of breath  lightheadedness  and a sense of nervousness. Denies chest pain  nausea  or loss of consciousness. Vital signs show tachycardia with an irregular rhythm. Initial EKG confirms atrial fibrillation.   Problem Representation: Elderly male with a significant cardiac history and risk factors such as smoking and Diabetes Mellitus  presenting with new onset atrial fibrillation  characterized by palpitations  shortness of breath  and lightheadedness.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents to the clinic complaining of intermittent palpitations  fatigue  and a recent episode of light-headedness. The patient's symptoms started about a week ago and have been worsening ever since. He is currently on Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension control and Atorvastatin 20mg nightly. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  syncope  or other significant symptoms. He has not had any recent surgeries  admits to drinking a glass of red wine on special occasions only  and has a 20-pack-year smoking history but quit about 15 years ago. Patient denies any history of stroke  blood clots  or anticoagulant use. On examination  the patient appears in no acute distress  but his pulse is irregularly irregular and rapid. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable apart from mild bilateral ankle edema. His ECG reveals atrial fibrillation.

Patient Profile: A 75-year-old African American male.  Relevant Medical History: Known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Patient quit smoking 5 years prior following a coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) surgery. Under medication for type II diabetes for the past 10 years.  Presenting Problem: Patient presents to the emergency department complaining of palpitations and general fatigue that have lasted for approximately 5-6 hours. Upon asking  patient reported living a sedentary lifestyle and a recent increase in alcohol consumption during the past month. No reported prior episodes of similar events.   Clinical Examination & Symptoms: Vital signs reveal a heart rate of 130 beats/min  blood pressure of 139/95 mmHg  oxygen saturation 93% on room air  and a body mass index of 27 kg/m2. On examination  patient appears confused and mildly distressed with rapid irregular heartbeat. Physical exam reveals an irregular rhythm  and no signs of congestive heart failure. EKG confirms atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response.   This presentation highlights the concern of new-onset atrial fibrillation in a 75-year-old African American male with multiple cardiovascular risk factors including hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type II diabetes  and prior coronary artery disease requiring CABG.

Problem Representation:  A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of essential hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with palpitations and episodic shortness of breath  ongoing for the past three weeks. The patient describes the palpitations as being irregular  fast  and without any associated chest pain. The episodes of dyspnea occur mostly during physical exertion and are frequently accompanied by episodes of fatigue. Additionally  there's decreased exercise tolerance  manifested as an inability to carry out moderate activities he could easily do a few weeks ago. He does not report any dizziness  syncope  or orthopnea. He denies alcohol  tobacco  or illicit substance abuse. His current medications include Metformin and Lisinopril. He is still active in his job as an engineer and lives with his wife. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases; his father had a myocardial infarction at 60  his mother is living with chronic heart failure. Physical examination reveals an irregularly irregular pulse with a rate of 130 bpm  elevated blood pressure of 147/92 mmHg. The remainder of the cardiovascular  pulmonary  and abdominal examination is normal. The patient's BMI is 27  indicating overweight status. The patient does not show signs of distress.

A 72-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of hypertension  stage III chronic kidney disease  and type 2 diabetes  presents with complaints of palpitations and shortness of breath for the past two weeks. He also mentions episodes of lightheadedness and fatigue that have progressively worsened. He denies chest pain  syncope  or recent sickness. He is currently taking metformin and lisinopril. The patient's father had a history of heart disease. On presentation  his blood pressure is 147/92 mmHg  heart rate irregular at 102 bpm  respiratory rate is 18  and he has an oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. On physical examination  the patient is alert and oriented  with irregular heart rhythms noted on cardiac auscultation. He has mild pitting edema in both lower extremities but no signs of acute distress. Initial lab findings show elevated B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) levels and EKG confirms atrial fibrillation.

A 72-year-old African American male presents with complaints of fatigue  episodes of lightheadedness  and palpitations. The patient reports these symptoms have been recurrent over the last six months but have considerably worsened over the last week. He denies any recent falls  syncope  or chest pain. He has a previous history of hypertension and type-2 diabetes mellitus  both are reasonably well-controlled with medications. The patient also has a 30 pack- year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. On physical examination  the patient has irregularly irregular heart rhythm and a normal blood pressure. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. His ECG confirms atrial fibrillation.

A 70-year-old African American male presents to the clinic complaining of palpitations and intermittent episodes of fatigue and light-headedness. Past medical history reveals hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2 that are managed with medication. He identifies as a non-smoker and does not drink alcohol. Family history reveals father with stroke at age 75. On further enquiry  the patient reports the palpitations are irregular and do not follow physical activities. Pulse measurement confirms irregularly irregular rhythm with a rate of about 110 bpm. Blood pressure is slightly elevated at 145/90. There are no signs of heart failure on physical exam. Initial EKG report identified atrial fibrillation.

A 71-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus type II presents with complaints of palpitations and shortness of breath for the past two weeks. His symptoms have progressively worsened  accompanied recently by episodes of lightheadedness. He denies chest pain or syncope. Additionally  he discloses that he is currently noncompliant with his antihypertensive medication due to financial reasons. His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease  with both his father and his older brother having been diagnosed with coronary artery disease before the age of 60. His physical examination reveals an irregularly irregular heartbeat  confirmed by an ECG as atrial fibrillation. Further diagnostic workup and cardioversion  and medication compliance review is warranted to manage his condition.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents with persistent atrial fibrillation. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. He reports episodes of rapid and irregular heartbeat  which he states are usually anosymptomatic  but recently have been associated with shortness of breath and fatigue. He also indicates feeling light-headed and has had one recent near-syncopal episode while sitting. He has a past medical history significant for type II diabetes mellitus and controlled hypertension. He denies any chest pain  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea or lower extremity swelling. The patient’s father had a similar heart condition and his mother has a history of stroke. The patient is currently taking metformin for diabetes  as well as a daily aspirin and lisinopril for hypertension.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male patient with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents with complaints of palpitations and fatigue over the past week. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncope. He has had episodes of dizziness. On physical examination  he has irregularly irregular pulse rate. His BP is 140/85 mmHg and BMI is 28. His medication list includes Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally. The preliminary diagnosis is Atrial Fibrillation.

A 70-year-old Asian male  with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus  presents at the clinic with ongoing palpitations  mild shortness of breath  and fatigue progressing over the last two weeks. He denies chest pain  orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. His home medications include metformin and losartan. His BP on presentation is 150/90 mmHg  pulse is irregularly irregular  and other physical examination findings are unremarkable. An immediate ECG shows atrial fibrillation. There is no history of stroke or bleeding disorders. The patient reports no use of tobacco or alcohol and leads a sedentary lifestyle. His father had a history of stroke in his late 70s.

A 72-year-old African-American male presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and occasional breathlessness for the last couple of days. He reports a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which have been managed with medications for the past 10 years. He is a non-smoker and denies any alcohol or illicit drug use. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease  with both parents dying of heart-related conditions. On presentation  he appears anxious but is not in acute distress. Vital signs are within normal limits except for an irregularly irregular rapid heart rate. On physical examination  he has irregularly irregular pulses and his cardiovascular examination reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. A 12-lead EKG confirms atrial fibrillation.

A 69-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia presents with palpitations and fatigue. These symptoms have been progressively increasing over the last two weeks. He describes the palpitations as being irregular and rapid  sometimes causing dizziness. He denies recent fever  chest pain  or dyspnea. Physical examination reveals an irregularly irregular pulse rate of 110 bpm and blood pressure of 145/92 mmHg. These findings raise suspicion of atrial fibrillation.

A 70-year-old African-American male presents with palpitations and breathlessness for the past week. He has a significant past medical history of well-controlled hypertension and early-stage chronic kidney disease  controlled with Lisinopril. He is a former smoker who quit smoking ten years ago  and has a reported alcohol consumption of approximately 12 units per week. He is currently overweight with a BMI of 29. Physical examination reveals tachycardia with irregularly irregular pulse. The patient is alert but appears visibly distressed. On auscultation  his heart sounds scattered with occasional extrasystoles. An EKG confirms the presence of atrial fibrillation with a heart rate of 130 beats per minute.

Patient Profile: A 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired manual laborer.   Medical History: Patient has a known history of essential hypertension managed with prescription medication (ACE inhibitors)  and moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) secondary to a 40-year smoking history  now ceased for ten years. He reports a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with both parents having experienced cardiac events in their late 60s.   Relevant Symptoms on Presentation: The patient presents complaining of palpitations  fatigue  reduced exercise tolerance and intermittent light headedness over the past several weeks. He denies any chest pain or shortness of breath. Upon physical examination  irregular heart rhythms were noted  and an ECG confirmed atrial fibrillation. Blood pressure reading showed mild hypertension. Complete blood count  thyroid function tests  and renal function tests were ordered to determine underlying cause.   In summary  this is a 72-year-old male with a history of hypertension and COPD presenting with new onset atrial fibrillation. Further evaluation is required to identify possible triggers for the atrial fibrillation and to manage his symptoms and risk factors. Measures to prevent stroke  a common complication of atrial fibrillation  should also be considered.

Patient Profile: A 70-year-old Caucasian male  Medical History: A diagnosis of hypertension 10 years ago  currently managed with medication. The patient also has a history of type II diabetes  diagnosed 5 years ago. Family history of cardiovascular diseases. Non-smoker and moderate alcohol consumer.  Presenting Problem: The patient reports experiencing occasional periods of rapid  irregular heartbeats  palpitations  weakness and dizziness over a couple of months. These episodes last from a few minutes to a few hours. The patient also has experienced unexplained shortness of breath  especially after physical exertion  and occasional light-headedness. Recently  these symptoms have increased in frequency. The patient denies chest pain  nausea or fainting spells.  These symptoms suggest the presence of atrial fibrillation. Further diagnostic tests would need to be conducted for confirmation and to rule out other conditions.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents in the ER with palpitations and shortness of breath that started two days ago. He has a medical history of hypertension  for which he takes Lisinopril 10mg daily  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed by Metformin 1g twice daily. He's a former smoker and quit smoking 10 years ago. On physical examination  he had an irregularly irregular heartbeat and an elevated resting heart rate of 110 bpm. His blood pressure was 145/92 mmHg. The patient also expressed feelings of general fatigue and occasional dizziness. Lab tests were ordered to look for any signs of heart damage  and an EKG confirmed the diagnosis of atrial fibrillation. He is not currently on any anticoagulant therapy.

A 74-year-old Caucasian male patient presents with complaints of a rapid  irregular heart rate and mild shortness of breath for the last 2 days. He reports a chronic history of hypertension controlled with lisinopril and type 2 diabetes managed with metformin. His other medical history includes a previous stroke 3 years ago. Family history reveals a father who had a stroke and a brother with atrial fibrillation. He does not smoke or consume alcohol. On examination  he has an irregular pulse at a rate of approximately 120 beat/min  blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg  and respiratory rate is 20 cycles/min. An EKG confirms atrial fibrillation.

Mr. J is a 75-year-old Caucasian male who presents with feelings of heart palpitations  fatigue  dizziness  and shortness of breath. He has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus and is on a regimen of metformin  lisinopril  and Lipitor. His mother had a stroke at the age of 68. He denies smoking  excessive alcohol consumption  and illicit drug use. His blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg  pulse irregularly irregular at 100 bpm  BMI measured at 30. He has no signs of acute distress. His lungs are clear upon auscultation. EKG reveals atrial fibrillation.

Patient Profile: A 72-year-old African American male  Medical history: Reported history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both managed with medication for the past ten years. Prior stroke within the last five years. No history of heart failure or lung disease. Patient is a former smoker  reported quitting 15 years ago.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents to the hospital reporting recent episodes of palpitations  fatigue  and shortness of breath  especially during physical activity. He also has noted intermittent dizziness. He denies any chest pain  significant weight gain  or recent illness.  Relevant signs on physical examination include irregularly irregular heart rhythm consistent with atrial fibrillation on auscultation. Blood pressure under control. A neurological exam shows no residual signs from prior stroke. Rest of the examination is unremarkable. Initial EKG confirms atrial fibrillation.   In summary  this is a 72-year-old African American male with a known history of hypertension  diabetes  and prior cerebrovascular accident presenting with new-onset atrial fibrillation manifested as palpitations  fatigue  and shortness of breath.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the clinic complaining of palpitations and shortness of breath for the past 2 weeks. The patient describes the palpitations as irregular and mentions experiencing episodes of light-headedness. He is currently on medication for his hypertension and diabetes. He denies chest pain  nausea  or any recent changes in his weight. Physical examination reveals an irregularly rhythical cardiac rhythym. His vital signs are as follows: Blood Pressure 145/85 mmHg  Heart Rate 130 beats/minute  Respiratory Rate 18 breaths/minute  Oxygen Saturation 96% on room air. Hemoglobin A1c is 7.1%. The electrocardiogram (EKG) confirms atrial fibrillation.

A 75-year-old African-American male patient presents with complaints of palpitations  periodic shortness of breath and fatigue for the past several weeks. The patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension  type II diabetes  and previous diagnosis of ischemic heart disease. He currently takes metformin for diabetes and amlodipine for his hypertension. He denies chest pain  syncope  or dizziness. On physical examination  the patient appeared generally well but anxious. Examination of cardiovascular system reveals irregular heart rhythm without any cardiac murmurs or added sounds. There is no leg swelling  and chest auscultation is unremarkable. Electrocardiogram (ECG) confirms the diagnosis of atrial fibrillation.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertensive heart disease and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with a one-day history of fatigue  lightheadedness  and palpitations. Patient reports episodes of dyspnea upon exertion and describes his symptoms as ""heart racing"". Family history is positive for stroke in multiple first degree relatives. He previously had normal sinus rhythm on monitoring  takes Metformin for diabetes  and Losartan for hypertension. He denies any chest pain  syncope  or recent illnesses. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history but quit 10 years ago. On examination  he is hemodynamically stable but has an irregularly irregular pulse. Further investigation reports a rapid ventricular rate.

A 72-year-old African American male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with palpitations and mild shortness of breath. He states these symptoms have been episodic over the last several days. He expresses feeling ""irregular heartbeats"" which has caused him concern. He denies any chest pain  fatigue  or dizziness. He has been compliant with his antihypertensive and lipid-lowering medication. His vitals on presentation include a blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg  pulse rate of 130 beats per minute (irregular)  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Upon physical examination  there is irregular rhythm noticed on cardiac auscultation along with general appearance of anxiety but no acute distress. There is no lower extremity edema or signs of congestive heart failure. Quick EKG at the clinic confirms atrial fibrillation. His laboratory studies  including thyroid function tests and basic metabolic panel  are within normal limits. He has no known family history of atrial fibrillation or heart diseases. He is a retired engineer  exercises on a regular basis  and follows a balanced diet. He doesn't drink alcohol or smoke.

A 68-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus type-2  and coronary artery disease  presents with atrial fibrillation. He reports a one-week history of palpitations  episodes of lightheadedness  and shortness of breath  especially on exertion.  On physical examination  he has an irregularly irregular pulse  and blood pressure is slightly elevated. Chest examination reveals no abnormal breath sounds and cardiovascular exam reveals an irregular rhythm with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. EKG confirms atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response.   Based on the CHA2DS2-VASc score (which takes into account Congestive heart failure  Hypertension  Age ≥75 [doubled]  Diabetes  Stroke [doubled]–Vascular disease  Age 65–74 and Sex category [female])  this patient falls under moderate risk of stroke and need further workup and management for his atrial fibrillation. His blood glucose levels are mildly elevated  suggesting suboptimal glycemic control  and his hypertension is not well-controlled judging on his current BP readings.

Patient: 68 y/o white male   Problem Representation: Mr. Smith  with a significant past medical history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus type II  and prior myocardial infarction four years ago  presents with a new onset intermittent fast heartbeat over the past week. Additional symptoms include fatigue and mild dyspnea on exertion that were initially attributed to his age and diabetes but have progressively worsened. He denies any chest pain  syncope or pre-syncope. He also has a history of non-compliance with medications  including beta-blockers  for his blood pressure and heart disease due to reported side effects. While at a routine follow-up appointment with his PCP  an irregular heart rhythm was detected on physical examination. An EKG was performed and showed atrial fibrillation. His blood pressure at presentation is well-controlled and he is in no apparent distress.

A 71-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents to the clinic with palpitations  fatigue  and intermittent episodes of light-headedness for the last two months. The patient has a history of smoking but quit 15 years ago. He admits to drinking alcohol occasionally. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncope. His family history is significant for stroke in his father. Physical examination reveals an irregularly irregular pulse. Rest of the examination including lung  cardiac and neurologic exam is non-significant. EKG confirms atrial fibrillation. The patient is on metformin for his diabetes and losartan for hypertension. His recent lab results show well-controlled blood glucose and blood pressure. Apart from sporadic reports of these symptoms  the patient's overall health before this point has been good.

A 65-year-old African-American male patient presents with complaints of an irregular heartbeat and lightheadedness persisting for the last two weeks. He has a notable medical history of Type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  controlled with regular medication. He is a non-smoker and moderate drinker.  Clinical examination revealed a rapid and irregular heartbeat of around 130 beats per minute  palpitations confirmed by a pulse check. He also reported fleeting episodes of chest discomfort  fatigue  and shortness of breath on moderate physical exertion. The patient has been relatively asymptomatic until now. Vital signs on presentation: blood pressure: 145/85 mmHg; pulse: irregular at 130 beats/min; respiratory rate: 16 breaths/min; temperature: 37.2 °C (98.9 °F); oxygen saturation: 96% on room air.  An Electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed which confirmed atrial fibrillation. Additional blood workup revealed elevated blood glucose levels and slightly elevated lipid profile  controlled on current treatment. There's no family history of atrial fibrillation or other form of heart disease. The patient is currently on Metformin for Diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia. His medications have been updated with no recent changes  the compliance is good and there are no known drug allergies.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male  with a known medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  presents to the out-patient clinic with complaints of palpitations and occasional shortness of breath over the past two weeks. His symptoms have been intermittent but became more frequent over the past three days. He denies any history of chest pain  pre-syncope  syncope  or previous history of heart failure. There is no known family history of atrial fibrillation or other arrhythmias. He stopped smoking ten years ago and has a minimal alcohol intake. He is currently taking metformin for his diabetes and Losartan for hypertension. On examination  a pulse palpation reveals an irregular rhythm. An electrocardiogram (ECG) confirms a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation.

Patient Profile: A 71-year-old African-American female  Presenting Problem: Patient reports ongoing palpitations and a feeling of general fatigue over the last couple of weeks.  Medical History: The patient has a comprehensive medical history  including type 2 diabetes and hypertension  both of which are well-managed with medications (Metformin and Lisinopril  respectively). Patient has a BMI of 29.1 indicating overweight condition. She’s a non-smoker and has no known allergies. There’s no family history of cardiac diseases.  Symptoms on Presentation: Patient is complaining of general fatigue  shortness of breath  occasional dizziness  and irregular and rapid heartbeat. She denies any chest pain  nausea  fainting spells  anxiety  or worsening of symptoms with physical exertion. Physical examination revealed an irregular pulse rate averaging to 110 beats per minute. Patient also appears generally tired.  Based on the initial assessment  ongoing symptoms  and patient’s age and background  atrial fibrillation is suspected. Further diagnostic investigations like an EKG  echocardiogram  blood tests   Will be planned to confirm the diagnosis and formulate an appropriate management plan.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with palpitations and mild shortness of breath. On examination  he is hemodynamically stable but has an irregularly irregular pulse. An electrocardiogram reveals atrial fibrillation. He recalls similar episodes in the past year but dismissed them as stress-related. His father had a history of stroke. He is a former smoker and consumes alcohol socially. He doesn't follow any specific diet and records minimal physical activity. He is worried about the implications of atrial fibrillation  given his father's history of stroke.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with a recent onset of palpitations  feeling of rapid heartbeat  lightheadedness  and breathlessness. He also mentions occasional episodes of chest discomfort that resolve on their own. His blood pressure is stable on presentation but he has an irregular pulse. Auscultation reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm suggestive of atrial fibrillation. He denies any recent illnesses  alcohol use  or caffeine consumption. His regular medications include amlodipine for hypertension and atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia. He has no history of heart failure  stroke  or blood clots. He has a 20-pack year smoking history but quit 10 years ago. He has no known drug allergies. Family history includes a father who suffered a stroke at the age of 75  but no history of atrial fibrillation or other heart diseases.

An 80-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of poorly controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus presented for a routine follow-up appointment  during which he disclosed experiencing sporadic episodes of lightheadedness  palpitations  and shortness of breath over the last several weeks. An on-spot EKG revealed findings consistent with atrial fibrillation. The patient also complained about intermittent fatigue and generalized weakness during his regular activities. He denied any episodes of chest pain  syncope  or stroke-like symptoms. He has no history of heart failure or valve disorders. Family history includes a brother with atrial fibrillation. He is a former smoker with a 30-pack year smoking history but quit smoking five years ago. Current medications include metformin for diabetes and hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male  with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and obstructive sleep apnea  presents with complaints of palpitations  unusual fatigue following normal routine activities  and a chronic intermittent feeling of breathlessness for the past 4 weeks. These symptoms are more severe during evenings and physical exertion. He also reports a recent unintentional weight loss of about 10 lbs over the past 2 months. He denies smoking  drug use  or alcohol consumption. He is on Lisinopril for hypertension and Metformin for diabetes  but not on any anticoagulation. His family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases. On examination  he is found to be tachycardic with irregular heart rhythm and mild peripheral edema. ECG reveals a rapid and irregular heart rhythm indicative of atrial fibrillation. His BP is 145/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 110 bpm  irregular  and SpO2 is 95% on room air.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents to the primary care clinic with complaints of fatigue  palpitations  and periodic shortness of breath over the last two weeks. He notes that his symptoms seem to be particularly present during physical activity. There is no history of syncope  chest pain  or symptoms of heart failure. He denied any recent weight loss  chest pain  or signs of infection. The patient has no family history of premature heart disease. He is a former smoker and quit 10 years ago but continues to take moderate amounts of alcohol. His medications include hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. His blood pressure on initial evaluation is 155/85 mmHg  pulse rate irregularly irregular at 92 beats/min  and his oxygen saturation is 96% while breathing ambient air. EKG findings are compatible with atrial fibrillation.

A 67-year-old African-American male with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with complaints of fatigue  shortness of breath  and occasional palpitations lasting for the past one week. He has noticed that his heart rate is irregular and fast  which typically lasts several minutes to an hour. These episodes are not precipitated by exertion and may occur at rest. He also reports some vague  intermittent chest discomfort  although not typical anginal chest pain. His medications include Lisinopril and Metformin. He has no known allergies. He doesn't smoke but admits to moderate alcohol consumption on the weekends. He denies any symptoms of fever  recent travel  or recent illness. His blood pressure is 150/92 mm/Hg  pulse is 112 beats/min  irregularly irregular  and respiratory rate is 18 breaths/min. On examination  he has an irregularly irregular rhythm. Labs show HbA1c of 7.8%. EKG shows atrial fibrillation.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male presents with newly diagnosed nonvalvular atrial fibrillation. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He denies any familial history of heart diseases. The patient reports feeling intermittent heart palpitations  lightheadedness  and fatigue for the past 2 weeks. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  and syncope. He has no history of smoking and denies any illicit drug or alcohol abuse. The patient's medications include Lisinopril for hypertension and Metformin for diabetes. Moreover  he describes moderate physical activity  with no recent changes in lifestyle or diet. His blood pressure on presentation is 142/90 mmHg  and his pulse is irregularly irregular  consistent with atrial fibrillation. Other examination findings are unremarkable.

Patient Profile: A 68-year-old Hispanic male presents to the emergency department.  Medical History: Patient has a documented history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Systemic review reveals a past medical intervention for a myocardial infarction 3 years ago. Patient recovery was reportedly uncomplicated. No known allergies. The patient adheres to a prescribed medication regimen including Metformin  Lisinopril  and Simvastatin.  Presenting Complaint and Symptoms: The patient complains of sudden onset palpitations and dizziness  which have persisted for the past several hours. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncope. On physical examination  his pulse is irregularly irregular and rapid. Electrocardiogram confirms atrial fibrillation.  Social History: The patient is a retired schoolteacher  non-smoker with moderate alcohol use. Life at home is reportedly stress-free  with a supportive wife of 40 years. He is partially sedentary since retirement but engages in a 30-minute walk daily.  Family History: There is a positive family history of cardiovascular diseases. His father had ischemic stroke at 70  and his older brother had a myocardial infarction at 62.  Representations: This is a 68-year-old Hispanic male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and T2DM  who presents with a several-hour history of palpitations and dizziness  with EKG findings confirming atrial fibrillation. Given patient's cardiovascular risk factors and family history  there is a need for further evaluation and treatment adjustment.

A 72-year-old African American woman presents to the clinic with a recent history of fatigue  palpitations  and intermittent shortness of breath. Past medical history includes controlled hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and is significant for a prior transient ischemic attack (TIA) 5 years previously. There is no known history of cardiac disease. Current medications include metformin  lisinopril  and aspirin. On physical examination  she has an irregularly irregular pulse  and her blood pressure is 140/90mm Hg. Initial 12-lead EKG shows atrial fibrillation. The patient confirms no prior diagnosis or suspicion of atrial fibrillation from any healthcare provider.

A 75-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and chronic kidney disease  presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations  fatigue  and mild shortness of breath for two days. He reports that the palpitations are irregular and fast  and are associated with episodes of dizziness. He further adds that these symptoms are not exertional. He denies chest pain  syncope  or any recent infections or fever. He is a non-smoker and rarely consumes alcohol. On physical examination  he has an irregularly irregular heart rhythm  a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  and a resting heart rate of 120 bpm. The rest of the physical exam including lung and abdomen is unremarkable. His current medications include metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. EKG confirms atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular rate.

Problem Representation:  An 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and occasional shortness of breath. His symptoms started about four hours prior to arrival and have been incessant since onset. He also mentions feeling lightheaded and notice increasing fatigue. He does not report any chest pain  fever  cough  or recent illnesses. He reports a previous episode of similar symptoms a few months ago  which had resolved on their own after a couple of hours. He denies any history of smoking or illicit drug use. His medications include amlodipine and atorvastatin. He has no known drug allergies. On examination  he appears mildly anxious. His vital signs are recorded with a blood pressure of 145/85 mmHg  heart rate of 135 beats per minute irregularly irregular  with respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. Physical examination is remarkable for irregular pulse. An ECG confirms the presence of atrial fibrillation.   Note: Atrial fibrillation is known to have a higher incidence with increasing age  in males  and in Caucasian populations. Additionally  risk factors include a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Complaints of palpitations  shortness of breath  and lightheadedness are common symptoms of atrial fibrillation.

A 68-year-old Hispanic female patient with a medical history significant for hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2  and obesity presents to the outpatient clinic with new onset of palpitations  fatigue  and light-headedness for the past two days. She denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncope. Her hypertension and diabetes have been well controlled with medication. She reports no prior episodes of similar symptoms and no known history of heart disease in her family. The patient does not smoke and consumes alcohol rarely. On further questioning  the patient reports she has been less compliant with her salt restriction diet indicated for hypertension management. Physical examination shows an irregularly irregular heart rhythm consistent with atrial fibrillation confirmed by EKG. There is no evidence of any acute respiratory distress  and lung fields are clear to auscultation. There are no signs of pedal edema  suggesting no overt heart failure. Laboratory studies show no signs of anemia or thyroid disease. This visit aims to evaluate the severity and potential causes of her atrial fibrillation  and to initiate necessary medical treatment.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the clinic with complaints of recent onset palpitations. He describes these palpitations as rapid  irregular  ""fluttering"" sensations in his chest and they seem to occur almost constantly over the past few days. The patient also reports episodes of feeling lightheaded and fatigued  more than usual. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncope. However  he notes that these symptoms have limited his ability to do his routine exercise  such as walking his dog in the morning. On examination  his pulse is noted to be irregularly irregular. The patient's height is 5'9'' and he weighs around 180 lbs; BMI computes to be 26.6 kg/m2  indicating that he is overweight. His blood pressure reading is 145/90 mmHg.

A 72-year-old African-American man with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents to the clinic complaining of palpitations and fatigue for the past week. He reports no chest pain  shortness of breath  lightheadedness  or syncope. His blood pressure at the clinic is 138/72 mmHg  heart rate irregular at 115 bpm  and he exhibits signs of mild dehydration. An ECG confirms atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. A review of his medical records shows no previous history of any heart disease. Current medications include metformin  amlodipine  and lisinopril.

A 72-year-old African American male  former smoker  presents to the clinic with complaints of palpitations and shortness of breath for the last two weeks. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes. He reports having noticed occasional rapid heartbeat while resting. He also states that he has been feeling unusually fatigued and having intermittent episodes of dizziness. The patient denies chest pain  orthopnea  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He has no family history of atrial fibrillation but his father had a stroke in his late 70s. His physical exam revealed an irregularly irregular pulse. Electrocardiogram confirms atrial fibrillation. Further diagnostic tests are necessary to identify potential causes and complications. His symptoms  associated medical conditions and EKG findings are suggestive of chronic atrial fibrillation.

A 68 year-old Caucasian male  with a medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  presents with symptoms of palpitations and intermittent shortness of breath. His symptoms have been progressively worsening over the past 2 weeks. Patient denies any chest pain  fainting  or dizziness. Previous EKGs show normal sinus rhythm. His medications include metformin  lisinopril  and low-dose aspirin. He has a 40-year smoking history but quit 5 years ago. He does not consume alcohol. He has no known drug allergies. His father had a history of atrial fibrillation and his mother has a history of stroke. On examination  his blood pressure is 145/90  pulse is irregular and the rate is 105 bpm  respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. His lungs are clear to auscultation and there is no peripheral edema. His EKG shows irregularly irregular rhythm  absence of consistent P waves and a variable ventricular response  suggestive of atrial fibrillation.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male patient with a medical history of hypertension and previous history of stroke presents with symptoms of palpitations  shortness of breath  and fatigue. The patient admits his symptoms have been gradually intensifying over the last few weeks. He also mentions his mother had a history of cardiac problems  but he is uncertain about the specifics. The patient does not have any known allergies but takes daily medication for hypertension. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol only occasionally. He also reports difficulties in carrying out daily activities due to generalized weakness. The patient also presents moderate obesity with a BMI of 32  further complicating his condition. On initial inspection  the patient appears tired and anxious. His pulse is irregular and fast; The ECG confirms the atrial fibrillation.

A 73-year-old African-American male presents to the office with complaints of palpitations and occasional shortness of breath for the last 2 weeks. He reports a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He is currently on Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. There is no history of previous cardiac events. His father had a myocardial infarction in his seventies. Examination reveals an irregularly irregular pulse rate of 108 beats per minute. Blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg. Auscultation of the heart confirms irregular rhythm  but there is no murmur. Lung fields are clear. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. Electrocardiography confirms atrial fibrillation.

A 67-year-old Hispanic male with a known medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and hyperlipidemia  presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and shortness of breath for the past few days. He also reports fatigue  occasional lightheadedness  and decreased exercise tolerance. On examination  his heart rate is irregular and rapid. An EKG reveals atrial fibrillation. He denies any pain  loss of consciousness  or other neurological symptoms. He has been adherent to his antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications  with no known drug allergies. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. His father had a history of stroke. This is the first episode of these symptoms.

An 80-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  with a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  presents to his primary care physician complaining of palpitations and shortness of breath  particularly worse with exercise  over the last two weeks. His hypertension is poorly controlled on current medication regimen; his most recent blood pressure reading was 156/89. The patient’s diabetes is reasonably controlled with a most recent HbA1c of 6.8%. He also reports fatigue and occasional dizziness. He has no known drug allergies  denies any recent weight loss or gain  changes in appetite  or gastrointestinal symptoms. On examination  an irregularly irregular pulse was noted. An EKG was performed which revealed atrial fibrillation. Physical exam was normal apart from the irregular pulse and blood pressure 160/90. Labs including a complete blood count  comprehensive metabolic panel  thyroid stimulating hormone  troponin  and BNP revealed no abnormalities. The patient is scheduled for a follow-up visit to discuss management options for his newly diagnosed atrial fibrillation.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents to the clinic with complaints of irregular and rapid heartbeats  persistent fatigue  and occasional bouts of shortness of breath over the past two weeks. He also reports developing reduced exercise tolerance and some light-headedness. There is no associated chest pain  nausea  or loss of consciousness. He has a family history of heart disease and his father suffered a stroke at the age of 80. He has been a 10 pack-years smoker but quit 15 years ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally and denies any illicit drug use. On examination  his pulse is irregularly irregular  and he has an elevated blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg. His echocardiogram reveals atrial fibrillation.

A 75-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for chronic hypertension  Type 2 diabetes mellitus  and moderate alcohol use presents at the out-patient clinic complaining of an overt intermittent rapid heartbeat and occasional shortness of breath for the past two weeks. He also mentions feeling increasingly fatigued and lightheaded on bending. He explains these symptoms exacerbate while he performs his daily moderate-intensity workout. He has no history of smoking or drug usage. His family history is unremarkable  with no known history of cardiac diseases. He is currently on Losartan for his hypertension and Metformin for his diabetes. Medication compliance is adequate. He denies chest pain  palpitations  syncope  or recent infection. No changes in medication or over-the-counter supplements. He lives alone and manages his daily activities independently. His body mass index (BMI) is within the normal range. Vital signs include blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  heart rate variable at 80-150 beats per minute  respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute  temperature 98.6F  and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. Physical examination is remarkable for an irregularly irregular pulse. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examination are unremarkable.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male presents with atrial fibrillation. Patient has a known medical history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2  and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. He is currently on metoprolol succinate  lisinopril  and metformin respectively for his conditions. Patient is a former smoker who quit 5 years ago  consumes moderate amounts of alcohol  and does not have known drug allergy. Patient's family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases with his father having had a heart attack at the age of 70 and a sister diagnosed with atrial fibrillation.   On presentation  patient complains of palpitations  shortness of breath  and fatigue that started last night and persisted. Physical exam reveals an irregularly irregular pulse rate of 130 beats per minute  blood pressure of 150/80 mmHg  and slight oedema in legs. All other physical examination findings including chest auscultation were unremarkable. The patient denies any chest pain  light-headedness  loss of consciousness  or neurological deficits. He is alert and oriented with intact cognitive function. Electrocardiogram confirms atrial fibrillation.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with complaint of palpitations  irregular heart rhythms  and fatigue for about 1 week. The patient also reports shortness of breath on exertion and mild dizziness. He is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago  and has a moderate alcohol intake. His medications include lisinopril for hypertension and metformin for diabetes. Physical examinations reveal an irregularly irregular rhythm  without any audible murmur. There's no evident pedal edema or jugular venous distention. Family history is notable for a father with a stroke at age 70. The patient's recent blood test shows good glycemic control with a HbA1c of 6.5%.

A 75-year-old Caucasian male  retired teacher  with a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  presents with new-onset palpitations and shortness of breath for the past one day. He describes the palpitations as rapid and irregular  which are associated with a feeling of fatigue and mild chest tightness. He denies any syncope  dizziness or orthopnea. He has a long-standing history of smoking (30 pack-years)  but quit about 15 years ago. He drinks socially and denies any illicit drug use. He is compliant with his antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications. On examination  his pulse is irregularly irregular  and he is mildly tachypneic. There are no other significant abnormal physical findings. His blood pressure and blood glucose levels are well-controlled.

A 63-year-old African American woman with a previous medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents complaints of recent ongoing palpitations and occasional shortness of breath. She notes these symptoms occur particularly during the evening and are often accompanied by light-headedness and fatigue. She has never experienced these symptoms before  apart from mild fatigue  which she attributed to her age and diabetes. Her hypertension has been well-controlled with medication and her diabetes is being managed with oral hypoglycemics. She follows a routine diet  and her lifestyle is moderately active. Her paternal grandfather had a history of ""heart problems.""   Physical examination reveals an irregularly irregular pulse and a normal S1 and S2 with no murmurs. EKG confirms atrial fibrillation. Her BP is 152/90 mmHg  which is relatively higher than her usual readings  and her BMI is 29  falling slightly under the category of obesity. There’s no evident leg swelling or other signs of heart failure. There's no evidence of hyperthyroidism  and lab results are otherwise normal. She's been non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally.   The problem representation of this patient could be: ""A 63-year-old African American woman with hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents with new-onset palpitations  occasional dyspnea  and fatigue  found to be in atrial fibrillation  which is likely to be precipitated by uncontrolled hypertension or other unknown factors.""

A 71-year-old Caucasian male presents with complaints of palpitations  fatigue and mild dyspnea over the past two weeks. He reports a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia controlled with medications. He has a 10-years history of smoking but quit five years ago.   On examination  his blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg  pulse irregularly irregular at 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 18 bpm  and oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. Cardiovascular examination reveals irregular rhythm with no murmurs  rubs or gallops. The remainder of his physical exam is unremarkable. Family history reveals a father with heart disease and a mother with stroke. His medications include amlodipine and atorvastatin.   His EKG exhibits atrial fibrillation with a controlled ventricular response. Lab findings indicate that his lipid panel is within the desired range  renal and hepatic function are normal  and TSH is normal. No previous EKGs or echocardiograms are available for comparison.  This is a high-risk elderly male patient with known cardiovascular risk factors and new onset atrial fibrillation presenting with palpitations  fatigue and dyspnea. The patient needs workup to determine the cause of his atrial fibrillation and appropriate treatment  as well as modification of his cardiovascular risk factors to reduce the risk of stroke which is commonly associated with uncontrolled atrial fibrillation.

A 70-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus presents with new onset palpitations and intermittent shortness of breath for 2 weeks. He reports associated episodes of dizziness and occasionally feeling a ""racing heart"" mainly in the evenings. He denies chest pain  nausea  vomiting  or loss of consciousness. There are no precipitating factors or alleviating factors for these symptoms. His medications include Lisinopril and Metformin. He has no known drug allergies. He denies tobacco  alcohol  or illicit drug use. Upon physical examination  he was tachycardic with an irregularly irregular rhythm  approximate rate in the 110's  blood pressure stable. The rest of the physical exam including lung and ankle examination was unremarkable.

Patient is a 72-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and COPD. He presents today complaining of intermittent periods of ""heart fluttering""  fatigue  and mild shortness of breath for the past 3 weeks. He indicates he occasionally feels lightheaded though he hasn’t had any episodes of fainting. He also reports of decreased exercise tolerance. His home medications include Lisinopril  Metformin  and a short-acting bronchodilator (Albuterol). He denies any chest pain  cough or fever. Family history is positive for cardiac disease  with his father having had a myocardial infarction at age 75. On physical examination  an irregularly irregular heart rhythm is appreciated.

Problem Representation:  Patient is an 75-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia presenting with intermittent palpitations  shortness of breath on exertion  and fatigue. His symptoms have been occurring for the past 5 weeks  but he minimized them until recently when they've become more persistent. He denies chest pain  loss of consciousness  or associated symptoms. His medication list includes a thiazide diuretic  metformin  and a statin. He is a former smoker and quit about 20 years ago. Family history is significant for cardiac diseases  particularly his father had a myocardial infarction at age 62.  Notably  his heart rate is irregularly irregular on physical examination  suggestive of atrial fibrillation. His blood pressure is mildly elevated at 145/90. Electrocardiography and laboratory studies including complete blood count  electrolytes  thyroid function tests  liver and kidney function  and coagulation parameters have been ordered for better assessment. He will likely need anticoagulation therapy for atrial fibrillation if his CHA2DS2-VASC score indicates a moderate-to-high risk of stroke. Cardioversion and long-term rate or rhythm control strategy will be considered based on his symptoms and cardiac function status.

A 70-year-old Caucasian female presents to the clinic with new-onset palpitations. She has a known history of hypertension for the last 10 years  which is managed with hydrochlorothiazide. She reports a 2-week history of feeling rapid  irregular heartbeats  especially during the night  associated with intermittent lightheadedness and shortness of breath. She denies any chest pain  heat or cold intolerances  unintentional weight changes  or history of rheumatic heart disease. She does not report any history of smoking or alcohol use. Her only family history of note is her father  who had coronary artery disease. Physical examination reveals an irregularly irregular pulse with a rate of around 110 bpm  blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  and bilateral pedal edema. EKG confirms atrial fibrillation. The remaining physical examination is unremarkable.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia presents with complaints of palpitations and moderate shortness of breath ongoing for two days. The patient's palpitations are described as irregular and rapid  and are often coupled with episodes of dizziness and moderate fatigue. The patient reports that he is adherent to his medications  which include Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia. He has no known drug allergies. There is a family history of cardiac disease  mostly coronary artery disease  on his paternal side. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. On examination  irregularly irregular cardiac rhythms are noted. There are no other significant findings on physical examination. His body mass index (BMI) is 28  indicating that he is overweight. Blood pressure at presentation is 155/95 mmHg.

A 75-year-old African American male patient  with a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  presents to the clinic complaining of recurrent episodes of palpitations  fatigue  and overall feeling of uneasiness for the past 2 months. The patient describes the palpitations as rapid and irregular. Furthermore  he has experienced occasional shortness of breath particularly after performing some basic daily activities. He has been adherent to his current anti-hypertensive and anti-diabetic medications. He denies chest pain  dizziness  syncope  or a significant weight change. He is a former smoker  quit ten years ago  and drinks alcohol socially. A steady increasing heart rate is noted in his recent vital sign charts. Family history includes a father with a heart attack at 68 and a brother with atrial fibrillation.

A 68-year-old African American male with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents with complaints of palpitations and mild shortness of breath that has been ongoing for the past week. He has moderate physical inactivity and is a non-smoker. He denies any chest pain  dizziness  or fainting. He has been adherent with his antihypertensive and hypoglycemic medications. He has no history of heart disease in his family. Upon examination  an irregularly irregular heart rhythm is noted  along with a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg. He has a BMI of 29 kg/m2  signaling overweight.

A 72-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of hypertension  diabetes  and congestive cardiac failure presents with a one-week history of palpitations  lightheadedness  and shortness of breath on exertion. He denies any chest pain  orthopnea  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. His blood pressure is 140/90mmHg and the pulse rate is irregular at 120 bpm. Auscultation reveals an irregular rhythm with no audible murmurs. EKG confirms atrial fibrillation. There is no history of smoking  alcohol or illicit drug use and he is compliant with his prescribed antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications. His family history is significant with his father having a stroke at the age of 62 years. The patient is retired and lives with his wife. He is cognitively intact  speaks English fluently  and has a BMI within the normal range. Labs show HbA1c of 7.4%  elevated BNP  normal thyroid function tests  and normal electrolytes.

A 68-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents to the clinic with shortness of breath  intermittent heart palpitations  and fatigue for the last two weeks. He has a 25-pack year history of smoking and admits to consuming alcohol on weekends but denies any illicit drug use. He is compliant with his hypertension and cholesterol medications. His father had a history of heart disease and died of a myocardial infarction in his early 70s. The patient has not been previously diagnosed with any cardiac condition. On examination  an irregularly irregular heartbeat is detected.

A 75-year-old Caucasian male presents with recent onset palpitations and intermittent fatigue. He has a medical history significant for hypertension  managed with Lisinopril  and stable coronary artery disease. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  syncope  or presyncope. On examination  his pulse is irregular and fast  but blood pressure is within normal limits. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. An electrocardiogram confirms the diagnosis of atrial fibrillation. The patient has no previous history of atrial fibrillation or other arrhythmias. His father had a stroke at the age of 80. The patient consumes alcohol daily and is a former smoker. His medications include Lisinopril  aspirin  and atorvastatin. There is no known history of drug allergies.

A 70-year-old African-American male with a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and smoking presents to the emergency department with a complaint of palpitations and progressive shortness of breath for the past two days. He also reports intermittent chest discomfort  fatigue  and light-headedness. The patient denies any history of alcohol use  illicit drug use  or recent trauma. Physical examination reveals irregular pulse and mild pedal edema. His blood pressure is stable  but heart rate ranges from 95-125 bpm. No obvious signs of heart failure or pulmonary edema on examination. Family history indicates that his father passed away at age 74 following a stroke. Current medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Aspirin.

Patient Presentation: A 72-year-old African American male with a medical history significant for hypertension and type II diabetes presents with complaints of intermittent palpitations and fatigue over the last few weeks.  Problem: New onset atrial fibrillation in a patient with a history of hypertension and type II diabetes. The patient also exhibits symptoms of palpitations and fatigue.

A 72-year-old African American male  with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus  and a transient ischemic attack 1 year ago  presents with intermittent palpitations and mild exertional dyspnea for the past two weeks. He denies any chest pain  current smoking  alcohol intake  or recreational drug use. His medications include metformin  aspirin  and amlodipine. On physical examination  he has an irregularly irregular heart rate of 110 beats per minute and blood pressure of 156/92 mmHg. His ECG shows atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.  Summary: This 72-year-old African American male with a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and transient ischemic attack  presents with symptoms of atrial fibrillation including palpitations and exertional dyspnea. Atrial fibrillation on ECG confirms the diagnosis.

Patient Profile: A 72-year-old Caucasian male  Relevant Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past 10 years  both of which are well-managed with medications (ACE inhibitors and statins respectively). He's been categorized as a moderate to heavy drinker and former smoker who ceased tobacco use 15 years prior.   Presenting Symptoms: The patient came to the hospital complaining of palpitations  shortness of breath  and an overall feeling of weakness that persisted over the past few days. He also mentioned occasional episodes of dizziness and mild chest discomfort. He denied any history of syncope  diaphoresis or alarming weight loss. The symptoms were not associated with physical activity and were persistent over the course of the day.  During physical examination  an irregular  rapid pulse and slightly elevated blood pressure were observed. Baseline blood investigations  ECG  and subsequent Echocardiogram confirmed the diagnosis of Atrial Fibrillation.

A 72-year-old African American male presents to the Emergency Department with complaints of palpitations and unusual fatigue for the past four days. This patient has a known history of hypertension managed with Prinivil (Lisinopril) as well as Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  controlled through diet and Metformin. There is no known history of heart disease in the family.   The patient reports that his symptoms started subtly and gradually become consistent. On the current presentation  his heart rate is irregularly irregular  exhibiting classical signs of atrial fibrillation. He denies any chest discomfort  dizziness  or dyspnea. Vitals include blood pressure of 145/88 mmHg  irregular pulse rate at 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute with an oxygen saturation of 95% on room air and 37.3°C temperature.   An electrocardiogram (EKG) confirms the diagnosis of atrial fibrillation. The patient is currently hemodynamically stable. Additional history reveals mild alcohol use  occasional cigars  and a sedentary lifestyle. Lab results demonstrate that his glucose level  kidney function  and liver tests are within normal limits. His anticoagulation status is currently unknown. The patient is admitted to cardiology for further management of atrial fibrillation.

A 72-year-old Caucasian man with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the clinic complaining of irregular heartbeats and episodes of fatigue. He has noticed his symptoms for the past two months but they have become more pronounced over the past week. He also reports associated shortness of breath  particularly during moderate physical activities  such as mowing the lawn. He denies chest pain  palpitations  syncope  or lower extremity swelling. He does not smoke  drinks alcohol occasionally  and is generally active. Family history is notable for coronary artery disease in his father. Current medications include metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. On physical examination  his heart rate was irregularly irregular and he has slightly elevated blood pressure. Further diagnostic evaluation revealed atrial fibrillation on EKG.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male patient presents with intermittent palpitations and episodes of lightheadedness that have become more frequent over the past few months. Past medical history is significant for hypertension  controlled by lisinopril  and hypercholesterolemia  managed with atorvastatin. His father had a stroke at the age of 75. He consumes alcohol moderately and quit smoking 10 years ago. There is no known drug or food allergy. On initial evaluation  his resting heart rate monitor displays an irregularly irregular rhythm  and his ECG confirms atrial fibrillation. Other vitals are within normal ranges  and physical examination is unremarkable except for irregular heart sounds. There is no acute chest pain  dyspnea  or signs of heart failure.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents to the emergency department with recurrent sensations of heart fluttering. These episodes have been intermittently occurring over the past 2 weeks. The patient reports each episode lasts for 1-2 hours  associated with mild shortness of breath  light-headedness  and occasional mild chest discomfort. He denies any episode of passing out or significant chest pain. Review of his medications revealed Aspirin 81mg  Lisinopril 10mg  and Metformin HCl 500mg twice daily. The patient has a 40 pack-year smoking history and drinks socially. He lives alone at home and is retired. He has not sought treatment for these symptoms before today. Physical examination reveals an irregularly irregular heart rhythm and the remainder of the examination is unremarkable. The patient’s blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg and heart rate varies between 88 and 130 bpm depending on the presence of atrial fibrillation. EKG confirms the suspected diagnosis of atrial fibrillation.

A 72-year-old Hispanic male presents to the emergency department with complaints of persistent palpitations  shortness of breath and occasional light-headedness for the past one week. He has a medical history significant for hypertension and moderate alcohol use. There were no known drug allergies. On examination  irregularly irregular heart rhythm noted on auscultation. He denies chest pain  nausea  vomiting  or recent illnesses. He has had intermittent palpitations before but they have never lasted as long or been associated with lightheadedness. He has not been previously diagnosed with AFib.

A 72-year-old African-American female with a history of hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and chronic kidney disease presents with recent onset symptoms of palpitations  occasional shortness of breath  and fatigue. These symptoms have been occurring intermittently over the past two weeks. She denies chest pain  dizziness  or syncope. On examination  her heart rate is irregularly irregular  confirming the suspicion of atrial fibrillation. She also has a slightly elevated blood pressure. Her remaining physical exam including lung auscultation is unremarkable. Her previous medications include amlodipine  metformin  and a statin. She has no known drug allergies. Her family history is significant for myocardial infarction in her father. She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally.   This patient's history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus contribute to her elevated risk for atrial fibrillation. These conditions  along with her age and African-American ethnicity  also increase her risk of stroke  a potential complication of atrial fibrillation. Thus  she is in need of prompt evaluation and  potentially  initiation of anticoagulation therapy. Her palpitations suggest an irregular heartbeat  while her fatigue and dyspnea may imply that her afib is affecting her cardiac output.   The patient's chronic kidney disease could have implications for both the management of her atrial fibrillation  particularly in relation to the use of anticoagulants  and its potential progression as a result of hemodynamic changes imposed by this arrhythmia. Furthermore  her risk for adverse outcomes  including stroke and heart failure  is amplified given her comorbidities and ethnicity. Thus  optimal management of her case requires taking into account not only her symptomatic atrial fibrillation but also her coexistent diseases and the interconnected implications of these conditions.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents with intermittent episodes of palpitations and mild shortness of breath that have been occurring for a past few months. The patient has a history of hypertension  diagnosed five years ago  controlled with Angiotensin Converting Enzyme (ACE) inhibitor (Lisinopril)  and a former smoker (quit 10 years ago). He denies chest pain  dizziness  or fainting spells. Physical examination reveals irregularly irregular heart rhythm. EKG confirms diagnosis of atrial fibrillation with ventricular rate of 110 BPM. His vitals on admission are BP 140/85 mmHg  RR 20/min  Body Temp 98.2 F  and SpO2 98% on room air. The patient has poor consumption of vegetables and fruits and does not engage in physical activity regularly. There is a family history of cardiovascular disease with his father having had a myocardial infarction at 65 years and a brother diagnosed with atrial fibrillation in the early 70s. His BMI is 28.3 kg/m2  indicating overweight.
