She has been consistent with her annual health reviews  with the last one documented 11 months earlier  with no significant findings.  V. Family History   Heart disease is prevalent in her family  with her father succumbing to a myocardial infarction at 84  and her elder sister underwent angioplasty at 75. There is no known family history of atrial fibrillation (AF).  VI. Review of Symptoms  On systematic inquiry  Mrs. L reported occasional nocturia and light-headedness but denied angina  syncope  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or edema.   VII. Physical Examination   The physical examination was relatively unremarkable  except for an irregular pulse rate ranging from 90 to 130 beats per minute. Blood pressure was 135/85 mm Hg  and no heart murmurs were auscultated.  VIII. Investigations and Diagnosis   An Electrocardiogram (ECG) confirmed atrial fibrillation  showing a complete absence of P waves  irregularly irregular R-R intervals  and a slightly fast ventricular rate. An Echocardiogram showed a normal ejection fraction and no valvular disease. Blood tests were mostly normal  including thyroid function tests.  Based on these findings  the diagnosis of persistent atrial fibrillation was made.  IX. Management and Follow-up   The management plan included rate control with beta-blockers and anticoagulation with warfarin to reduce the risk of stroke. She was referred to a cardiologist for consideration of rhythm control strategies. Lifestyle modifications were reinforced  and the patient was instructed to return in a month for follow-up and reassessment.    This case report outlines the typical presentation of atrial fibrillation  a common cardiac arrhythmia often seen in clinical practice  particularly in the elderly population with comorbid cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes  and dyslipidemia. Further  it underscores the need for comprehensive management  encompassing pharmacotherapy  lifestyle modifications  and specialist referrals.

Title: Atrial Fibrillation in a 67-Year-Old Male with Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia: A Case Report  Introduction: Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a common chronic rhythm disorder associated with serious consequences such as stroke and heart failure. It often develops in the context of other cardiovascular diseases  such as hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Here  we present the case of a 67-year-old male with a history of both  who was diagnosed with AF.  Case Presentation: A 67-year-old African American male presented to the clinic with complaints of irregular heartbeat and intermittent episodes of palpitations  which he reported had been occurring for several weeks. He also described feeling fatigued and shortness of breath  particularly during his morning walks. The patient's past medical history revealed a diagnosis of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both under control with medication. He does not have a known history of diabetes  no history of smoking  and drinks alcohol socially. He leads a semi-sedentary lifestyle  being a retired accountant. He is currently on amlodipine and atorvastatin.  Clinical Examination and Diagnosis: Physical examination showed elevated blood pressure (150/95mmHg) and irregular pulse (98 bpm)  and the rest of the examination was unremarkable. The complete blood count  renal and liver function tests were within normal range. However  cholesterol panel revealed a high LDL level at 150 mg/dL.   Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed irregularly irregular rhythm  absence of distinct p waves  and an irregular ventricular response  which are characteristic of atrial fibrillation. Transthoracic echocardiogram showed a dilated left atrium but normal left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 56%. Based on these findings  the patient was diagnosed with non-valvular atrial fibrillation.  Management and Follow-up: The patient was started on oral anticoagulation with apixaban  considering his risk of thromboembolism (CHA2DS2-VASc score 2). He was also started on rate-control therapy with metoprolol  and his hypertension medications were adjusted. His cholesterol management was also addressed by increasing the dose of his statin therapy. The patient was also educated on the importance of maintaining a heart-healthy diet  regular exercise  compliance with medications  and regular monitoring.  He was followed up after two weeks  showing marked improvement in his symptoms and blood pressure (135/85mmHg). Over the subsequent months  his LDL levels also improved (115 mg/dL)  and his EKG showed satisfactory control of ventricular rate.  Discussion: The presented case emphasizes the role of common cardiovascular conditions such as hypertension and hyperlipidemia as risk factors for the development of atrial fibrillation. Early detection and appropriate management of these conditions can significantly reduce the occurrence and complications of AF. It is also highlighted that comprehensive management including comorbidity control  lifestyle modification and judicious use of medications can yield satisfactory symptom control in AF patients.  NOTE: This case does not disclose any identifiable patient information and is fully compliant with ethical guidelines for case reporting.

Case Report: Atrial Fibrillation in a 65-year-old Caucasian Male Patient  Patient Information: The patient is identified as a 65-year-old Caucasian male. He is a married grandfather to five grandchildren and is now retired after a lengthy career in construction. His body mass index (BMI) is above normal; he has a history of mild hypertension  controlled by regular medication.  Chief Complaint: Irregular and unusually rapid heart rhythm experienced intermittently  described as 'fluttering' in the chest. The patient also reported instances of fatigue  mild breathlessness  and anxiety.  History of Present Illness: Patient has been experiencing episodic symptoms primarily characterized by an irregular heartbeat for the past four months  although the frequency and intensity has increased in the last six weeks. Episodes appear to be unprovoked and spontaneous with most occurring during rest. The duration varies from a few minutes to a couple of hours.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of mild hypertension diagnosed ten years ago  which has been adequately controlled with an ACE inhibitor (Lisinopril) and lifestyle modifications. He has no history of heart attacks  strokes  or other coronary diseases. His cholesterol has always been within a normal range. There’s no significant history of other severe systemic diseases. The patient is a former smoker  having stopped 15 years ago.  Family History: The patient's father suffered from atrial fibrillation (AFib) and passed away due to a stroke. His mother has type 2 diabetes and hypertension. The patient has two siblings: a brother diagnosed with AFib in his late 60s  and a sister in good overall health.  Medication History: Regular medication includes Lisinopril (10mg) once daily for hypertension. He takes no other prescription drugs but occasionally uses over-the-counter antacids for gastroesophageal reflux disease. No drug allergies have been documented.  Diagnostic Assessment:   Physical Examination: No acute distress was noted. The patient’s BMI is 27.5 (overweight). His blood pressure is slightly elevated  and an irregular pulse rate was detected upon auscultation. On examination  no other abnormalities were found.  Investigations: An electrocardiogram was suggestive of AFib  verified by a 24-hour Holter monitor. A transthoracic echocardiogram showed no structural heart disease. Blood tests indicated normal kidney function and electrolyte balance.  Diagnosis: The clinical presentation  family history  physical examination  and diagnostic tests aided in diagnosing the patient with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (PAF).  Therapeutic Intervention:   The patient was started on Apixaban for stroke prevention due to his age and family history. A rate-controlling strategy with Metoprolol succinate (25 mg  twice daily) was initiated as well. Risk factor modification included advice on weight reduction  limiting caffeine and alcohol  and regular exercise.  Prognosis: Regular follow-ups were scheduled for early detection of progression from PAF to persistent AFib and for comorbidity management  primarily hypertension. With prompt management  adherence to therapy  and lifestyle modification  a favorable prognosis is expected.  Conclusion: This case underlines the importance of recognizing symptoms of atrial fibrillation  even in the absence of structural heart disease. Given the strong family history  we may argue a possible genetic predisposition for AFib in this case. However  with adequate therapeutic intervention and lifestyle modifications  the patient's quality of life can remain high - demonstrating the importance of early diagnosis and treatment of PAF.

Title: Anticoagulation Management in an Elderly Female with Newly Diagnosed Atrial Fibrillation  Introduction: This report describes the case of an 82-year-old Caucasian female with newly diagnosed atrial fibrillation (AF)  discussing her clinical presentation  evaluation  and management plan  particularly focusing on anticoagulation management.  Patient Information: The patient is an 82-year-old Caucasian female  a resident of a small town in Midwestern United States. She lives with her husband and is retired. Her family history includes a brother who had a stroke at age 58.  Past Medical History: She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which she takes Lisinopril and Simvastatin respectively. She had a total knee replacement surgery 10 years ago. She has never smoked or drank alcohol  and she had no known drug allergies.  Clinical Findings:  The patient presented to the clinic with a recent history of occasional palpitations and fatigue primarily on exertion. On examination  irregularly irregular heart rhythm was detected.   Diagnosis:  An electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed which showed evidence of atrial fibrillation. Given her age and past medical history  she was calculated to have a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 4 (1 point for age  1 for hypertension  and 2 for being female)  suggesting a high risk of stroke.  Therapeutic Intervention: Following a shared-decision making discussion about the benefits and potential complications related to therapy  the patient was placed on an oral anticoagulant  Apixaban  for stroke prophylaxis. Rate control was achieved with Metoprolol  and lifestyle modifications were encouraged.  Follow-up and Outcome: After 3 months  the patient's symptoms improved significantly. Her fatigue was much better and her palpitations resolved. Her anticoagulation was well-managed and she had no reported bleeding or bruising complications.  Discussion: This patient's case illustrates the typical presentation of atrial fibrillation in an elderly female. Her management was steered by her CHA2DS2-VASc score  reflecting the need for and benefit of anticoagulation used in conjunction with rate control—a common and effective strategy used in AF management. The case also highlights the importance of individualizing treatment plans taking into the account the patient's preferences and overall health condition.  Conclusion: Atrial fibrillation is common among the aging population and its optimal management requires invasive treatment for some while others may do well with rate control and anticoagulation. In this case  the patient's symptoms have greatly improved following initiation of the treatment  indicating the effective management of her newly diagnosed atrial fibrillation.

Title: Management of Atrial Fibrillation in an Elderly Man with Prior Stroke History – A Case Report  Patient Demographics:  The patient is an 81-year-old Caucasian male  retired teacher  a lifetime nonsmoker  and a social drinker. His BMI is within the normal range  he lives alone and drives independently.   Case Presentation:  The patient presented in the emergency department complaining of palpitations and mild chest discomfort which started an hour prior to arrival. His past medical history is significant for hypertension  high cholesterol  and an ischemic stroke 5 years earlier.   Past Medical History:  The patient had an ischemic stroke five years ago which left him with mild residual left-side weakness. He has hypertension  controlled with daily Amlodipine 5mg  and high cholesterol controlled with daily Statin  40mg. The patient had no diabetes  no history of myocardial infarction  heart failure  or any intervention. The patient was not on anticoagulation therapy.  Clinical Findings: Upon examination  the patient's blood pressure was 152/87 mmHg and his heart rate was irregularly irregular  ranging between 90-120 beats per min. An ECG confirmed the presence of atrial fibrillation (AF). Lab values were unremarkable except for an elevated INR.  Assessment and Treatment: The patient was diagnosed with new-onset AF. Given the patient's age  prior stroke history  and current CHA2DS2-VASc score calculation  he needed to be initiated on oral anticoagulation to prevent thromboembolism. After discussing the potential risks and benefits  the patient was started on Dabigatran  a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC). The plan was to monitor his kidney function and adjust the dose of Dabigatran appropriately.   Educational/Awareness Point: This case is a typical presentation of AF in an elderly patient with a history of stroke. Given the high risk of stroke in patients with untreated AF  the necessity of anticoagulation was emphasized and started despite the relatively minor symptoms presented by the patient. This case emphasizes the importance of a risk-stratified approach in managing AF  especially in elderly patients as they have the highest risk of stroke. It also highlights individualized patient care in tailoring anticoagulation therapy to patient-specific factors such as age  previous medical history  etc. The role of DOACs as easier to manage alternative to traditional anticoagulation with Warfarin  needing fewer tests but subject to renal function  was underscored.  Consent:  Informed consent was obtained from the patient for being included in the study.

Case Report:  Title: Management of Atrial Fibrillation in an Elderly Male: A Case Study   Introduction: A 78-year-old African American male with a diagnosis of chronic atrial fibrillation is the focus of this case study. The purpose is to discuss the clinical course  diagnosis  and treatment of this commonly encountered cardiac arrhythmia.  Patient Information: The patient is a retired school principal living with his wife in a suburban community. He is a non-smoker and reports moderate alcohol use. He has a past medical history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus  both well-managed with medication. The patient has no known allergies.  Clinical Findings: The patient presented to the Emergency Department with a complaint of episodic rapid heartbeat for the previous three days  coupled with shortness of breath after minimal effort and generalized weakness. On physical examination  he appeared anxious and was sweating slightly. His heart rate was irregular and fast  ranging between 115-140 beats per minute. His blood pressure was moderately high at 150/90 mmHg. Rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment: An Electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed that showed irregular R-R intervals and absence of distinct P-waves — hallmarks of atrial fibrillation. A laboratory workup including a complete blood count  renal and liver function tests  and thyroid function tests were all within normal limits. However  an elevated HbA1c of 7.5% indicated poor glycemic control. Chest X-ray and echocardiogram did not show any abnormalities.  Therapeutic Focus and Assessment: Management focused on rate control  anticoagulation  and addressing diabetic control. The patient was started on a beta-blocker (metoprolol) for rate control  which effectively reduced his heart rate to less than 100 beats per minute. For stroke prophylaxis  considering his age and comorbidities  the patient was started on an oral anticoagulant (apixaban). His diabetic medications were also adjusted.   Follow-Up and Prognosis: Patient's symptoms improved significantly over the next three days  and he was discharged with a follow-up appointment with a cardiologist. The patient was informed about lifestyle measures to prevent triggering of atrial fibrillation and the importance of adhering to his medication. He was also advised to attend regular diabetes and blood pressure clinics.   Conclusion: Optimal management of atrial fibrillation requires a comprehensive approach that combines symptom control  prevention of thromboembolic complications  and treatment of underlying conditions.  Note: This case report aims to contribute to the clinical conversation around elderly patients with atrial fibrillation. The case highlights the importance of prompt recognition  correct diagnosis  and comprehensive treatment of this condition. It also underscores the need for more robust primary prevention strategies targeting modifiable risk factors in this vulnerable population.

Title: Management of Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation in an Elderly Male Patient with Co-existing Hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus  Patient Introduction: The patient is a 78-year-old Caucasian male referred by his general practitioner for palpitations. He has a known history of hypertension controlled by Losartan 50mg daily for the past seven years and type II diabetes managed with Metformin 500mg twice daily over six years. His other medical history includes moderate osteoarthritis for which he regularly takes Paracetamol. He is a retired engineer  a non-smoker  and drinks approximately 10 units of alcohol weekly. Family history reveals his father had a stroke at the age of 70.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented with a one-week history of decreased exercise tolerance  intermittent palpitations and discomfort in the left upper quadrant of his chest. The symptoms were more severe at night and seemed unrelated to physical activity. He did not report any episodes of syncope  breathlessness  or chest pain.  Clinical Examination and Results: Upon physical examination  the patient appeared anxious  had a palpable irregular radial pulse of 90 beats per minute  and blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg. Cardiac auscultation indicated an irregularly irregular heart rhythm with no audible murmurs. Routine blood tests including complete blood count  fasting glucose  kidney function  thyroid function  and liver function were all within normal limits except for elevated HbA1c (8.2%)  indicating poor control of his diabetes. A resting 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) confirmed atrial fibrillation (AF) with an ventricular rate of 90 beats per minute.  Management: The patient was diagnosed with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. The initial treatment approach focused on rate control through administration of beta-blockers  namely Metoprolol 50mg twice daily. After further cardiology consultation  it was decided to initiate oral anticoagulation treatment with Apixaban due to his elevated CHA2DS2-VASc score (3 points: age >75 years  hypertension  and diabetes)  which suggested a high annual risk for stroke. His diabetes management was also reviewed and intensified by adding Glipizide 5mg daily to his regimen. He was educated regarding the nature of his condition and the importance of medication adherence.  Follow-up: At a 6-week follow-up visit  the patient reported a significant improvement in his symptoms. His heart rhythm was well controlled and blood pressure and HbA1c levels also improved. Regular check-ups and monitoring were planned for further management of his condition.  Conclusion: This case presents an individualized approach to managing paroxysmal atrial fibrillation in an elderly patient with co-existing medical conditions  highlighting the importance of a comprehensive risk assessment to improve patient outcomes.

Case Report: Atrial Fibrillation  Patient Description  The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male residing in a suburban area. His weight is 82 kilograms  and he stands at 1.75 meters tall. His cigarette smoking history involves a pack per day for the past 40 years. He is a retired engineer  living with his wife  with a family history of heart disease and stroke. The patient describes himself as a moderate drinker. He has a limited physical activity routine and a diet that lacks in fruits and vegetables.   Past Medical History  The patient was diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus 15 years ago. He has been managing his conditions with Metformin 500 mg twice daily for diabetes  and Lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension. Over these years  his blood pressure and blood sugar control has often been suboptimal due to his inconsistent compliance with medication and lifestyle advice. He reported past instances of transient ischemic attacks but did not seek immediate medical attention for these.   He also has hyperlipidemia  which has been managed with Simvastatin 40 mg daily. He had an appendectomy at age 25 and a hernia repair at the age of 47 with no reported post-operative complications. The patient denies any known allergies.   Presenting Complaint  The patient presented to the clinic with complaints of palpitations  intermittent dizziness  occasional chest discomfort  and shortness of breath of one month’s duration. The symptoms were more noticeable during periods of activity  but he also reported experiencing them at rest.   Clinical Assessment  On examination  irregularly irregular heart sounds were heard on auscultation  suggestive of atrial fibrillation. His blood pressure was 160/90mmHg. Laboratory exams  including a complete blood count  electrolytes  and thyroid-stimulating hormone levels  were normal except for slightly elevated fasting blood glucose (148 mg/dL) and LDL cholesterol (150 mg/dL).  Electrocardiography confirmed a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. Echocardiogram showed left atrial enlargement and estimated ejection fraction (EF) of 45%.  Summarizing  The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a significant medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  and a current diagnosis of atrial fibrillation. His risk factors include advanced age  Caucasian ethnicity  male gender  positive family history of cardiovascular disease  persistent hypertension  long-standing diabetes  smoking  hyperlipidemia and his suboptimal adherence to prescribed medications.

Title: New Onset of Atrial Fibrillation in a 68-Year-Old Caucasian Male with Prior Hypertensive History  Introduction:   Atrial fibrillation (AF) is common in elderly people  complicating the management of existing medical conditions. This case report describes a 68-year old Caucasian male who presented with new onset AF against a background of managed hypertension.  Patient Information:  Mr. Smith  a retired engineer who enjoys regular physical activity  presented with palpitations lasting for a few days. He was conscious  oriented  and cooperative. His Pulse rate 106/minute  irregularly irregular  and blood pressure of 150/90mm Hg. His body mass index (BMI) was within normal limits and he denied any family history of cardiac diseases.   Medical History:  The patient has been diagnosed with essential hypertension five years back and has been on regular medication (Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme Inhibitors). He has no known allergies and maintains abstinence from smoking and alcohol. He has not been diagnosed with diabetes or any other chronic disease.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  there was no visible pulsation or inflammation in the precordium. Cardiovascular examination confirmed an irregularly irregular pulse with no heart murmurs. Electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrated AF with a fast ventricular rate. No overt source of infection  which could have precipitated this event  was identified. The patient was haemodynamically stable.  Diagnostic Assessment and Therapeutic Intervention:  Confirmation of AF was done by repeat ECG. His Troponin I levels were normal. His echocardiogram showed left ventricular hypertrophy with normal systolic function. No clots were seen in the heart chambers. He was initiated on Beta-Blockers (Metoprolol) to control his heart rate and oral anticoagulants (Apixaban) for stroke prevention. His AF had probably resulted from long-standing hypertension  leading to structural changes of the heart  although no specific trigger could be identified.  Follow Up and Outcomes:  His blood pressure and heart rate were successfully brought under control with the above treatment regimen along with continued ACE inhibitors for hypertension. His palpitations improved  and he was discharged a few days later  with outpatient follow-up instructions.  Discussion:  This case illustrates the new onset of AF in an elderly male patient  whose only risk factor was a well-managed hypertensive history. It underscores the importance of regular cardiac screening in such patients  as they can develop AF without any specific symptoms or triggers. Incorporating regular ECG screening into their follow-up may help in early detection and management of this complication.  Conclusion:  Early detection and management of AF in hypertensive patients are crucial as this can prevent complications such as stroke and heart failure. This case report emphasizes the importance of regular  streamlined follow-ups co-managed by primary care physicians and cardiologists in the case of elderly hypertensive patients.

Title: Newly Diagnosed Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation in a Mid-Age Female Patient  Introduction: Mrs. S  a 55-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the outpatient clinic department due to spells of palpitation and episodes of shortness of breath repeatedly experienced in the past few weeks. She is a lifelong non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. She is engaged in a sedentary lifestyle with limited physical activities.  Clinical Findings: Upon evaluation  the patient's BMI was calculated to 30.5 denoting an overweight status. Her blood pressure was fluctuating between normal to moderately high ranges (140/90 mmHg in the highest record). Precordial examination revealed irregular heart rhythms.  Past Medical History: Patient has a history of hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus  but no family history of cardiovascular diseases. Her fluctuating blood pressure was controlled with Metoprolol  and type II diabetes was controlled with Metformin.  Investigations: Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed irregular R-R intervals without P-waves  suggesting atrial fibrillation (AF). Echocardiography showed normal size and function of the left ventricle  with no valvular abnormalities. Hemogram and electrolyte panel were within normal limits. Her glycated hemoglobin (HbA1C) was 7.8% indicative of uncontrolled blood sugar. Thyroid hormone levels were within their normal ranges.  Diagnosis: Considering her ECG and symptoms  a diagnosis of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation was confirmed.  Treatment: In terms of pharmacologic management  the patient was initiated on Rivaroxaban  an anticoagulant  for stroke prophylaxis based on her CHA2DS2-VASc score of 3 calculated for non-valvular atrial fibrillation risk. She was counseled regarding lifestyle changes: physical activities  weight loss and limiting alcohol and caffeine intake. Anti-arrhythmic drug Flecainide was started to manage her paroxysms of atrial fibrillation. Her anti-hypertensive therapy was optimized by adding Amlodipine in view of persistently borderline blood pressure and her anti diabetic therapy was intensified by the addition of a DPP-4 inhibitor  Sitagliptin.  Follow-up:  Review and follow-up was scheduled after 4 weeks to assess monitor the symptoms and any possible side effects from the newly introduced medications.  Conclusion: This single-patient case spotlights the connection of lifestyle factors and comorbidities such as obesity  hypertension  and Type II Diabetes in the onset of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Regular follow-up visits  constant monitoring  appropriate therapy and lifestyle modifications play an integral role in managing such conditions effectively.

Patient Identification: Generalized information for privacy and protection of individual.  Gender: Female  Age: 68 years Race: Caucasian Residence: Massachusetts  USA  Past Medical History:  Significant for moderate persistent asthma  type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with lifestyle adjustments and medication  and hypertension well-controlled with amlodipine. No history of heart disease  stroke  or clotting disorders. The patient is a nonsmoker and doesn't consume alcohol. She is a retired teacher  married  with three adult children. There have been no hospital admissions or surgical operations in the past.  Presenting Complaint:  Patient presented to the emergency department with intermittent palpitations and irregular heartbeat over the past few weeks.  Clinical Findings:  Upon examination  an irregularly irregular heartbeat was noted. Rest of the physical exam  including respiration and mental state  revealed no abnormalities. The patient's blood pressure was measured at 150/90 mmHg.  Investigations:  An electrocardiogram (ECG) was conducted confirming a diagnosis of chronic atrial fibrillation (AF). Additional tests were done to determine the cause  including a stress test  echocardiogram  and blood tests. The echocardiogram showed a normal left ventricular ejection fraction with no valvular heart disease. Her blood tests revealed slightly elevated fasting blood glucose levels and HbA1c levels confirming uncontrolled diabetes.   Treatment: The patient was initiated on anticoagulant therapy using Dabigatran to reduce the risk of stroke. Rate control was achieved with Metoprolol. Her glycemic control was reassessed  insulin was added to her regime and lifestyle modifications were intensified.   Patient Education: Patient and family were provided with information about AF  the importance of medication adherence  risk  and management of potential side-effects. Further  the patient was counseled about the significance of tight glucose control and its impact on cardiovascular health.   Follow-up: The patient was scheduled for regular out-patient follow-ups to monitor blood glucose  heart rate  rhythm control  and possible side-effects of the anticoagulant.   This document follows guidelines for authorship and acknowledgment in the preparation of case reports and has been created with an intent to aid clinical understanding without any potential breach of patient-doctor confidentiality or bioethical principles.  The case report of this 68-year-old female patient presents a common but important manifestation of atrial fibrillation in an individual with existing comorbidities (e.g.  hypertension  diabetes mellitus). Her presentation underscores the need for proper management of these conditions to reduce potential complications including atrial fibrillation and stroke.

Title: Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation in a Hypertensive 69-Year-old African American Male – A Case Study   Patient Profile: The patient is a 69-year-old African American male with a previous medical history of hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He is unmarried  retired and lives alone. He is a former smoker and reports moderate alcohol consumption. His exercise level is generally low due to knee pain from osteoarthritis.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented at the outpatient clinic complaining of episodic periods of palpitations  intermittent chest discomfort  fatigue  and occasional lightheadedness over the past few weeks.   Medical History: The patient has been under treatment for hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia for the past decade. He regularly takes medications including Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. His hypertension has generally been well controlled  with most recent readings consistently below 140/90 mmHg. His fasting blood glucose and HbA1c levels have also been satisfactory for his diabetic condition  rendering it under control.  Clinical Examination and Investigations: On examination  his BMI was 29.1. His vital signs showed variations in heart rates ranging from 80 to 160 bpm and an elevated blood pressure of 155/95 mmHg. An ECG confirmed paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (Afib) with rapid ventricular response.  Given his risk factors (hypertension  diabetes  advanced age  heart disease)  the patient was advised to undergo further investigations. Laboratory findings revealed a slightly elevated LDL cholesterol of 140 mg/dL  elevated serum triglycerides of 220 mg/dL  and normal HbA1c levels. Echocardiography demonstrated mild concentric left ventricular hypertrophy  left atrial enlargement  and preserved left ventricular ejection fraction. No valvular heart disease was noted.  Diagnosis: Given the combination of physical symptoms  ECG findings  and further investigations  a diagnosis of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation was made.  Clinical Management: The patient was prescribed Warfarin for anticoagulation to reduce stroke risks associated with Afib. Due to his poorly controlled blood pressure  a calcium channel blocker  Amlodipine was added to his current regimen. He was also advised to modify lifestyle behaviors  advised to maintain a healthy diet by reducing cholesterol and sodium intake  and to increase physical activity within his limitations. He was further advised to abstain from alcohol.  Follow-Up and Outcome: The patient was scheduled for follow-up appointments to monitor the Afib  adjust the dose of Warfarin and control remaining risk factors such as hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient was also referred for patient education about Afib and the importance of medication adherence.  This case underscores the importance of monitoring blood pressure and heart rate in patients with cardiovascular risk factors and the need for effective therapeutic regimes to manage Afib.

Title: A Case Report on a Geriatric Patient with Newly Diagnosed Atrial Fibrillation  Patient Information: A 73-year-old Caucasian male presents to the outpatient clinic with a primary complaint of a two-week history of palpitations and increasing shortness of breath especially on exertion. There are no associated symptoms of chest pain  syncope or dizziness. The patient also mentions a significant unintentional weight loss over the past three months. He denies smoking but admits to significant alcohol consumption of 3-4 glasses of wine per night for many years. He has no relevant family history of either heart disease or stroke.  PMH (Past Medical History): The patient has been previously diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He was prescribed metformin 1000mg twice daily  lisinopril 10mg daily  and atorvastatin 20mg at bedtime  respectively. His hypertension and hyperlipidemia levels were managed adequately. However  his diabetic status showed poor control  with a recent HbA1c level of 8.5%.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  this patient presents irregularly irregular pulse rated at 98 bpm  normal blood pressure of 138/80 mm Hg  and respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minutes. Cardiac examination revealed an irregular heart rhythm  but no murmur or gallop were detected. Results from the ECG (Electrocardiogram) confirmed the suspicion of atrial fibrillation (AF).  Diagnostic Assessment: A comprehensive metabolic panel showed elevated levels of glucose  suggesting poor control of diabetes. Lipid profile was within normal range. Transthoracic echocardiogram was performed which revealed normal left ventricle size and function  but with left atrial enlargement. No clot was found in the left atrium. Chest x-ray was unremarkable with no signs of congestion or any other abnormal findings.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was initiated on anticoagulation therapy with dabigatran to minimize the risk of thromboembolic events  following the CHA2DS2-VASc score (of 3). Rate control was achieved using beta-blocker metoprolol  titrated to maintain the heart rate below 100 bpm. The patient was also referred to a dietitian for better control of his diabetic status and was given counseling on lifestyle modification  which included reducing alcohol intake.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: The patient is to follow up within two weeks to assess symptoms and heart rate control and monthly for monitoring of diabetes management  including HbA1c. He was also instructed to return to the emergency department if he experiences chest pain  worsening shortness of breath  dizziness  or fainting episodes.  Patient Perspective: The patient expresses concern regarding his new diagnosis and is worried about the implications. He is willing to comply with the new treatment plan and lifestyle changes. The patient shows signs of slight anxiety but is cooperative and is assured he will receive all the necessary support to manage his condition.  Informed Consent: Patient's written consent was obtained for writing and publication of this case report. His identity has been fully anonymous to maintain confidentiality as per the journal's guidelines.

Title: Persistent Atrial Fibrillation in a 62-Year-Old Female with a History of Hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Patient Information:  The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian female with a known medical history of hypertension for over a decade and Type 2 diabetes mellitus for seven years. The patient is a nonsmoker and is moderate to low in alcohol use. The patient works as a bookshop owner and lives with her 68-year-old husband in their private home.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient presented to the cardiology outpatient clinic with complaints of sporadic bouts of palpitations for the past six months. She also reported experiencing associated symptoms such as brief periods of lightheadedness  easy fatigability  and occasional dyspnea on exertion.   Clinical Findings:  On examination  the patient’s blood pressure was raised at 154/96 mmHg and an irregularly irregular pulse of 98bpm was noted. The rest of the cardiovascular  respiratory  abdominal  and neurological examinations were unremarkable. Her BMI was calculated to be 29 kg/m^2  and her glycemic control was suboptimal with an HbA1c of 8%.  Diagnostic Assessments:  A 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed which revealed absence of P waves with irregular RR intervals  suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Blood tests further highlighted elevated B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) levels. An echocardiogram showed slight left atrial enlargement with preserved left ventricular function  supporting the diagnosis.   Therapeutic Intervention:  Given her symptoms  a decision was made to pursue rhythm control. The patient was started on the anticoagulant apixaban to reduce the risk of stroke and a rhythm control medication  Dronedarone. She also received pharmacological treatment for hypertension  and her diabetes medication regimen was adjusted for better glycemic control.   Follow-Up & Outcome:  On her four-week follow-up visit  the patient reported feeling significantly better with a reduction in palpitation episodes. Repeat ECG confirmed reversion to sinus rhythm. Furthermore  her blood pressure readings and glycemic control improved  highlighting the importance of comprehensive management.  Patient Perspective:  The patient expressed relief  reporting an improvement in her overall quality of life. She was educated about lifestyle modification  the need for regular clinic visits  and the importance of medication adherence in managing her conditions effectively.   Clinician Perspective:  This case underlines the complexity of managing atrial fibrillation in patients with comorbid conditions. A tailored treatment approach addressing the patient's cardiac issues  and optimizing control of her other chronic conditions  resulted in improved patient outcomes. Further longitudinal monitoring  however  will be necessary to assess long-term effectiveness.

Case Report: Atrial Fibrillation in an Elderly Female Patient  Patient Information   A 75-year-old Caucasian female presented to the outpatient department of our cardiology clinic. The patient resides in a suburban area and is a retired school teacher  living with her retired husband. She is a non-smoker  consumes alcohol occasionally  and has no known drug allergies.   Chief Complaint  The patient complained of occasional heart palpitations and shortness of breath worsening over the past two weeks  particularly when climbing stairs. She reported no chest pain  fever  syncope  or recent viral infections.  History of Present Illness  Review of her symptomatic timeline indicated that the patient initially experienced heart palpitations six months prior. Also  a two-month history of increasing shortness of breath was noted  mostly triggered by moderate exertion.   Past Medical History   The patient has a known history of high blood pressure and type II diabetes mellitus  both managed with oral medication for the past ten years. Her last recorded blood pressure was 140/90 mmHg  and her HbA1c was 7.0% three months ago. She was also diagnosed with hypothyroidism five years ago and is being managed on levothyroxine. No previous history of heart disease  stroke  pulmonary disease  liver disease  kidney disease  or cancer was reported.  Family History  Her father had a history of ischemic heart disease  and her mother had a stroke in her mid-70s. Her older brother  aged 77  is currently living with chronic heart failure.   Physical Examination  On examination  her pulse was irregularly irregular. The patient was comfortable at rest  but demonstrated a slight shortness of breath on exertion. The remainder of the examination  including blood pressure  cardiovascular  respiratory  and neurological examination  was unremarkable.   Diagnostic Assessment   Considering the irregularly irregular pulse and the described symptoms  a 12-lead Electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed  which confirmed atrial fibrillation (AF). The patient was furthered to the hospital where Holter-ECG was undertaken and echocardiogram was conducted to evaluate structural heart conditions. Blood work including complete blood count  lipid profile  renal function tests  liver function tests  and thyroid function tests was done.   Management   The patient was initiated on rate control strategy with beta-blockers and anticoagulation with direct oral anticoagulants taking into consideration her age  comorbidities  and CHA2DS2-VASc score.   Follow-Up  The patient has been scheduled for a follow-up visit next month to monitor her progress and to ensure therapeutic control is being achieved with the prescribed medications. Patient education regarding AF  its complications and the importance of medication adherence was rendered.   A multidisciplinary approach including Cardiologist  Endocrinologist  and General Practitioner interactions is envisaged to manage her AF  hypertension  diabetes  and hypothyroidism effectively

Title: Management of Atrial Fibrillation in a 72-Year-Old Caucasian Female with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: A Case Report  Introduction:  Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common sustained cardiac arrhythmia  predominantly afflicting individuals over the age of 65. It has been associated with a 5-fold increase in the risk of stroke  a 3-fold incidence of heart failure  and a 2-fold increase in dementia and mortality. We report the case of a 72-year-old Caucasian woman presenting with AF as well as type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).  Case Presentation:  The patient  a retired teacher  was a non-smoker and consumed alcohol socially. She had a BMI of 27.5  and a history of hypertension and T2DM for which she was on Metformin and Lisinopril. She reported intermittent episodes of palpitations  shortness of breath  and fatigue for the last few months.   On examination  the patient had an irregular heartbeat  blood pressure of 140/80 mmHg  pulse rate of 130 beats per minute  and oxygenation of 96% on ambient air. Her blood glucose level was relatively high  at 9.5 mmol/L. Other clinical findings were within normal limits  and the patient's neurological examination was also normal.  Investigation:  An electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed atrial fibrillation with a fast ventricular rate. A complete blood count reported no abnormalities while her lipid profile showed slightly raised LDL levels. An echocardiogram showed moderate left atrial enlargement and normal systolic function.  A Holter monitor confirmed persistent AF  with rapid ventricular response times up to 140 bpm. An MRI of the brain done to rule out a cerebral vascular event showed no abnormal findings.  Management:  The patient was started on anticoagulation therapy with Apixaban to prevent AF-related stroke. Rate control was achieved with Metoprolol and Digoxin. She was also started on Atorvastatin for lipid control  and her Lisinopril dosage was adjusted. Blood glucose levels were managed by adjusting the dose of Metformin and with dietary modifications.  Outcome and Follow-Up:  The patient's symptoms improved over the following weeks. Regular follow-ups have been scheduled for ECG  blood glucose checks  and consultation. The patient was also advised to make lifestyle modifications including a healthy diet  regular exercise  and weight management for better control of her AF and T2DM.  Conclusion:  This case outlines the importance of recognizing and managing AF in elderly patients  especially those with multiple comorbid conditions like T2DM and hypertension. Patient education and lifestyle modifications play an integral role in controlling these conditions alongside medication management. Regular follow-up and monitoring are crucial to detect and manage any complications early.

Title: Management of Atrial Fibrillation in an Elderly Female Patient with Hypertension: A Case Report  Introduction: This case report describes an elderly African American female patient with a diagnosis of hypertension and atrial fibrillation (AF). The demographic patterns of AF in the U.S indicate a higher prevalence in older adults  with 70% of cases in individuals aged 65-85. Although AF is common in both sexes  the illness is expected to affect more women partly due to their longer lifespan. Additionally  AF is about 50% more common in African American individuals as compared to their Caucasian counterparts.  Patient Information: The patient  a 76-year-old African American female  presented to the hospital with complaints of irregular heartbeat and shortness of breath. She has a known medical history of hypertension for the past fifteen years  managed with losartan 50mg daily. She has never smoked or consumed alcohol  and she follows a controlled sodium diet at home. She reported occasional episodes of unexplained weakness and dizziness over the past two months.  Clinical Findings: Upon admission  her blood pressure was 140/90 mmHg  heart rate was irregular at 110 beats/min  respiratory rate was 18 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation was 96% on room air. Her body mass index (BMI) was 30 kg/m2. Electrocardiogram revealed irregular rhythm with no discernible P waves  suggesting atrial fibrillation.  Diagnostic Assessment: Laboratory investigations  including complete blood count  renal function test  and thyroid-stimulating hormone test  were within normal limits. The echocardiogram demonstrated a mildly dilated left atrium and preserved left ventricular ejection fraction without any significant valvular disease. A chest X-ray was also performed which did not reveal any abnormalities.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was started on oral warfarin for anticoagulation in addition to losartan for blood pressure control. To control her heart rate  metoprolol 50mg twice daily was added. She was monitored for heart rate control  blood pressure  and any adverse effects related to the medication  particularly bleeding due to warfarin therapy.  Follow-up and Outcomes: Over the next few days  her symptoms of irregular heart rate and shortness of breath improved dramatically. Follow-up appointments were scheduled for regular INR checks and dose adjustment of warfarin  monitoring of signs of heart failure  and routine blood pressure checks. Her hypertension is well controlled with losartan  and there are currently no signs of heart failure.  Conclusion: This case emphasizes the importance of considering atrial fibrillation as a potential diagnosis in elderly hypertensive patients presenting with unexplained irregular heart rate  shortness of breath  dizziness  or weakness. This patient’s outcomes illustrate the efficacy of management with anticoagulation and rate control  demonstrating the opportunity for successful treatment and improved quality of life in this patient population.

Title: A Case of Atrial Fibrillation in a 72-Year-Old Male with Hypertension and Diabetes  Patient Description:  The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired  nonsmoker  and occasional drinker  who resides in an urban locality. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease  with both parents experiencing heart troubles in their late 60s.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a 10-year history of hypertension  managed with daily doses of lisinopril. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes five years ago and has been managing his condition with metformin and regular insulin injections; the last recorded HbA1c was 7.6%. The patient also has hyperlipidemia  for which he takes daily doses of atorvastatin.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient came to the emergency department presenting with an irregular and rapid heartbeat  episodes of breathlessness on exertion  mild fatigue  and occasional dizziness.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  the patient was comfortable and in no apparent distress. The initial vital signs were stable; blood pressure: 142/89 mmHg  heart rate (irregular): 116 bpm  and saturation of peripheral oxygen (SpO2): 98% while breathing room air.  Investigations:  An immediate EKG was done  revealing atrial fibrillation (AF) with a rate of 116 bpm. Complete blood counts  basic metabolic panel  and thyroid function tests were within normal limits. The echocardiogram showed normal left ventricular (LV) function with an ejection fraction (EF) of 60% and no significant valvular abnormalities.  Diagnoses:  Given the clinical findings and test results  the patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation.  Treatment:  Given the presenting symptoms and the risk factors (age > 65  hypertension  diabetes  and heart failure)  the patient has a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 4  indicating a high risk for stroke. After a discussion with the patient  it was decided to start him on oral anticoagulation (warfarin) to reduce his risk of stroke. The patient was also initiated on beta-blockers (metoprolol) to control his heart rate.  Follow-up:  A follow-up appointment was scheduled in one week for INR check and to assess the effectiveness and tolerance of warfarin and metoprolol. Long term  the patient will continue to regularly monitor his blood pressure  blood glucose  and lipid profile to manage his risk factors for AF.  This report is an example of a common presentation of atrial fibrillation in a senior patient with multiple comorbidities. Management involves not just addressing the arrhythmia but also managing associated risk factors that can increase the risk of stroke.

Title: Case Study of a Patient with Atrial Fibrillation: A 65-year-old African-American Male Patient  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 65-year-old African-American male residing in an urban area. He is retired and formerly worked as an engineer. He is a widower and lives alone  with two adult children living out of state.  Past Medical History: His past medical history includes high blood pressure (hypertension) diagnosed at the age of 45 and managed with Lisinopril 20 mg per day. He was diagnosed with Type II diabetes mellitus at the age of 50  which has been fairly controlled with metformin 1000mg twice daily with a recent HbA1c of 7.2%. He is a non-smoker but reports occasional alcohol consumption on social occasions. He has no known allergies. His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease  with his father suffering from a heart attack at the age of 60.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented to the outpatient department complaining of a 2-week history of palpitations  fatigue  and shortness of breath causing discomfort  mainly during the exertion.  Examination and Investigations: On examination  his blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg  and his pulse is irregular with a rate ranging from 80-150 beats per minute. An electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm with the absence of P waves  consistent with a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation (AF). Echocardiogram showed the preserved ejection fraction and no valvular abnormalities.  Management: The patient was initiated on Dabigatran  a non-vitamin K antagonist oral anticoagulant (NOAC)  for stroke prevention as his CHA2DS2-VASc score was 3  which indicates moderate risk. Rate control was achieved with Metoprolol succinate 25mg twice daily. His response was good  and his symptoms were controlled noticeably with this treatment. The hypertension management was reviewed  and Lisinopril dose was increased to 40mg daily.  Follow Up: He was scheduled for follow-up in the outpatient clinic every three months for monitoring of his symptoms  heart rate  and to adjust the medications as necessary. Education regarding lifestyle modification including salt and alcohol limit  maintaining a healthy weight  and regular exercise was given.  This case represents a common scenario in the management of patients with atrial fibrillation. The patient’s comorbid conditions such as hypertension and diabetes are significant as they add to his overall cardiovascular risk. This comorbidity and demographic profile is especially relevant given the higher cardiovascular risk associated with African Americans and as per literature  the prevalence of AF is expected to rise in the United States  most notably among elderly and minority populations.

Title: Persistent Atrial Fibrillation in an Elderly Caucasian Female: A Case Study  Background: Atrial fibrillation is the most common heart rhythm disorder and is a significant source of morbidity and mortality  especially in the elderly population. This case describes an 82-year-old Caucasian female who presented with new-onset persistent atrial fibrillation.  Case Presentation:  Patient Information: The patient is an 82-year-old Caucasian female  originally from London  Ontario  Canada. She is a retired schoolteacher and now lives with her daughter and son-in-law.  Medical History: Earlier  the patient had been diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for which she had been on medication (amlodipine  metformin). She has been otherwise relatively healthy with only an occasional visit to her family physician.  Presenting Concerns: The patient presented to the emergency department with sudden weakness  dizziness  shortness of breath  and intermittent palpitations for the past week. She also noted increased fatigue during her daily activities and decreased exercise tolerance.  Clinical Findings: On examination  her blood pressure was slightly elevated  and an irregular heartbeat was noted. Her cardiac examination revealed an irregular rhythm. The electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed atrial fibrillation with an average ventricular rate of 96 beats/minute.  Diagnostic Assessment: Atrial fibrillation was diagnosed based on an electrocardiogram. Blood tests reported slightly elevated glucose levels and mild electrolyte imbalance.  Therapeutic Interventions: The patient was started on anticoagulation (Warfarin) to reduce the risk of stroke and rate control medications (Beta-Blocker-Metoprolol) to control her ventricular rate. Her symptoms improved gradually  and her heartbeat returned to a regular rhythm after 24 hours.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: The patient was followed up in the outpatient cardiology clinic where her blood pressure and heart rate remained controlled. She was educated about stroke symptoms and the importance of medication adherence. She currently maintains a healthy lifestyle  which includes a balanced diet and regular exercise.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of identifying and managing atrial fibrillation  particularly in elderly patients with a history of hypertension and diabetes to avoid potential complications such as stroke. The case also shows the importance of lifestyle modifications and medication adherence for disease management.  Note: This case report is representative of the demographic distribution of atrial fibrillation  which is more common in caucasians  the elderly  and patients with a history of hypertension and diabetes.

Title: Management of Newly Diagnosed Atrial Fibrillation in an Elderly Female Patient  Abstract:  This case report describes the demographics  clinical characteristics  treatment and outcomes of an 80-year-old Caucasian female who was newly diagnosed with atrial fibrillation (AF).  Case Presentation:  Patient Information:  The patient is an 80-year-old Caucasian female of modest socioeconomic status living independently in a suburban community. The patient was previously healthy  living an active lifestyle  with no known allergies. However  a history of hypertension controlled through diet was reported.   Clinical Findings:  The patient presented to the emergency department complaining of palpitations  shortness of breath  fatigue  and light-headedness that had persisted for a few days. On examination  her pulse was irregularly irregular with a rate of 118 bpm  blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and blood oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. An immediate 12-lead ECG confirmed a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response.  Diagnostic Assessment:  The initial laboratory investigation included complete blood count  electrolyte panel  thyroid function tests and coagulation profile which were all within normal limits. Furthermore  a chest X-ray did not show any signs of cardiomegaly or pulmonary congestion. Transthoracic echocardiography revealed enlarged left atrium and preserved left ventricular function.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The treatment plan for the patient included rate control and anticoagulation. Initially  metoprolol was started to control her heart rate. Due to her age and hypertension  she was considered high risk for stroke  as per CHA2DS2-VASc score therefore  oral anticoagulation with apixaban was initiated.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: Regular follow-ups after her discharge showed improvement in her palpitations  fatigue and breathlessness over a course of 8 weeks. Her blood pressure and heart rate improved and stabilized over the following appointments.   Discussion: Atrial fibrillation is commonly diagnosed in the elderly population  and it often presents with symptoms like palpitations  shortness of breath  or fatigue as in this case. Early detection  rate control  and anticoagulation acts as an effective management path  thus helping in improved patient outcomes and quality of life.   Patient Perspective: The patient reported that she felt empowered by the detailed explanation of her condition and treatment plan. She felt relief at the improvement of her symptoms and is willing to comply with the necessary lifestyle changes  follow-ups and treatment plan proposed.   Conclusion: This report demonstrates the classic presentation  diagnosis  and management of atrilateral fibrillation in an elderly patient. Emphasis should be placed on prompt diagnosis  patient education  and a comprehensive approach to treatment and management.

Title: A Case of Non-Valvular Atrial Fibrillation in a 68-year-old African-American Male  Patient Information:  A 68-year-old African-American male  living in an urban area with a former occupation as a factory worker. He is retired and smokes about a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. He also consumes alcohol moderately. His BMI calculates to 30 indicating obesity. There is a family history of cardiovascular diseases; his father died from a heart attack at the age of 72.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a significant medical history of type two diabetes mellitus (T2DM)  controlled with Metformin  and hypertension which is managed with Lisinopril. There are no recorded instances of myocardial infarctions  strokes or transient ischemic attacks. Hyperlipidemia has been managed with Atorvastatin. He had a cholecystectomy 7 years ago. He has been non-compliant with antihypertensive therapy.  Presenting Concerns:  He was presented to the hospital with complaints of irregular heartbeats  shortness of breath and dizziness for the past week. There were also episodes of fatigue  particularly after physical exertion. There were no complaints of chest pain  palpitations  or fainting spells.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed an irregularly irregular pulse at a rate of 125 beats per minute  and blood pressure was a bit elevated at 145/95 mmHg. Examination of the cardiovascular system revealed no heart murmurs  but irregular heartbeat was appreciated on auscultation.  Diagnostic Assessment: Electrocardiography confirmed the diagnosis of atrial fibrillation (AF) with a ventricular rate of 130 beats per minute  the absence of P waves  unorganized electrical activity in the atria  presence of 'f' waves with variable amplitudes  frequencies and morphologies. Echocardiography was negative for valvular heart diseases. Blood investigations showed a slightly elevated HbA1c of 7.3%.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was treated with rate-control strategy using beta-blocker metoprolol and anticoagulant Dabigatran. Attempts to convert to sinus rhythm using drugs were initially successful but AF relapses were frequent.  Follow Up and Outcomes: He was followed up on monthly and then 2-monthly intervals. After one year  the patient is managing on propafenone and Dabigatran. The symptoms are well controlled and he reported some weight loss after joining a weight loss programme.  Patient Perspective: The patient initially found it difficult to deal with the heart condition but has come to terms with it  finding comfort in symptom management and adopting a healthier lifestyle.  Informed Consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.    Concluding Remarks:  This report entails the progression of an African-American patient with persistent non-valvular AF which was likely contributed to by his T2DM  hypertension  and family history. This case highlights the importance of adherence to prescribed medications in controlling associated risk factors to prevent the onset or the progression of AF. Despite societal and public health efforts  there continue to be significant racial and ethnic disparities in AF outcomes  which require further addressing.

Title: Management of Chronic Atrial Fibrillation in a 73-year-old African American Female  Patient Information:   Mrs. A  a 73-year-old African American female  presented to the outpatient department of our medical center  with complaints of on-and-off palpitations of moderate severity  occasional shortness of breath  and fatigue over the past month. The patient was a retired teacher with low socioeconomic status  living with her daughter in an urban area. She was a non-smoker  had no history of alcohol or recreational drug use  and mentioned no recent travel or contact with sick individuals.  Past Medical History:   The patient had a history of hypertension  obesity  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Hypertension was diagnosed about ten years ago and had been relatively well-controlled with a regimen of Lisinopril 10mg once daily. Her type 2 diabetes was managed by Metformin 500mg bid and occasional Insulin use.   Presenting Complaints:  Mrs. A reported episodes of irregular heartbeat  which were occasionally accompanied by lightheadedness. She also mentioned experiencing breathlessness  fatigue  and slight chest discomfort after climbing a flight of stairs or performing other activities that were not previously challenging for her.  Clinical Findings:   On examination  Mrs. A appeared comfortable at rest. Her vital signs were as follow: Temperature 37.0°C  blood pressure 142/90 mmHg  respiratory rate 18 breaths per min  pulse rate irregularly irregular at 120 beats per min  and O2 sat 96% on room air. Cardiac auscultation revealed irregular heart rhythm with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Physical examination was otherwise unremarkable.   Diagnostic Assessment:  Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed atrial fibrillation (AF) with a rapid ventricular rate. Blood tests revealed hemoglobin A1c level of 7.9%  indicating poorly controlled diabetes. Other baseline blood tests including thyroid function tests were within normal range. Transthoracic Echocardiography (TTE) revealed a mildly dilated left atrium  normal left ventricular ejection fraction  and no valve pathology.  Therapeutic Intervention:   Mrs. A was started on metoprolol succinate 25 mg once daily to control her heart rate. Since she had a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 3 (female sex  hypertension  and over 65 years old)  long-term anticoagulant therapy was started with Apixaban 5mg twice daily for stroke prevention.  Follow-up:  She was advised to follow up every month to monitor her symptoms and adjust medication accordingly. She was also referred to a dietician to improve diabetes control as part of her care.  Conclusions:  This case highlights the importance of early detection and comprehensive management of atrial fibrillation  especially in elderly patients with multiple co-morbidities. Management requires a multifaceted approach - beyond rate and rhythm control  it must include stroke prevention and good primary care to address the patient's other health needs.

Case Report: Atrial Fibrillation in a 64-year-old Male   Patient Profile: The patient  Mr. J  is a 64-year-old Caucasian male. Mr. J is of average build  and his lifestyle is mostly sedentary. He has a 50-pack-year history of smoking  although he quit ten years ago. Despite cessation  Mr. J may have suffered extensive damage to his lungs. Since retirement  his consumption of alcohol has increased to moderate levels. The patient lives alone  is a widower  and has three grown-up children.  Past Medical History: Mr. J previously led a relatively healthy life. He was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia about five years ago  conditions which he controls through medication. Mr. J underwent an appendectomy at the age of 26 and has not had any major health issues or surgeries since then.   Present Complaint and History of the Present Illness: Mr. J came to the emergency department with complaints of continued palpitation for the past 12 hours. The patient reported the sensation of his heart “racing” and “fluttering ” accompanied by light-headedness. There were no associated symptoms of chest pain  dyspnea  orthopnea  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. The patient has never experienced symptoms suggestive of a transient ischemic attack or stroke. There was no history of syncope or pre-syncope.   Clinical Examination: On examination  Mr. J appeared moderately distressed. His pulse was irregularly irregular  with a rate of approximately 110 beats/min. His blood pressure was elevated at 160/90 mmHg. Cardiovascular examination disclosed an irregularly irregular rhythm without murmurs  rubs  or gallops. The lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally. The remainder of the physical examination was unremarkable.   Investigations and Diagnosis: An electrocardiogram (EKG) was done  which demonstrated atrial fibrillation with a ventricular response of approximately 110 beats/min. Other laboratory tests  including complete blood count  renal function tests  thyroid function tests  and liver function tests  were within normal limits. The patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation.   Management and Follow Up: The patient was admitted and a rate control strategy was initiated. HIPCO coupling was readily achieved with intravenous diltiazem. The anticoagulant  warfarin  was initiated and titrated to keep his international normalized ratio between 2 and 3. After stabilization  Mr. J was discharged to a regular rhythm with advice to reduce alcohol consumption. He will continue the medical therapy as an outpatient and has been referred to a cardiologist for further management.   In Conclusion: The presence of risk factors like age  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and history of smoking combined with his presenting symptoms led to the diagnosis of atrial fibrillation in Mr. J. His case represents a common occurrence in the demographic of older  white males with cardiovascular risk factors. Through this case review  clinicians can appreciate the characteristic presentation  diagnosis  and management procedure for patients with atrial fibrillation.     (Disclaimer: This is a hypothetical case created for illustrative purposes.)

Case Report: Atrial Fibrillation in a 72-year-old Caucasian Male Patient  Patient Profile: The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. X  residing in an urban neighborhood of Los Angeles  California. He is a retired college professor  married with two children  and is an active smoker with a history of moderate alcohol consumption.   Presenting Concern: Mr. X presented to the clinic complaining of palpitations  fatigue  shortness of breath  and occasional dizziness for the past month. These symptoms had increased in severity over the past week  prompting him to seek medical attention.  Medical History: The patient's medical history reveals diagnosed hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he has been on medication for ten years. He has a familial history of cardiovascular disease  with both his father and older brother dying of myocardial infarction in their early 70s. He also reports occasional episodes of breathlessness and chest discomfort during rigorous physical activities for the past year. He has not undergone any surgeries in the past.   Physical Examination and Diagnostic Evaluation: Baseline vitals were taken. Blood pressure was elevated at 150/90 mm Hg  pulse irregular and rapid at 110 beats per minute  temperature and respiratory rate within normal range. Cardiac examination confirmed irregular heart rate. Rest of his physical examination was unremarkable.   An electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed  revealing irregularly irregular rhythms consistent with atrial fibrillation (AF). He also underwent a transthoracic echocardiogram  which showed normal left ventricular function and no sign of valvular disease. Blood tests were done  cholesterol level was high and thyroid function was normal.   Management and Follow-up: The patient was diagnosed with non-valvular atrial fibrillation. Anticoagulation therapy was commenced immediately with Apixaban to reduce the risk of stroke. In addition  beta-blockers were prescribed for rate control. The patient was counselled on lifestyle modification including quitting smoking  limiting alcohol consumption  maintaining a healthy diet  and regular exercise to manage his hypertension and hyperlipidemia.   Mr. X was scheduled for a clinic visit after two weeks to monitor his clinical condition and adjust the medication regime if required. He was also advised to immediately report to the hospital if his current symptoms worsen or if he develops new symptoms such as severe chest pain  fainting  or difficulty in speaking or seeing.   Concluding Remarks: This case highlights the importance of early detection and management of atrial fibrillation  especially in patients with multiple risk factors  in preventing severe complications like stroke. It also underscores the significance of lifestyle modification in managing cardiovascular conditions.

Title: A Case Report of Atrial Fibrillation in an African American Male with a History of Hypertension  Patient Information: The patient is a 65-year-old African American male named Mr. James Bartholomew  living in Washington D.C.  Chief Complaint: Mr. Bartholomew presented at the clinic with complaints of generalized fatigue  heart palpitations  and intermittent chest discomfort. His symptoms began two weeks ago and progressively worsened.  Medical History: Mr. Bartholomew has a 10-year history of hypertension which had been managed with Lisinopril 20mg daily. He has no known history of diabetes mellitus or heart disease and has no history of smoking or alcohol consumption. There is a family history of cardiovascular diseases; his father died at 69 from a myocardial infarction.  Clinical Findings: Upon examination  his blood pressure was slightly elevated at 150/90 mmHg. His pulse was irregularly irregular  with a rate varying from 70 to 130 beats per minute. Chest examination and other systems were normal.  Diagnostic Assessment: An EKG revealed atrial fibrillation with a variable ventricular response. Laboratory analysis indicated elevated D-dimer levels. A Transthoracic Echocardiogram indicated a mildly dilated left atrium. No thrombi were detected in the atrial cavities.  Therapeutic intervention:  Mr. Bartholomew was started on Warfarin for anticoagulation and Metoprolol to control the ventricular response rate. He was scheduled for a follow-up in the Cardiology Unit for possible cardioversion.  Outcome and follow-up:   Two weeks post initiation of therapy  on repeat EKG  the atrial fibrillation had converted to sinus rhythm. Blood pressure was controlled  and he reported a significant reduction in symptoms. He is advised to continue his current medications and to follow up regularly for INR monitoring while on warfarin. Lifestyle modification education concerning diet  exercise  and stress management was also given.  Discussion: This case highlights the common presentation of atrial fibrillation in a patient with a known history of hypertension. It underscores the need for routine follow-ups in patients with cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension. Early detection and management of atrial fibrillation are crucial in preventing devastating complications such as stroke and heart failure. Further research is needed to explore the disparity in the occurrence and management of atrial fibrillation in the African American population.   Patient Consent: Informed Patient Consent was obtained for this case report.   Ethics Approval: Not applicable.

Title: Chronic Atrial Fibrillation in a 75-Year-Old Male: A Case Report  Patient Demographic Information:  Mr. J.S. is a 75-year-old Caucasian male of middle socioeconomic status born and raised in the Midwest of the United States. He is married with three grown children and retired from a 45-year career as a corporate banker. He doesn't smoke and drinks alcohol socially.  Past Medical History:  His past medical history is significant for controlled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and prostatic hypertrophy. He has been compliant on his medication: hydrochlorothiazide  atorvastatin  and tamsulosin. Despite these comorbidities  he was physically active and maintained a regular exercise regimen until the onset of consistent palpitations  fatigue  and dyspnea.  Current Case:  He presented to the cardiology outpatient department complaining of irregular heartbeats  general fatigue  slight breathlessness on exertion  and occasional lightheadedness for the last few months. An Electrocardiogram (ECG) was conducted revealing a chaotic rhythm in the upper chambers of the heart  leading to the diagnosis of chronic atrial fibrillation (AF).  He doesn't have any records of previous ischemic strokes or transient ischemic attacks. His current CHA2DS2-VASc score  used to estimate the risk of stroke in patients with non-rheumatic atrial fibrillation  is 3 (1 point each for age  hypertension  and hypertrophy)  implying a moderate risk for future stroke.  Management:  A detailed discussion was carried out regarding the advantages and pitfalls of rate versus rhythm control strategies. Considering his symptoms and his wish to maintain an active lifestyle  rhythm control was considered better.  He was started on anticoagulation therapy with Apixaban to reduce his stroke risk. Also  a rhythm control strategy was opted by starting him on Amiodarone. He will be considered for cardioversion once his anticoagulation has been established for a few weeks if the irregular heartbeats persist and prove to be symptomatic. He was also counseled about lifestyle modifications helpful in atrial fibrillation management  including moderation in alcohol intake and maintenance of a healthy weight.           Over a period  he will be on regular follow-up to assess the efficacy and side-effects of the treatment and to manage the AF optimally.  Takeaway:  Atrial fibrillation is not uncommon in the aging population and demands careful attention due to its possible complications  including stroke. This case reiterates the importance of individualizing the management of atrial fibrillation based on patient’s symptoms  preferences  and associated comorbidities.

Title: Management of Atrial Fibrillation in an Elderly Female Patient with Comorbid Hypertension and Diabetes: A Case Report  Introduction:  Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common cardiac arrhythmia  disproportionately affecting people of old age. Here we present the case of an 82-year-old African-American woman diagnosed with atrial fibrillation  utilizing a personalized treatment approach to manage her condition.  Case Presentation:  The patient  Mrs. J  is an 82-year-old African-American woman  living independently at home  who presented at our cardiology department with complaints of palpitations  increasing episodes of shortness of breath  fatigue and occasional dizziness. She has a past clinical history of hypertension (for 20 years) and type 2 diabetes mellitus (for 15 years). She does not smoke or consume alcohol. She maintains her blood glucose levels with metformin and controls her blood pressure with daily administration of lisinopril.  Physical examination revealed an irregular rhythm with a heart rate of 120 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg. Her body mass index was found to be 29kg/m^2  indicating she is overweight.  Investigations:  An Electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed atrial fibrillation with a ventricular rate of 120 beats per minute. Echocardiography showed a normal left ventricular ejection fraction with no significant valvular heart disease. Blood work showed slightly elevated blood glucose levels controlled by an established metformin regimen.  Management and Follow-up:  Given the patient's age  presence of AF  hypertension  diabetes  and risk of stroke (as evaluated by CHA2DS2-VASc score)  anticoagulation was initiated with oral apixaban (a direct oral anticoagulant). Rate control was achieved through administration of a beta-blocker: metoprolol.  Lifestyle modifications were advised  including a low sodium and low carbohydrate diet  regular physical activity  and weight management.  The patient received comprehensive education about her condition and the importance of medication adherence. She was followed up regularly  every three months  at the outpatient department.
